title: Scholarships for Jobless Engineers
description: In 1961, in the heady aftermath of Sputnik, in the age of the missile gap, some of the region's largest military contractors banded together to set up a school on the edge of an airfield here to train a new generation of engineers and scientists.

title: 1992 CAMPAIGN: Congress; With Ingredients for Revolt, Illinois May Lead Way in Anti-Incumbent Vote
description: If the American public's general unhappiness with Congress is going to cost individual lawmakers their jobs, the March 17 primary in once insurgent-proof Illinois will be the first place it shows.

title: Pepsi Widens 'Generation' With New Pitch to All Ages
description: WHEN Coca-Cola introduced a completely new marketing campaign for its Pepsi-like "new" Coke in 1985, exultant Pepsi-Cola executives boasted that "the other guy blinked." Now, as Pepsi readies a revamped marketing campaign, it is Coke's turn to make the same taunt.

title: Russia's Cup Entry Appears Grounded
description: Russia's first attempt to compete for the America's Cup, characterized by bizarre circumstances, appears to have reached a bitter conclusion.

title: California Leader Explains Speech Mix-Up
description: Gov. Pete Wilson blamed himself and his press office today for the confusion surrounding the existence and identity of three men he referred to in his State of the State Message.

title: Stars & Stripes Beats Jayhawk
description: Dennis Conner and his Stars & Stripes crew sailed aggressively today to defeat William Koch, who skippered Jayhawk, by 2 minutes 16 seconds in the trials to pick an America's Cup defender.

title: Rob Lowe Braves Farce
description: It was open season on Rob Lowe -- yes, that Rob Lowe -- as soon as the usual suspects realized the actor was making his Broadway debut in "A Little Hotel on the Side," the second offering of the National Actors Theater. "A National Scandal," punned the headline on the People page of The Daily News when it ran pictures of Mr. Lowe. And Cindy Adams reminded her readers in The New York Post that Mr. Lowe "personally staged a now famous production a while back in some little hotel on the side in Atlanta," referring to the actor's naughty videotape at the 1988 Democratic National Convention.

title: Bridge
description: Those who play regularly in clubs and tournaments will find many good things in a new book by Dr. George Rosenkranz of Mexico City. It is "More Tips for Tops", a wide-ranging discussion of important aspects of bidding, play and defense, and it is available for $12.95, including mailing, from Baron-Barclay Bridge Supplies, by calling (800) 274-2221.

title: Planned Parenthood Clinic In Montana Damaged by Fire
description: The office of a Planned Parenthood clinic where abortions are performed was heavily damaged by fire Saturday.

title: Taylor Takes Turn For the Best
description: He was fighting before hometown fans and that might have emboldened Meldrick Taylor, the World Boxing Association welterweight champion.

title: SHL Systemhouse reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: Pioneer-Standard Electronics Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Sales represented net sales.

title: In Albany, a Long-Term Budget Is Best
description: To the Editor:

title: Sven Dodington, 79, Inventor of System To Guide Aircraft
description: Sven H. Dodington, the inventor of the basic navigation system used to guide aircraft throughout the world, died on Jan. 13 at the Crestwood Nursing Home in Whippany, N.J. He was 79 years old and a resident of Mountain Lakes, N.J.

title: Riley Yells 'Foul!' And Takes A Shot
description: The Knicks' 108-106 loss to the Cleveland Cavaliers on Saturday night figures to have a wide-ranging impact.

title: Road to Minneapolis On 615 Miles of Film
description: It's back to football this year for STEVE SABOL.

title: New Magazine By Times Co.
description: The New York Times Company Women's Magazines is starting Fitness, a sports and health magazine for women that will be published four times a year, starting in February.

title: Book Theft at St. Patrick's
description: A large religious book was stolen early yesterday from an altar in St. Patrick's Cathedral, the police said. The Book of the Gospels, on display in the Sacred Heart Altar, was taken between 6 and 7 A.M., before the first Mass at the cathedral on Fifth Avenue at 50th Street. A police spokeswoman, Sgt. Theresa C. Tobin, said a 16-year-old boy tried to take the book on Saturday night, but was stopped. A young male was seen rushing from the church at 6:20 A.M. yesterday, she said. A spokesman for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, Joseph Zwilling, said that the book was a gift and that he did not know its age or value.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; Networks Tuning Out Pilots As a Way to Develop Shows
description: LIKE many other traditions from network television's past, the process of beginning a new prime-time series with a highly produced, carefully polished pilot episode is doing a slow fade-out.

title: Leader of Bulgaria Wins Election Over Ex-Communists' Candidate
description: President Zhelyu Zhelev won the country's first direct presidential election on Sunday, defeating a lawyer backed by former Communists, unofficial results indicated.

title: Track Record Polishes Golden Globes' Gleam
description: Barbra and Bette showed up. So did Warren and Annette. And Dustin and Kevin and Arnold and Michelle and Robin and Anjelica and Jodie and just about every other major star and powerbroker in town crammed into a hotel ballroom on Saturday night for an old-fashioned Hollywood event that was, by all accounts, the glitziest and most curious awards ceremonies of the year.

title: 6,800 Miles From Tokyo, East Meets West at a Shopping Mall
description: About once a month, when the selection at the local Stop and Shop in Warwick, R.I., just won't do, Masatomo Kobayashi gets into the car with his 9-year-old son and drives nearly four hours to Edgewater and the Yaohan Plaza.

title: Beijing Journal; Crime Is Up in China, and So Is the Public's Rage
description: Chinese prisons tend to be short of food and long on lice, beatings, and coffin-sized punishment cells. Felons can be executed immediately after the most perfunctory of trials, even for nonviolent offenses like embezzlement, and criminals' families are sometimes billed a few cents for the cost of the bullet used to execute their loved ones.

title: Apathy Is Seen Greeting Agony Of the Homeless
description: A decade after homeless and destitute people began flooding city streets, religious leaders say they fear that Americans are beginning to turn away from the outstretched hands, numbed by the severity of the problem and confused about how to respond.

title: Seymour Rotker Weds Barrie Stern
description: Barrie Stern, an art director, was married yesterday to Acting Justice Seymour Rotker of New York State Supreme Court. Rabbi Joseph Weiss officiated at the Water's Edge Restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: NBC Thinks Being No. 1 Is Too Costly
description: NBC has no interest in losing tens of millions of dollars on sporting events to remain the highest-rated network, Robert C. Wright, the network's president, told a group of investment counselors on Friday.

title: After X's and O's, Focus Is on $'s and 's
description: Memo to National Football League general managers: Maybe those eager young players coming out of college really do need an agent.

title: Books of The Times; World on the Brink of Nuclear War
description: Eyeball to Eyeball The Inside Story of the Cuban Missile Crisis By Dino A. Brugioni Illustrated. 622 pages. Random House. $35.

title: Horse of the Year 1991: Down to an Unlikely 3
description: The envelope, please. And, for Horse of the Year in 1991, the winner is. . . .

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Environmental Hazards to Poor Gain New Focus at E.P.A.
description: An Environmental Protection Agency scientist in Chicago is putting the final touches on a computer program that can identify neighborhoods where childhood exposure to lead is likely to be rampant. Corrective measures would be concentrated there -- most likely focusing the benefits on black children, who are known to suffer disproportionately from lead poisoning.

title: Washington Talk; Trying to Turn a Deficit Into a Political Asset
description: The problem for President Bush's budget planners this year was how to meet his election-year political needs without seeming to ignore the enormous Federal deficit.

title: Dispute Over a Dam on the Scenic Yangtze
description: THE Three Gorges Dam would be far from the highest ever built, but it certainly would be among the most controversial water projects in the world.

title: And We Call Ourselves Democrats?
description: Last summer, before I announced my candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination, it never occurred to me to worry whether the chairman of the Democratic National Committee in Washington or network executives in New York would like my message. Instead, I worried whether millions of Americans would respond to a campaign calling for immediate measures to cut the military budget in half and use the funds to rebuild our country.

title: Corrections
description: The Guide column of the Westchester Weekly on Sunday misstated the date of the Thomas Paine National Historical Association's dinner honoring Robert MacNeil of PBS. It will be held in New Rochelle, N.Y., on Jan. 30, not this Thursday.

title: International Game Technology
description: International Game Technology Inc. received an order from Manitoba's government for 400 additional video lottery terminals, Marcia Hunt, communications manager for the Manitoba Lottery Foundation, said. With the latest award, the province has ordered a total of 1,200 terminals under a contract with the Reno-based video game and slot machine manufacturer.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Two architects and a United States Senator will receive the first Thomas Jefferson Award for Public Architecture, to be given by the American Institute of Architects tomorrow. The awards will be presented at a reception expected to draw 600 people to the institute's headquarters in Washington.

title: Laidlaw Ban Is Considered
description: Canada's Competition Tribunal said it was considering banning Laidlaw Inc., the Canadian transportation and waste removal concern, from acquiring any new commercial waste businesses in three regions of Vancouver Island for three years.

title: Britain Rejects a Hard Line in Ulster
description: Prime Minister John Major and rival political leaders vowed today to press Britain's fight against the Irish Republican Army in Northern Ireland, but the Government sidestepped demands for hard-line security measures in the province, including detention of suspected terrorists without trial.

title: A Spiral Galaxy
description: Scientists say they have found the strongest evidence yet for a distant spiral galaxy in which one arm points in the opposite direction from the others.

title: Standard Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $ 612,000 in the quarter and $ 945,000 in the 6 months.

title: International Dairy Queen reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alpo Petfoods, Allentown, Pa., a unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., named Kevin T. Martin president. * American International Group, New York, an insurance company, named Steve A. Schleisman president of the North American division of American International Underwriters, the company's overseas property and casualty insurance organization.

title: Flak Jackets Available For New York Jockeys
description: Flak jackets to protect jockeys in spills will be furnished to riders at New York's tracks, the New York Racing Association announced yesterday. But the jackets, which are mandatory in England, will be optional with riders here and will count against the weight limit stipulated for each horse.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by Reuters in the Media Business columns of Business Day on Jan. 13 about the Turner Broadcasting System misstated the year in which the company expects to earn more than $100 million. It is 1992, not 1991.

title: Electronic Arts reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NS Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
Bridge
description: Many of the world's best partnerships were contending in the Netherlands during the weekend, but only two of them were in contention at the finish. It was the sixth Cap Gemini Pandata World Top tournament played in The Hague, and the winners were Zia Mahmood and Michael Rosenberg of Manhattan. With one match remaining they led by two imps over the star Dutch pair, Enri Leufkens and Berry Westra. They held on to win by exactly that margin, but the places would have been reversed if a good slam contract reached by the Dutch pair had succeeded.

title: UBS Is Hiring For U.S. Jobs
description: UBS Securities Inc., the American securities unit of the Union Bank of Switzerland, is hiring Wall Street traders and salespeople in what it said was a move to increase its presence in the United States.

title: Bank Director to Head British Takeover Board
description: Frances Heaton, a director of the investment bank Lazard Brothers, was appointed director general of Britain's Panel on Takeovers and Mergers, the regulatory body that reviews business combinations and acquisitions.

title: Legent Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Stratus C0mputer Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Prudential Payment Ordered
description: The New York Stock Exchange has ordered Prudential Securities Inc. to pay more than $686,000 in damages to Anglo-American Financial, a private partnership that accused Prudential of fraud, breach of contract and misrepresentation in a 1988 transaction.

title: International Crew Set For Shuttle Launching
description: THE space shuttle Discovery is poised to carry an international crew into orbit on a mission that will simulate many of the planned activities aboard Space Station Freedom.

title: Landmark Graphics Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pietro di Donato Is Dead at 80; Wrote of Immigrants' Experience
description: Pietro di Donato, whose novel "Christ in Concrete" was acclaimed as an American classic when it was published in 1938, died on Sunday at University Hospital in Stony Brook, L.I. He was 80 years old and lived in Setauket, L.I., for many years.

title: Most Markets Open Yesterday
description: Trading in government, corporate and tax-exempt bonds was suspended yesterday in observance of the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and the regular Monday Treasury bill auction was postponed until today. The markets for stocks, futures contracts, commodities, precious metals and currencies, however, were open as usual. Most banks were closed, as were Federal, state and municipal offices in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Raytheon Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mets and Magadan Meet Halfway
description: Feelings may still need to be mended, but the Mets and Dave Magadan yesterday did manage to end one significant difference of opinion when they agreed on a one-year contract for a figure that fell midway between their salary arbitration filings of last week.

title: Global Marine Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats; Pragmatism Is a Big Winner As Clinton Gains in New York
description: In a display of political pragmatism that brought together Democrats who spent the early months of the Presidential campaign waiting first for Jesse Jackson and then Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to declare their intentions, several prominent New York City Democrats announced yesterday that they would support Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: GAS PIPELINE SET TO OPEN

title: Qualcomm Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
New Cancer Clue: How Cells Talk To Each Other
description: SEVERAL times each day, a normal cell in the body mutates into a cancerous one but is knocked out by the body's defense mechanisms. Occasionally, however, the mutant cells take hold and grow uncontrollably into a malignant tumor.

title: Sealright Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hope and Anger Mix on King Day
description: In pride, anger and sorrow, the nation, and blacks in particular, paid homage to the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today on the seventh observance of the national holiday established in his honor.

title: Borland International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 116 million in restructuring and pooling costs.c-Net incomeThe year-ago periods are restated for the pooling of interests.

title: 2 Revlon Brands Sold; Executives Also Move
description: In what is emerging as a strategy to focus on its core business, Revlon Inc. has sold two more of its brands, and several of its top international executives went along with the businesses, the company said yesterday.

title: Central & South West Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Russian Visit to Nymex
description: A delegation from the fledgling Moscow Commodity Exchange will visit the New York Mercantile Exchange from March 2 to 13 to receive training in exchange procedures, Nymex said yesterday. The visit is a result of an agreement signed last summer, before the mid-August Soviet coup. In the spring, a Nymex delegation will visit Moscow.

title: Southwestern Bell
description: Heard of call-waiting? Get ready for call-nagging. The Southwestern Bell Corporation is testing a service in which an operator tries to deliver a recorded message every 30 minutes over a six-hour period to any telephone number that has a busy signal or does not answer after five rings. The message can be up to three minutes long and the customer who records it can designate the best hours to try to deliver the message and when to stop trying. The service, which costs $1.50 a message, is being tested in Oklahoma in the 405 area code.

title: Q&A
description: Swimming Weather

title: Market Place; Nasdaq at Night: Risky Trades in the Dark
description: The overnight trading of American stocks on Nasdaq began yesterday with a clear warning to brokers of the risks of global trading, as one trader apparently managed to sell shares in a small American company at an unrealistically high price.

title: Commonwealth Edison Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-In November 1991, the company recorded the remaining portion of an unreasonable plant cost disallowance charge amounting to $ 706.4 million, resulting in a reduction to net income of $ 533.7 million, or $ 2.51 a share.c-Net income

title: Andrew Stein's Interests
description: City Council President Andrew Stein can't seem to keep his reasoning straight. Originally he said he wouldn't participate in New York City's system of public campaign financing, designed to limit the influence of monied interests, because he couldn't justify spending taxpayer dollars on politics. Now, set to challenge Mayor David Dinkins in 1993, Mr. Stein adds, "I don't see why I should have one hand tied behind my back running against an incumbent."

title: Books of The Times; Wanted: A Father, and a Cure for Love and Loss
description: The Lost Father By Mona Simpson 506 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.

title: G.M.'s Gone, but This City's Alive
description: On Nov. 6, 1986, General Motors delivered a body blow to this city of 24,000. To cut costs, the auto maker said it would close its 64-year-old plant here that assembled Chevrolet Camaros and Pontiac Firebirds.

title: Mitek Systems Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Knicks Hold Off Pacers to Regain Peace of Mind
description: It was not pretty, nor was it particularly exciting. But their victory yesterday was something the Knicks sorely needed.

title: Star Clusters Astonish Astronomers
description: PEERING deep into the heart of a distant galaxy, the Hubble Space Telescope has astonished astronomers by revealing a scattering of dense clusters of young blue stars. They appear to be clues to the cataclysmic collisions of galaxies eons ago.

title: TransCanada Pipelines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: On My Mind; In Search of Buckley
description: After more than a year of study of the abundant record, William F. Buckley Jr., columnist, novelist, television host, lecturer and distinguished sailor, finally has delivered the judgment that Patrick Buchanan, Republican candidate for the Presidency, really has said "things about Jews" that are anti-Semitic.

title: Corrections
description: The Patents column in Business Day on Dec. 21 misidentified an anti-ulcer drug that improved the behavioral problems of a schizophrenia patient and prompted a psychiatrist at Mount Sinai Medical Center to begin research into using such drugs for treating a form of schizophrenia. It was Pepcid, from Merck & Company, not Zantac, from Glaxo Holdings.

title: Cuomo Wants to Increase Tuition And Cut State Jobs and Medicaid
description: To close the gap of nearly $5 billion in next year's $31 billion budget, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposes authorizing sharp tuition increases at SUNY campuses, eliminating more than 5,000 state jobs, cutting Medicaid spending by about $1 billion and deferring more than $1 billion in tax cuts.

title: Sonoco Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraoardinary credit of $ 4.5 million after-tax, or 10 cents a share, on gain from sale of the company's 40 percent interest in Sonoco Graham Co.c-After a one-time after-tax charge of $ 54.7 million to cover restructuring costs.

title: George Carlin, Small but Amusing
description: All actors hunger for a role that allows them to stretch. George Carlin landed one that requires him to shrink, all the way down to 18 inches. As the magical Mr. Conductor, he appears out of thin air to advise, amuse and tell stories about Thomas the Tank Engine to the children of "Shining Time Station," the children's series on PBS.

title: Florio Signs Regulations On Batteries
description: In a move to reduce the amount of metal pollutants dumped in New Jersey, Gov. Jim Florio today signed into law a bill that he said imposed one of the toughest standards in the nation on the manufacture and disposal of dry-cell batteries.

title: Dibble and Surhoff Sign
description: ROB DIBBLE of Cincinnati and B. J. SURHOFF of Milwaukee have negotiated 1992 salaries with their teams.

title: New Microsoft-Intel System
description: The Microsoft Corporation and the Intel Corporation announced a software system today that they said would extend the battery life of portable computers.

title: Kimball International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are class A, primary.

title: Structural Dynamics Research Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective on July 29, 1991.Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: New Show Spurs Debate On Old Issue
description: A TELEVISION program being offered to local stations around the country would combine elements of traditional talk shows with the buy-it-now sales pitches of home-shopping channels. If it enters production this fall, the program would be the latest in a spate of new media ventures that blur the line between editorial content and advertising.

title: 1992 CAMPAIGN: Endorsements; Elaborate Ritual Mates Candidates and Backers
description: Once every four years, people like Louis L. Goldstein, Joseph E. Gardner and Don Fraser migrate to the center of the political universe. Governors call them at home. Presidential candidates visit them at work. Rich and powerful friends take them out to expensive meals.

title: Troubled Redmen Defeated
description: As the Big East season reaches the point where contending teams are seeking the confidence of consistent success, the St. John's Redmen find themselves grasping in vain for both. Their 75-60 loss to Seton Hall at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight, the third in the last five conference games, held just one bright spot:

title: Dow Drops 10.95 in Quiet Holiday Trading
description: Stock prices pulled back a bit yesterday from last week's surge to a record, remaining in a fairly narrow range throughout the session. Because of the holiday honoring the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., trading was far quieter than last week's hectic pace. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 10.95 points to finish at 3,254.03.

title: Progress Software Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-13 U.N. DEMAND ON LIBYA EXPECTED

title: In Research on Cervical Cancer, A Wart Virus Is the Prime Suspect
description: SCIENTISTS have discovered the nasty tricks used by a virus that causes genital warts, and largely because of these discoveries the virus has emerged as the primary suspect in nearly all cervical cancer.

title: Rasterops Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Galapagos Mystery Solved: Fauna Evolved on Vanished Isle
description: TO biologists, the Galapagos Islands are very special places, not least because their distinctive wildlife prompted Darwin to hit upon the theory of evolution. But the islands, off the coast of Ecuador, have long posed a troublesome evolutionary mystery: geologically, they are far too young for evolution, operating at its usual pace, to have produced the many unique life forms that now inhabit the islands.

title: Computer Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Included after-tax gain of $ 2.1 million, or 13 cents a share, on the formation of a general partnership with Equifax Inc.

title: Trash Station In Rail Yard Is Scrapped
description: After bitter opposition from residents and business people and intervention by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the Long Island Rail Road has dropped plans to install a garbage-shipment operation at a freight yard in Queens.

title: Diplomats Are Edgy as India Stubbornly Builds Its Nuclear Arsenal
description: In sharp contrast to the rest of the world, South Asia is on the brink of a nuclear arms race, say senior Western diplomats and foreign political figures who have visited New Delhi in recent weeks.

title: Scientists Suggest Global Warming Could Hasten the Next Ice Age
description: IF global warming proceeds as forecast, it could cause the Northern Hemisphere's ice sheets to expand much as they did at the start of the last Ice Age, when the world's climate was slightly warmer than it is today, American and Canadian scientists say.

title: Diebold Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Karl Confirms It: He's Talking to Sonics
description: GEORGE KARL said yesterday he was going to Seattle to be interviewed for the vacant head-coaching job with the SuperSonics.

title: Oregon St. Player Who Had Stroke Dies
description: Earnest Killum, who decided to play basketball for Oregon State despite a blood-clotting disorder, died today, three days after suffering his second stroke in six months.

title: Twin Disc Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Congress Returns Today To Fight Over Economy
description: Congressional leaders are predicting that they will kick out of the starting block when they return to work Tuesday, trying to overcome election-year partisanship and act quickly on a number of measures intended to stimulate the economy, like a tax cut for the middle class and an extension of unemployment benefits for the jobless.

title: This Time, The Bills And Levy Are Ready
description: Last year, in his team's first appearance in the Super Bowl, Bills Coach Marv Levy skipped media day, one of the first mass press gatherings of the week, choosing to work on his game plan instead. He was fined by the National Football League for that break with protocol.

title: Chess
description: The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign triumphed in the 1991 Pan-American Intercollegiate Team Championship, held at the Palmer House Hotel in Chicago from Dec. 27 to 30. The Illinois team scored 5 1/2- 1/2 to surpass 33 teams from Canada, Central America and the United States in the six-round, Swiss-system tournament.

title: FOR SOUTH AFRICA, ONE STEP FORWARD
description: Negotiations on South Africa's future took a small but significant step forward today as representatives of 19 political parties and groups gathered to work out the first practical details for formal talks leading to a non-racist constitution.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Daniel Saidenberg Faculty Recital Series Juilliard Theater

title: Pacific Telesis Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a restructuring charge of $ 122 million in the quarter and year; the year also included a $ 28 million gain from sale of cellular holdings, U.K. Microtel holdings and settlement of lawsuit.c-After a restructuring charge of $ 72 million in the quarter and year.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There is no job-placement office at the United States Military Academy at West Point, so leaders of the West Point Society, an alumni association in the New York area, decided last year that it was time to promote a little networking to help graduates with their job searches. The effort was such a success that it is being repeated tonight at the Union League Club in Manhattan.

title: Business and Health; Efforts to Reduce Retiree Costs
description: PUSHED by a new accounting rule, most large employers are examining ways to reduce the enormous future costs of medical benefits they have promised to retirees. Benefits consultants say some executives view the benefits as a "gratuity" rather than a permanent obligation, when they are not detailed in an employment contract. But most employers say they are committed to continuing the programs, albeit often with reduced benefits, despite rapid growth in both medical costs and the numbers of retirees.

title: American Electric Power reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SHAMIR IS VOWING NEW SETTLEMENTS
description: In a direct challenge to Bush Administration calls for his Government to stop building settlements in occupied lands, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir declared defiantly today that "this construction will continue and no power in the world will prevent this construction."

title: Jailed Drug Cartel Chief Still Feared in Colombia
description: Seven months after Pablo Escobar, Colombia's most notorious drug trafficker, entered a luxury jail here, his word still inspires terror across the land.

title: Thrift Office's Eager Terminator
description: In the mire of the savings and loan mess, T. Timothy Ryan Jr., the nation's top savings and loan regulator, has gotten remarkably little mud on his clothes.

title: 2 East German Guards Convicted Of Killing Man as He Fled to West
description: In a case that raised far-reaching political and moral questions, two former East German border guards were convicted today of having shot and killed a fleeing refugee in February 1989.

title: Duff & Phelps Stock Offering
description: Duff & Phelps, the third-largest credit rating agency, said today that it plans to sell 3.5 million common shares at about $17 a share in an initial public offering next month.

title: Broader Use Of Macintosh Software Set
description: A Silicon Valley company plans to announce a program on Wednesday that permits users and developers to run programs designed for Apple Computer's Macintosh on Sun, I.B.M. and Silicon Graphics work stations. It will be the first significant attempt to use software designed for the Macintosh on other computers.

title: Tests by Genzyme
description: Researchers from the Genzyme Corporation and Tufts University said they had developed a possible way to mass-produce a protein for the treatment of cystic fibrosis, a lung disease. They said they had genetically altered mice with a human gene that governs production of the protein and harvested it from fat globules in the mices' milk. Genzyme, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., said the tests marked the first time proteins normally attached to cell membranes had been produced in animal milk.

title: Valley Resources Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Paul P. Gewirtz, 87, Music Publisher, Dies
description: Paul P. Gewirtz, a retired music-publishing executive, died on Saturday while vacationing in Satellite Beach, Fla. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sanofi in Deal With Unilever
description: Unilever P.L.C., the British consumer products company, agreed in principle to sell the rights to the Fendi trademark for its fragrances and cosmetics in certain parts of the world to Sanofi S.A., the French health-care conglomerate. The transaction is expected to be completed by the end of April. The price was not disclosed.

title: Stocks Decline in Tokyo
description: Japanese stock prices posted a 16-month low today for the second day in a row. The Nikkei index of 225 shares closed at 20,858.30 at the end of afternoon trading, down 55.52 points, or 0.27 percent.

title: Chinese Aim to Harness Yangtze and Yellow Rivers
description: DISCONTENT with the way the heavens have arranged its rivers and rainfall, China is embarking on a program to build huge waterworks that could have a colossal impact on the nation's development in the 21st century.

title: New Image Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Cuban Firing Squad Executes Exile
description: A Cuban exile convicted of sabotage and terrorism was executed by firing squad today in a warning the Government said was aimed at right-wing exile groups operating from the United States. Eduardo Diaz Betancourt, 38 years old, was shot after appeals for clemency were turned down by Cuba's Supreme Court and the ruling Council of State headed by President Fidel Castro.

title: Insurer Has Big Investor: Metropolitan
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has agreed to buy half of the Executive Life Insurance Company of New York, a move that should greatly ease the concerns of the 100,000 policyholders in limbo since insurance regulators seized Executive Life and its sister company in California last spring.

title: A Top Japanese Politician Calls U.S. Work Force Lazy
description: One of Japan's most senior politicians said over the weekend that America's economic troubles were rooted in a work force "too lazy" to compete with Japan, and argued that one of the biggest problems of the United States was that nearly a third of its workers "cannot even read."

title: Continuum Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports of The Times; The Perils Of Life in Minneapolis
description: THEY have signs on some of the larger streets here that inform drivers that these are "Snow Emergency Routes." The signs draw a glance from the Super Bowl crowd beginning to stream in for next Sunday's game. The signs in fact are not taken down even in summer. I remember asking someone about this when I moved here in 1965. "Remove them?" she said. "For three days?"

title: So What's in the Cage? Excitement With Ears
description: THE excitement had built all week in the preschool class at the Wilton Family Y. The animal lady was coming, and she might bring real live animals. Now kids know instinctively that no sane adult, especially teachers like Marcia Shushan and Maggie Schluntz, is ever going to suggest the exciting possibility of live animals unless they know darned well the creatures are coming. No one, even after nap time, invites the volatile disappointment of a platoon of short people whose lifetime perspective is measured in months.

title: Bruno's Inc.  reports earnings for 14wks to Dec 28
Ban on Muslim Political Party Expected in Algeria
description: The Algerian Government appears to be moving toward an official ban of the Islamic fundamentalist party as well as significant changes in the multiparty system that it has permitted since 1989, senior Algerian officials said today.

title: Omni Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net incomec-Net loss

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House; BUSH AIDES DIVIDED ON HOW TO CORRECT SLIP IN POPULARITY
description: The struggle over how to stop President Bush's political slide has fanned staff rivalries in the White House and intensified a broader debate over campaign tactics and economic policy, Administration officials and Republican strategists said today.

title: Careers; Some Views On Job Loss By an Expert
description: WITH so many thousands of middle managers losing their jobs, the outplacement business should be booming. But while business is good, it is not booming because companies dismissing large numbers of middle and top managers do not want to pay the costs. Often they pay only for group sessions and other short-term guidance.

title: LIBYA IS EXPECTED TO GET U.N. DEMAND ON BOMB SUSPECTS
description: The United Nations Security Council is expected to serve Libya on Tuesday with a virtual demand that it hand over agents accused of blowing up Pan American Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland in December 1988 or face the threat of economic sanctions.

title: Article 162992 -- No Title
description: Setting up a battle with the Agnelli family of Italy, Nestle made a $2.4 billion bid today for Source Perrier S.A.

title: BASEBALL;
description: The Yankees assured themselves of having a sturdy starting catcher for the next three seasons as they avoided arbitration with Matt Nokes and signed him yesterday to a three-year, $7.5 million contract.

title: Winter Dreams
description: "It must be wonderful to be in New York now, with the snow falling and children sledding in Central Park," a young Australian said last month to a visitor from America. "Yes, it is," the visitor replied. Who was she to shatter his illusions?

title: Paris Business Forms Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Zealand Is Odd but Solid Challenger
description: When New Zealand's America's Cup team practices for racing here, the syndicate's boats aren't hard to find. It's as if the yachts have gone sailing in a giant ocean eddy that has sucked in every other boat for miles.

title: Decision Time on Abortion
description: Today the Supreme Court is expected to announce whether it will consider the future of Roe v. Wade, the landmark 1973 decision that recognized women's fundamental constitutional right to choose whether to bear a child.

title: Cornhusker Is Charged
description: A University of Nebraska football player was charged yesterday in Lincoln in the beating of a 23-year-old woman and was sent to a state mental hospital for an examination to determine his competency to stand trial.

title: Can a Symbol of Fiscal Aplomb Ever Retire?
description: In 1975, Felix G. Rohatyn was recruited from the lofty confines of investment banking to help rescue the city from its own excesses. Mr. Rohatyn quickly emerged as a household name.

title: Nets Find a Coach to Turn It Around: His Name Is Fitch
description: Wouldn't it be wild if Bill Fitch wound up as the National Basketball Association's Coach of the Year?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: BRIEFS
description: Common Stock * Synopsys Inc. of Mountain View, Calif., has filed for two million shares of common to be sold through Morgan Stanley at a price between $13 and $15 a share. The company, which will use proceeds for working capital and other general purposes, develops computer software. Ratings * Chevy Chase Savings Bank received a downgrade on $128 million in subordinated debt to CC from CCC+ from Standard & Poor's, reflecting asset-quality problems in the Washington-area residential real estate market. The rating service did, however, cite the bank's profitable consumer-lending business and strong retail deposits. * Union Pacific won an AA+ rating for $83 million in equipment trust certificates from Standard & Poor's.

title: Dover Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bills Fans Overheat Buffalo (in January)
description: Cathy Jo Woloszyn spent a lonely 1991 Super Bowl on Manhattan's Upper East Side, desperately looking for a bar populated with Buffalo Bills fans. Instead, the Buffalo native recalled, she found swarms of New York Giants fans, who cheered their team to victory over the Bills.

title: Legg Mason Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Separating Margarita From Foster Parents Was Grave Injustice
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; Looking Inward and Finding Emptiness
description: In a theatrical space as intimate as the Manhattan Theater Club Stage 2, you can tell when a play has gripped its audience, for no one seems to breathe, let alone shift in his seat. The phenomenon can be observed first-hand these nights at "Sight Unseen," a smart and sad new comedy by Donald Margulies that has all sorts of unpleasant things to say about the 1980's art scene, the loss of love and the price of assimilation, both ethnic and intellectual, in an America where authenticity often has little to do with an artist's -- or anyone else's -- rise to the top.

title: Aggrieved British Car Owners Toast Notable Man of Action
description: Ever since John Thompson tried to dump the parking worker into Torquay harbor, people won't let him pay for his own beer.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Concord Camera Corp., Avenel, N.J., agreed with its senior lender, Midlantic National Bank, Newark, N.J., to restructure a $2.5 million partial repayment of its existing credit line. * Corning Inc., Corning, N.Y., a chemicals company, completed the sale of a less than 10 percent equity interest in its Corning Japan K.K. unit, a maker of flat glass substrates used in liquid crystal display screens, to Japanese investors. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Evelyn Openhym, 89, University Benefactor
description: Evelyn Tennyson Openhym, a book collector and benefactor of Alfred University in western New York, died on Jan. 13 at her home in Wellsville, N.Y. She was 89 years old.

title: Review/Dance; Stories Told in Movement and Talk
description: Irene Hultman is one of the best dancers around. Her way of moving is a miraculous mix of simplicity and juiciness, of robustness and delicacy. There is a blunt good humor to the way she presents herself and her resilient body to her audience, her round elf's face brimming with teasing, impudent cheer. But there is also a miracle flow to her dancing, and a gift for deft and telling inflection as subtle as any music. There was a good deal of Trisha Brown's slippery, continuous motion to what she danced on Saturday night at St. Mark's Danspace, unsurprisingly, since Ms. Hultman performed with Ms. Brown for five years. But Ms. Hultman, who is Swedish, has made Ms. Brown's style her own.

title: Free Care for the Poor and Pregnant Comes on Wheels
description: It has been just over a year since a large white van began lumbering into some of the poorest sections of this city, offering free medical care to pregnant women who seldom see a doctor except on television and who see far more of their babies die than other American women.

title: Sifco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Southern Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Southern said that 1991 included a gain of $ 114 million, or 36 cents a share, from the first installment in the settlement of a contract dispute with Gulf States Utilities.The company also said that 1991 earnings were hurt by a charge of $ 33 million taken in December to cover early retirement costs from a work force reduction at Georgia Power. They were also reduced by $ 25 million from the operations of Southern Electric International.The company said that 1990's net income was reduced by an after-tax writeoff of $ 218 million after the Georgia Supreme Court refused to review a decision by the State Public Service Commission disallowing a portion of the company's investment in plant Vogtle.

title: Bowater Inc. (X) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After premium and related costs of $ 9,046,000 incurred to retire outstanding debentures.Results do not include Great Northern Paper Inc., which was acquired at the end of 1991.The net income in the year 1990 results used in the calculation of earnings per share has been reduced by the dividend requirement of the LIBOR preferred stock.

title: Reading Lips, and Votes, in Trenton
description: Gov. Jim Florio's new support of citizen lawmaking through initiative and referendum puts enormous pressure on the Republican majority to enact the legislation they have sworn to support for more than a decade.

title: Accounts
description: * Tire America, Wheeling, W.Va., a tire retailer, to Barkley & Evergreen Advertising Inc., Shawnee Mission, Kan., for its advertising and marketing account, which was formerly in-house. Billings were not disclosed. * Marigold Foods to Martin/Williams, both in Minneapolis, for the national introduction of its Kemps Frozen Yogurt line. Martin/Williams has handled advertising for the product on a regional basis. Billings have not been determined.

title: 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week; Debate Is Mere Tuneup On Democrats' Journey
description: Everybody had an angle in Sunday night's debate among the Democratic Presidential candidates. Stirring political theater it certainly was not, but it gave some clues about what each of the five will be trying to do in the weeks ahead.

title: Shadow of the Russian Bear Is Lifted From Finland
description: Russia and Finland signed a treaty today agreeing to treat each other as equals and effectively nullifying the era of Finlandization, when Moscow maintained the right to dictate Helsinki's foreign and defense policies.

title: AID TO EX-SOVIETS IS BEING HINDERED
description: Two months after Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan announced a $165 million program to send free American food to what was then the Soviet Union, no food has been delivered and only one contract, worth $15 million, has been awarded.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section on Jan. 12 about the television producers Joshua Brand and John Falsey misstated Mr. Brand's educational background. His undergraduate degree is from City College in New York, where he majored in English literature. He received a master's degree in English literature from Columbia University and at one point sought a teaching job at LaGuardia Community College in New York.

title: Some Gifts to the Neediest Are in the Spirit of Protest
description: Most letters attached to contributions to the The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund recount personal experiences or insights that prompted the impulse to give. But a few contributors are moved by larger forces, making donations in celebration of great political events or in protest of government policies.

title: Net Up 9.9% At Raytheon
description: The Raytheon Company today reported a 9.9 percent increase in quarterly earnings, saying its diversity helped shield the company from a weak economy and military cuts.

title: Review/Rock; Sound and Style of the 60's
description: An MTV-era musician whose values vastly predate the video age, Chris Whitley is a welcome anachronism. Tonight at Maxwell's here, this New York-based singer and guitarist gave the kind of performance that might have seemed less unusual 20 or 25 years ago. Wearing a scant white tank top that defied the winter cold, switching back and forth between an array of gorgeous antique guitars, Mr. Whitley played a set that had much less to do with showmanship than with music itself.

title: A Graphics Program That Isn't Child's Play
description: DELTA Drawing Today is deceptively simple on the surface, a graphics program for children from preschool through third grade. With it, a teacher or parent can help a child learn or discover simple and essential concepts, like right and left; fundamental shapes, like squares, rectangles, triangles and circles, as well as the rudiments of reading and writing and even the logic of programming. And it's fun.

title: Critic's Notebook; Robert Shaw Magic: It's Based on Sweat
description: Sometimes a musical project proves so interesting and valuable that it survives its original purpose. In November 1990, Carnegie Hall sponsored its first Professional Training Workshop as part of its centennial celebration. Robert Shaw, the pre-eminent American choral conductor, was invited to lead the program, and more than 200 choral conductors, singers and music administrators came from all over the United States for five days of intensive work on Brahms's German Requiem, and a performance with the Orchestra of St. Luke's.

title: Ambition for Frankfurt
description: Germany is applying for the future European Central Bank to be based in Frankfurt, Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today. "Frankfurt lends itself for that like no other place," he said today at the New Year's reception of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange. European Community leaders agreed in December to establish a single currency for at least some community members by Jan. 1, 1999. The treaty also calls for the establishment of the European Monetary Institute and the European Central Bank.

title: Treasury Prices Up a Bit Abroad
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved a bit higher in overseas trading yesterday.

title: The Protest That Won't Go Away
description: A group called the National Summit on Racism in Sports and the Media will be using the Super Bowl to try and focus attention on attempts to eliminate American Indian mascots and symbols from sports.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the public's attitude toward homeless people described it incorrectly, as did a headline in some copies. While polls show that the public perceives widespread apathy toward the homeless, there are no firm numbers showing an increase in that attitude.

title: Why Eastern Europe Is Going Nowhere
description: The outcome of the fight between free-market democracy and authoritarianism in Eastern Europe is still in doubt. In place of Communism, democratically elected authoritarian regimes, aggressive nationalism and quasi-feudalism have emerged in some countries, and former Communist hard-liners, some converted to religious nationalism, are inciting populist extremism.

title: Irradiated Food Coming, But Not Without Protest
description: After years of scientific debate and commercial hesitation, the first food irradiation plant in the nation now stands ready for service and could begin shipping specially treated fruit as early as next week.

title: China and Belarus Set Up Ties
description: China and Belarus have established diplomatic relations after the first visit to Beijing by a leader from the Commonwealth of Independent States, , the official Chinese newspaper reported today. China Daily said that Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Tian Zengpei and Belarus Foreign Minister P. Kravchenko also agreed late Monday on a pact to promote trade and economic ties. China now has diplomatic relations with eight of the 15 former Soviet republics: Russia, Belarus, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, Turkmenistan and Tajikistan.

title: Paris Showcase of Ukrainian Performing Arts
description: In his film "Meeting Venus," the Hungarian director Istvan Szabo used a Paris production of Wagner's "Tannhauser" as a metaphor for the quarreling cacophony of the new Europe. "Ukraine in Paris," a five-month showcase of the performing arts from that newly independent country, which began here on Friday night, seems a kind of real-life echo of Mr. Szabo's film, exposing the mixture of privation and pride, confusion and purpose that defines the Ukrainian intelligentsia in these unsure times.

title: Prosecutors Ask Removal Of Another Gotti Lawyer
description: On the eve of jury selection, the judge presiding over John Gotti's racketeering case in Brooklyn is considering a prosecution request to knock another defense lawyer out of the trial of the reputed Mafia leader and a defense countermove to disqualify a prosecutor.

title: Cypress Semiconductor reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
North Sea Oil Output
description: Total offshore crude oil output from the North Sea in January may exceed the previous record high of 4.272 million barrels a day achieved in September 1991, according to analysts at County NatWest Woodmac Ltd.

title: Corning Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-After an extraordinary credit from tax benefit of loss carryforwards of $ 5.6 million, or 3 cents a share.c-After extraordinary credits of $ 2.3 million, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 2.9 million, or 2 cents a share, in the year, both from tax benefits of loss carryforwards.The share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split effective Jan. 13, 1992.The company said that during its latest fourth quarter it recognized non-operating gains from consolidated operations of $ 8.5 million, or $ 8.3 million after-tax, which included a gain of $ 5.3 million, pre- and after-tax, on the sale of a less than 10 percent interest in Corning Japan K.K.. Corning also recognized a $ 8.2 million reduction in equity earnings to reflect its share of a charge recorded by Dow Corning Corp. for costs anticipated as a result of the suspension of its breast-implant business.In 1991, Corning recognized net non-operating gains equaling to $ 14.6 million after tax, from consolidated operations, and the $ 8.2 million reduction in equity earnings reflecting Dow Corning's charge.In 1990, Corning recognized non-operating gains totaling $ 69.2 million, or $ 29.2 million after-tax, on the sales of certain investments, including a gain on the sale of substantially all the company's investment in Iwaki Glass Co. totaling $ 51.1 million, or $ 19.4 million after-tax.

title: Blockbuster Entertainment Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Systemwide revenue for the latest periods totaled $ 433,242,000 in the quarter and $ 1,520,141,000 in the year, compared with $ 318,097,000 and $ 1,133,150,000 for same year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Lebanese Says Israel Widens Its Army Zone
description: A prominent Shiite Muslim leader charged today that Israel had expanded the area it calls its security zone in southern Lebanon by adding a town to the zone.

title: Observer; Six Mind Benders
description: Now that we have been told everything we always wanted to know about sex but were afraid to ask, could somebody please tell us the answers to some other questions we've been afraid to ask because the answers are probably so obvious that asking the questions would make us look stupid?

title: Corrections
description: A book review yesterday about "Eyeball to Eyeball: The Inside Story of the Cuban Missile Crisis" omitted the reviewer's byline in some copies. The review was by Christopher Lehmann-Haupt.

title: Steinbrenner Helped to Pay for Lawsuit
description: Prohibited by agreement from suing the baseball commissioner himself, George Steinbrenner financially backed Leonard Kleinman's lawsuit against Fay Vincent by establishing a $250,000 escrow account for Kleinman's legal fees. But Steinbrenner subsequently terminated the account, although not his financial support, because the lawyers threatened to sue him after he disputed their bills and refused to pay them.

title: Prague Has to Drive Fast in Economic Mud
description: To the Editor:

title: Introducing the Most Powerful Group in Washington
description: Mark Rypien stepped to the line of scrimmage, called for a timeout and went to the sideline for a brainstorming session with Coach Joe Gibbs.

title: Rochester Telephone Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 3,757,000, or 12 cents a share, from gain on sale of assets.

title: The Children's Hour
description: In truth, it was not an hour but two, during which five would-be Presidents debated and polished their personas Sunday night on C-SPAN. Under Cokie Roberts's courteous prodding, three of them -- Kerrey, Tsongas and Harkin -- were sharper than on a previous outing with Tom Brokaw. Two of them -- Brown and Clinton -- gave warmth to previously sketchy impressions. But for all five Democrats, it was the children's hour.

title: In Move to Spur Economy, Bush Is Urged to Order 90-Day Ban on New Federal Rules
description: President Bush's senior advisers have recommended that he stop all Government agencies from issuing new rules for three months as part of a broad campaign to revive the economy by reducing the burden of Federal regulation, White House officials said today.

title: Iomega Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
O'Sullivan Back for Mile
description: MARCUS O'SULLIVAN, a 30-year-old Irishman, has won indoor track's most celebrated race, the Wanamaker Mile, four times in the last six years. Yesterday, Snickers Millrose Games officials announced that O'Sullivan would head the field for this year's Wanamaker Mile on Feb. 7 in Madison Square Garden.

title: Patterns
description: Just Ask for Josie

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about a Holocaust survivor who was active in organizations that helped other survivors misspelled his name. He was Milton Butnick.

title: Miller Building Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Prague Has to Drive Fast in Economic Mud; Lustration Is Necessary
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Daniel S. Tomlinson Jr. has been named the chairman and chief executive of the Sawyer Ferguson Walker Co., New York, succeeding Roy G. Blackfield, who has retired. Mr. Tomlinson had been president of the company, the nation's largest independent newspaper advertising sales representative firm.

title: The Tiananmen in East Timor
description: What President Bush has called "the tragedy in East Timor" is finally eliciting more than ritual sympathy. The former Portuguese colony was forcibly seized by Indonesia in 1975, an act comparable to Iraq's devouring Kuwait. This was largely ignored until last Nov. 12, when Indonesian troops killed 50 Timorese at a wreath-laying ceremony for a slain youth, an act reminiscent of China's 1989 massacre of pro-democracy students in Tiananmen Square.

title: Parcells in 'What Contract? Part 2'
description: A rose may be a rose, but is a contract a contract if one of the parties is Bill Parcells? During his recent, botched flirtations with a return to coaching, Parcells was said to have three years left on his NBC contract to return as the analyst on "The N.F.L. Live" or step up to No. 1 game analyst.

title: Versa Technologies Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Treasury Market Study Said to Seek New Policy
description: The Government report done in the wake of the Salomon Brothers trading scandal will propose that the Treasury Department sell extra bonds or notes when the department determines that there is a squeeze in the government securities market, according to people who have seen part of the study.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: "This is going to be a real bonanza for growers and consumers alike." -- SAM WHITNEY, president of a company that is about to begin irradiating fresh fruit in Florida. [ A1:1. ]

title: INSIDE
description: French Airbus Crashes; 9 of 96 Survive

title: Steelers Hire Cowher
description: BILL COWHER, 34, will become the National Football League's second-youngest coach and the 15th in Pittsburgh Steelers' history when he is introduced today at a news conference. Cowher, the Kansas City Chiefs' defensive coordinator for three years, accepted the job Sunday.

title: CIT Group Holdings Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 1,325,000 after-tax extraordinary charge on the early extinguishment of debt.c-Included an after-tax extraordinary charge of $ 5,937,000 on the early extinguishment of debt and a $ 20,350,000 income tax benefit for the adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 96, ''Accounting for Income Taxes''.

title: Review/Fashion; Real Clothes Designed for Real Women
description: Adolfo opened his show at the Plaza last week with festive short black lace dresses embroidered with white braid and embedded with rhinestones. Then he tied a long taffeta skirt in pastel colors or black over each dress. It was clear that in his spring and summer show, he would be concerned with hemlines.

title: Prague Has to Drive Fast in Economic Mud; Ban Proven Agents
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
Czechs by Millions Invest $35 in Big State Sale
description: Czechoslovakia has been swept up in a frenzy that can perhaps be described as gold fever. Government offices across the country have been swamped as the deadline approaches for signing up for a virtual giveaway of a large chunk of the state-owned economy.

title: Henry Stommel, 71, Theoretician Influential in Ocean Current Study
description: Henry M. Stommel, a leading theoretician on ocean currents, died Friday at the age of 71 at the New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. His wife, Elizabeth Stommel, said he died of a heart attack after surgery for a liver tumor. He lived in Woods Hole, Mass.

title: Dentist's Assistant Is Killed in Robbery
description: A dentist's sister, who was also his dental assistant, was shot and killed yesterday by two men who burst into her brother's office on the Lower East Side and tried to rob it, the police said.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Music Today Merkin Concert Hall

title: Programming & Systems Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Black Box: Out of Sight but Crucial
description: THE hard disk drive may be the most important component of a personal computer system, yet because it is usually out of sight it is often out of mind. The little black (or silver) box seems pretty simple, but it holds nearly everything dear to the computer owner: all the important business reports and love letters and phone numbers and customer invoices and other data that make the world go round.

title: Kennametal Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax loss of $ 900,000 relating to the divestiture of Precision Hard Materials S.A. with related income tax benefits of $ 1.2 million.

title: 700 Burmese Muslims Said to Die in Detention
description: At least 700 Burmese Muslims died of suffocation in crowded warehouses in their homeland where they were detained by soldiers, a newspaper reported today.

title: Jury Selection Process Is Not a Waste of Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief's Woes Are a Trial for Detroit, Too
description: While this hard-luck city descended into the quicksand of crack and violence, Federal prosecutors say, the police Chief was stealing from a fund set up to fight drugs, funneling the money to phony corporations and setting up his mistress in an apartment in the suburbs.

title: Review/Television; Sun Myung Moon Changes Robes
description: If you've been wondering what the Rev. Sun Myung Moon is up to these days, tonight's edition of "Frontline" offers a suspicion or two. "The Resurrection of Reverend Moon," at 9 on Channels 13 and 49, produces evidence that since serving 13 months in Federal prison for conspiracy and false tax returns in the early 1980's, the head of the Unification Church has become a behind-the-scenes political force.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Ilya Itin Pianist Alice Tully Hall

title: F.D.A. Tells Company To Release Implant Data
description: The Food and Drug Administration has told the Dow Corning Corporation to make public some 90 documents on silicone gel breast implants, but company officials said today the company may not comply.

title: Watch Out for the Widening Ozone Hole
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Aide Rejects View From Japan on Illiteracy
description: A Department of Education official today denied the assertion of a senior Japanese politician that nearly a third of American workers cauld not read.

title: Zilog Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 2,404,000, or 16 cents a share, from the sale of the VHDL product line in the quarter and year; the year also included restructuring charges of $ 10,528,000.c-Net loss

title: Caracas Journal; Venezuela's Two-Faced Boom: Riches and Riots
description: High in a tinted glass office tower that rises from this city's valley floor, Venezuela's Planning Minister recently listed the statistical mileposts of his country's economic resurgence: a treasury brimming with foreign reserves, inflation at its lowest level in five years and an economy growing at the fastest rate in the Americas, 9.2 percent in 1991.

title: Becton, Dickinson & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dun Software's Unix Alliance
description: Dun & Bradstreet Software, a leading supplier of application software for mainframe computers, is set to announce a joint development agreement today with both the Hewlett-Packard Company and the Data General Corporation.

title: Nationsbank Posts Loss After Merger
description: Nationsbank, the new name for the country's fourth-largest banking company, created by the year-end merger of the NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., and the C&S/Sovran Corporation of Atlanta, said it had a $243.8 million loss in the fourth quarter and a profit of $201.8 million, or 76 cents a share, for all of 1991. The loss, the bank said, was a result of its previously announced plans to lump various merger expenses into the final quarter of last year.

title: Antley Is Suspended
description: Aqueduct stewards suspended jockey CHRIS ANTLEY yesterday through Jan. 27 for careless riding aboard Choice Prize in Sunday's fourth race. Choice Prize, who ran first, was disqualified and placed sixth. (AP)

title: CHRONICLE
description: The ROBERT MAXWELL story goes on, and another chapter will unfold on Feb. 14, when Sotheby's sells the contents of the press lord's London home at auction.

title: AICorp Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflected tax benefits of net operating loss carryforwards of $ 464,000, or 5 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 1,019,000, or 12 cents a share, in the 9 months.c-Net incomeThe latest quarter's income before item included non-operating loss of $ 300,000 relating to the company's 9 percent interest in its affiliate, AICorp Europe. The results reflected the December 1991 acquisition of the remaining 91 percent of AICorp Europe for 800,000 shares of the company's common stock.

title: Giant Meteorite Blast Gouged a 30-Mile Trail
description: THE explosion of a giant meteorite as it grazed Earth less than 10,000 years ago gouged a 30-mile chain of elongated depressions in the Argentine pampas, scientists say.

title: Shift at the Top At Campbell Offices
description: Campbell-Mithun-Esty has announced significant changes at its offices in Houston and Southfield, Mich.

title: By Design; All-Weather Fabrics
description: This winter's weather has proved that "miracle" fibers are magic. Last week, when one day was a balmy 62 degrees and the next was in the teens, a microfiber coat was the ideal solution.

title: Northeast Gas Pipeline Ready But Critics Still Doubt Need
description: After a decade of planning and construction that has provoked fierce opposition from environmentalists, homeowners and oil executives, a major natural gas pipeline from Canada is to begin operation here this month, providing the largest single new source of energy to the New York region since the 1950's.

title: VMS Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Home Health-Care Employees Reach Pact on Wage Increases
description: In a labor agreement likely to set the pace for publicly financed home health-care services in New York City, the union representing about 20,000 nurses' aides announced a tentative agreement yesterday with 28 private agencies on a 5 percent wage increase, from $5.90 to $6.20 an hour.

title: Scuds Are Gone, but the Israelis' Fears Linger
description: The problem with her new apartment on Jabotinsky Street, Ofra Ovadia says, is not so much that it is spare as that it overlooks a broad and noisy avenue.

title: Article 158092 -- No Title
description: Textron Inc. said today that it would buy the Cessna Aircraft Company from the General Dynamics Corporation for $600 million.

title: Woodhead Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
In Chill of the Night, the Homeless Change Habits
description: His bare feet jammed into high-top sneakers, James Murray stumbled out of his shack and into the 14-degree weather late Sunday night. He would not have gone out at all, but charity workers were serving pea soup at his shantytown, an encampment on the Lower East Side built around a 20-foot canvas tepee.

title: Two Wounded in Shooting
description: Two people were shot last night on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, the police said. Robert Vargas, 22 years old, of 59 West 87th Street, was shot in the right leg by one of several men he was arguing with at Columbus Avenue and West 88th Street. A 15-year-old youth, who was not involved in the dispute, was hit in the right shoulder. Both victims were reported in stable condition.

title: Williams Discharged
description: TED WILLIAMS, 73 years old, has been released in good condition from Shands Hospital in Gainesville, Fla., a week after undergoing neck surgery aimed at preventing future strokes. The surgery was related to a mild stroke the Hall of Fame outfielder suffered in November. The stroke is said to have left no permanent damage. (AP)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Texaco's Profit Down 16.5% in 4th Quarter
description: Texaco Inc., the first big oil company to announce fourth-quarter earnings, said yesterday that net income fell 16.5 percent because of lower prices for crude oil and natural gas and weak demand for gasoline, chemicals and other refined products.

title: Critic's Notebook; Making a Movie Take the Rap For the Violence That It Attracts
description: The type of individual who would brandish a semi-automatic weapon at a movie theater where Ernest Dickerson's "Juice" is playing (as someone did in Commack, L.I., the other evening) is the best argument for the reasonableness of what Mr. Dickerson has to say. His film addresses the peer pressures at work on a group of Harlem high school students, one of whom eventually develops a taste for murderous mayhem and viciously attacks his friends.

title: Economy Likely To Revive Soon, Congress Is Told
description: At the start of a Presidential election year in which the economy is a central issue, the Congressional Budget Office predicted today that the economy would begin a weak recovery by the middle of 1992 and warned lawmakers not to endanger the recovery by resorting to radical changes in economic policy before the November election.

title: Review/Music; Bilson and Bylsma In a Lighthearted Mood
description: Before beginning to play a sonata with the cellist Anner Bylsma at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday night, Malcolm Bilson spoke briefly about his instrument, a fortepiano built by Alois Graff in Vienna in 1825. It had six pedals. Three were unremarkable: one raised the dampers, allowing sustained tones; one resembled the una corda pedal on the modern piano, allowing a softer sound and different timbre; another inserted a piece of cloth between hammer and strings, muting the impact. The others, Mr. Bilson explained, were "noisemakers." He pressed one: it sounded as if a drum were being struck with a great stick, accompanied by the jangling of strings.

title: Ready for Prime Time in Moscow
description: For the first time, tens of millions of Russian television viewers will spend a week watching "Murphy Brown," "Life Goes On" and an array of American prime-time programs and movies dubbed in their language.

title: Grand Forks Journal; History's About-Face Felt on Plains
description: For the last quarter of a century, this quiet farming and university town high in the Dakota plains stood sentry at the front gates of the cold war.

title: Who Should Liberate Iraq?
description: Should America encourage Iraqis to overthrow Saddam Hussein? Yes. Should it advertise that any new Iraqi government could expect an early easing of the international economic embargo and generous reconstruction aid? Yes again. But should the U.S. commit itself in advance to give armed support to any group that challenges the Iraqi dictator, as Saudi Arabia now urges? Under present circumstances, the best answer is no.

title: America-Bashing, Not All False
description: First came President Bush's clumsy, embarrassing effort to bully the Japanese into buying unwanted autos and parts. Now Yoshio Sakurauchi, Speaker of Japan's lower house, gratuitously and falsely berates U.S. workers as lazy and illiterate. As apologetic Japanese officials realize, these views could not have spewed out at a worse time, with overtones of trade war already audible in the Presidential campaign. 'Sneak Attack!' yesterday's New York Post shouted, voicing the offense many Americans are apt to feel.

title: An Ad in Defense Of the Ad Deduction
description: Proposals to cut the Federal deficit by lowering the deductions on advertising as a business expense have not made much progress over the last five years. But as President Bush's State of the Union address nears, the American Advertising Federation is not taking any chances.

title: Pilgrim's Pride reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net income

title: Packing Cable With Programs
description: Cable television companies and their equipment suppliers are on the verge of installing new technology that will pack many more channels into cable networks, creating a potential programming revolution with implications for broadcasters, telephone companies and the consumer electronics industry.

title: Executive Stock Rule Considered
description: The group that makes most of the nation's accounting rules is about to revive a long-dormant project that would require companies to deduct from their income the cost of granting stock options to their top executives.

title: 3 Students Are Stabbed In Brooklyn
description: Three students were stabbed yesterday outside their Brooklyn high school, leaving one of them in critical condition, the police said.

title: McEachern to Penguins
description: SHAWN McEACHERN, the leading scorer on Team USA, signed a multiyear contract yesterday with the Pittsburgh Penguins and will join them after the Winter Olympics next month. McEachern, a left wing who played at Boston University for three seasons, was the Penguins' sixth-round draft choice in 1987. He was a first-team all-American and the leading scorer on Boston University's team last season with 34 goals and 48 assists. (AP)

title: Paine Webber Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a $ 95,452,000 charge for restructuring and merchant banking reserves taken in the year-earlier fourth quarter.The share earnings reflected the 3-for-2 stock split in the form of a 50 percent stock dividend distributed Dec. 10.Revenue represented net revenues.

title: Saatchi Touch For a Cigarette
description: The Lorillard Inc. division of the Loews Corporation is introducing a brand, aimed at women, in the growing lower-priced segment of the cigarette market.

title: Massachusetts Acts on Workers' Comp Fraud
description: To the Editor:

title: After Gun Law, Fatal Shooting Sets Off Debate
description: Until New Year's Day, C. Nicholas Conchas's life was one of the small successes of the Hispanic community that makes up much of this city's East Side.

title: Bausch & Lomb reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 64,100,000 from restructuring of pharmaceutical operations, restructuring of some other product lines and reserve for possible liabilities related to patent litigation.c-After an extraordinary charge of $ 125,000,000 which included $ 61.3 million on a change in accounting principle and $ 64.1 million on the restructuring of pharmaceutical operations, restructuring of some other product lines and reserve for possible liabilities related to patent litigation.d-Net income

title: Market Place; Bulls vs. Bears: The Super Bowl
description: CAN the Super Bowl forecast the stock market? Can the stock market forecast the Super Bowl?

title: SPENDING CUTBACKS OUTLINED BY CUOMO TO BALANCE BUDGET
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, rebuffed in bids to forge a long-term solution to New York State's chronic fiscal ills, presented the Legislature today with a more traditional approach that would pare spending on nearly all local-aid and state programs in his 1992-93 state budget.

title: Text of U.N. Resolution Asking Libya's Help
description: Following is the text of Security Council Resolution 731, approved unanimously today, which calls on Libya to turn over two of its citizens to face trial in one airliner bombing and to cooperate in the investigation of another:

title: Broad Outline Described For a Milken Settlement
description: Michael R. Milken and other former officials of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. are negotiating a broad outline of a settlement of civil claims under which they would pay government and other claimants between $800 million and $900 million, people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Dow Chemical To Report a Loss
description: The Dow Chemical Company said it would report a loss for the fourth quarter of 1991 because of a $370 million pretax charge against earnings, related to plant closings. Enrique C. Falla, Dow's chief financial officer, said earnings from continuing operations in the quarter would exceed 35 cents a share, as many analysts have predicted. The results will be announced Jan. 30.

title: Goalie Moves for Bruins
description: The Boston Bruins made two moves in two days to strengthen their stability in goal.

title: Chrysler Raises Prices by 0.6%
description: The Chrysler Corporation increased car and truck prices by six-tenths of 1 percent today and announced that the price of its much-awaited Grand Cherokee utility vehicle would start at more than $20,000.

title: United Technologies To Cut 13,900 Jobs; Blow to Connecticut
description: The United Technologies Corporation, the largest private employer in Connecticut, announced a series of plant closings and cutbacks yesterday that would eliminate 13,900 jobs, including 6,412 in the state, by 1995. The cuts represent 7 percent of the 193,000 workers employed worldwide by the sprawling company, whose businesses include Pratt & Whitney jet engines and Otis elevators.

title: 'Falsettos' Headed For Broadway, Not the Beaumont
description: "March of the Falsettos" and "Falsettoland" are coming to Broadway this spring, but it won't be the production everyone was expecting.

title: The Pop Life
description: Heavy Metal Founder

title: BMC Software Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Recession Prompts First-Time Gifts as Neediest Cases Lead '91 Pace
description: "I have not donated money to the Neediest Cases fund before," Deborah Dorfman of Princeton, N.J., wrote, "but the need seems so great this year."
