title: General Public Utilities reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 56.2 million on costs recognized to prepare Three Mile Island Unit 2 for long-term monitored storage as well as the recognition of accident-related decommissioning costs for Three Mile Island Unit 2.c-Net income

title: Review/Film; Spoofing the Horror Genre
description: Mike (Craig Peck), the main character in Rolfe Kanefsky's "There's Nothing Out There," which opens today at the Eighth Street Playhouse, has seen too many horror movies. He's seen so many that he can barely go on a weekend trip to a remote house in a lonely wooded setting without getting very, very nervous.

title: New York Announces Plans For Executive Life Bailout
description: Insurance regulators in New York announced a rescue plan yesterday for the Executive Life Insurance Company of New York that should pay 100 cents on the dollar to the insurer's 118,000 customers. But insurance professionals said the plan would make it impossible for customers to cash in their policies without incurring substantial penalties, known as surrender charges.

title: Watts Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Key Rates
Gesture of Fiscal Conciliation
description: In promoting his budget as a vehicle for a quick deal with State Senate Republicans, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo armed himself today with political ammunition to assail the Legislature if it fails again to pass a timely budget.

title: 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans; Bush Urges Head Start Increase, And Debate on Its Impact Follows
description: President Bush flew to Baltimore today to announce his proposal for a vast increase in Federal spending for Head Start, the program for preschool children from low-income families.

title: Old Is New in the Treatment of Hypertension
description: To the Editor:

title: Bankers Trust Names Three to Top Positions
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation yesterday named a president and two vice chairmen and announced the resignation of Ralph L. MacDonald, one of its top officers and corporate finance specialists over the last decade.

title: New on the Laser Menu: Potato Skins, Well Done
description: A research lab in Ohio is using sophisticated laser technology in the service of one of the most mundane culinary tasks: peeling potatoes.

title: F.T.C. Approves RWE Licensing
description: The Federal Trade Commission approved a plan by RWE Aktiengesellschaft of Germany to license its technology for high-purity alcohol-process alumina, a chemical used in refining, to Discovery Aluminas Inc. of Port Allen, La. RWE, a unit of RWE-DEA Aktiengesellschaft fur Mineralol und Chemie, agreed last November to license the technology to settle F.T.C. charges that its acquisition of the Vista Chemical Company of Houston would reduce competition in the United States alcohol-process alumina market.

title: Stein Starts Mayoral Bid With a Bash
description: New York City's 1993 mayoral campaign began haltingly 15 months ago when Andrew J. Stein and, a few months later, Rudolph W. Giuliani all but declared their candidacies -- then just as abruptly dismissed their candor as premature and retreated from the starting line.

title: In Russia, Long Lines for Plentiful Bread
description: Few bread stores anywhere are as well-equipped as the Australia Shop on Piatnitskaya Street in downtown Moscow. Automated equipment, a recent gift from Australia, mixes dough and bakes bread 18 hours a day, and as fresh loaves come out of the stainless-steel ovens, they are stacked in wire-mesh trays, waiting to be sold. But despite this abundance, anxious customers form a line half a block long outside the shop.

title: Eastex Energy Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Behind Deadly Rush at City College
description: It was a ghastly scene on the stairwell. People crying out, gasping for air and fainting, a fearful sense of being under water, arms pinned and fighting for life.

title: Attica Judge to Trim Vacation
description: The judge in the Attica trial yesterday bowed to the wishes of his judicial superior and agreed to cut short his Caribbean vacation to preside over jury deliberations in Buffalo.

title: Some Neighborhood Haunts Go Back 120 Years, Some Only 40
description: THEY are harbors of serenity in the feverish metropolis. You won't find them in the trend-tracking urban magazines, nor will their chefs be lionized in lists of up-and-coming stars. And the chances of spotting Warren Beatty or Michelle Pfeiffer chewing the fat at the bar are about equal to encountering Saddam Hussein on the IRT.

title: HIGH COURT TAKES PENNSYLVANIA CASE ON ABORTION RIGHT
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a Pennsylvania law that restricts access to abortion is constitutional, an action that virtually insures a ruling on the politically explosive abortion issue by early summer of this Presidential election year.

title: Our Man in Nirvana
description: In the first week of August 1974, when I was a speechwriter for President Richard Nixon, I walked into the office of the White House physician, next door to the White House. As I asked for some allergy medicine, I noticed a surgical-steel tray laden with filled syringes, their needles dripping. Next to them was a vial of a potent chlorpromazine tranquilizer.

title: Homestead Mortgage Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest share earnings reflects the conversion of 3,140,304 shares of series A preferred stock into 2,826,256 shares of common.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The National Arts Club will present its 93d annual Gold Medal of Honor tonight to CHRISTO, the Bulgarian- born artist, for his wrapping of the Pont Neuf in Paris in fabric and, later, several islands in Biscayne Bay in Florida.

title: Riley Says Things Will Get Better
description: Asked today if the Knicks had overachieved in winning 17 of their first 27 games, Pat Riley did not evade the question.

title: New Worry for Bush; Possibility of Supreme Court Decision On Abortion Poses Campaign Risk
description: The Supreme Court's action today on abortion activates an extraordinarily divisive issue in the 1992 Presidential election and becomes one more worrisome variable for President Bush's re-election campaign.

title: Eating Well
description: IS it panic time in the fish department? Sort of. Sales are off, say some owners, but not the way they have been with past scares about fish or seafood.

title: Fannie Mae Payment
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association said today that its former chairman, David Maxwell, had relinquished his right to a final retirement payment of $5.5 million.

title: Public & Private; The $64 Question
description: It's hard to imagine, looking over New Jersey's new welfare legislation, that the people who designed it sought information or help from those who will be most affected by it.

title: From Cruel to Cool, Singer Recalls Roots of Hate
description: THERE is a snapshot of the singer Garland Jeffreys that grabs you like a summer afternoon and won't let go. He is 4 or 5 years old and going to his first baseball game. Behind him is the late, great Ebbets Field. He wears a Dodgers uniform, high black shoes, a Jackie Robinson button.

title: Supreme Court in Trenton Considers Death Sentence
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court, which has upheld the death sentence given Robert O. Marshall for ordering his wife's murder, began deliberating today over whether carrying it out would be fair.

title: Massachusetts Acts on Workers' Comp Control; Employers Gain Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Scents of 60's Wafting Again (No, Not That One. Musk.)
description: FOR the last few years, the 1960's have been rediscovered, re-invented and regurgitated. Miniskirts and false eyelashes, LSD and the Grateful Dead have all enjoyed revisionist status. It seems the only unexplored territory of that overworked decade is its smells: musk oil, patchouli and sandalwood. And guess what? They too are back.

title: Northern Telecom Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Preferred share dividends in the latest periods were $ 3.8 million in the quarter and $ 18.4 million in the year, compared with $ 6.1 million and $ 24.2 million in same year-ago periods, respectively.

title: An Epidemic of Genital Warts Raises Concern but Not Alarm
description: ALTHOUGH 20 to 30 percent of sexually active Americans are infected with the virus that causes genital warts and though it is found in 85 percent or more of cancers of the cervix, doctors say the wart epidemic is cause for concern but not alarm.

title: Moscow Journal; Temple to Lenin Opens Its Doors to Freethinkers
description: The Institute for Marxism-Leninism, once the inner sanctum of scholarly privilege for Communist ideologues, has changed its slant along with its name. It is now called the Russian Center for the Study of the Documents of Modern History, a careful title with no ism or ax to grind.

title: Pacts for Outfielders
description: Outfielders DAVE MARTINEZ and BRADY ANDERSON, both of whom had filed for arbitration, reached agreement with their teams yesterday. Martinez signed with the Cincinnati Reds for $1.3 million and Anderson with the Baltimore Orioles for $345,000.

title: G.E. Net Up by 2% In Quarter
description: Helped by continued strength in financial services, the General Electric Company said yesterday that profits in the last three months of 1991 edged up 2 percent, to more than $1.26 billion. It also cited growth in businesses where products are ordered many months or even years in advance, like medical equipment, power systems and aircraft engines.

title: Theater in Review
description: Iron Lung La Mama E.T.C. 74A East Fourth Street Manhattan Through Sunday Written, directed and designed by John Jesurun; lighting, Jeff Nash; stage manager, Mathew Buckingham; technical director, Jim Coleman. Presented by La Mama E.T.C. and the Shatterhand Company. WITH: Oscar De La Fe Colon, Rebecca Moore, Larry Tighe, Michael Tighe and Sanghi Wagner.

title: U.S. Agents Say Libya Is Adding And Hiding Chemical Weapons
description: Libya is expanding its chemical weapons program, and is dispersing chemical stockpiles to avoid detection, United States intelligence officials say.

title: Compaq And Silicon Cancel Pact
description: Less than a year after forming a strategic alliance, Compaq Computer and Silicon Graphics have parted ways. The alliance was expected to speed Compaq's entry in the work stations market dominated by Sun Microsystems.

title: Embattled Italian Financier Vows to Regain MGM-Pathe
description: In a rare public appearance today, Giancarlo Parretti, the indebted Italian financier who briefly controlled the MGM-Pathe Communications Company last year, swore that he would battle to win the movie studio back.

title: Libya Unyielding Despite U.N. Demand
description: The Security Council voted unanimously today to demand that Libya turn over for trial the agents accused of blowing up two civilian passenger aircraft and killing 440 people, but Libya indicated no willingness to comply.

title: A Drama That Will Rival the Ring When Tyson Faces His Accuser
description: No fighter since the days of Muhammad Ali has been dissected and inspected quite the way Mike Tyson has. At age 25 he has been one of those public figures who fascinate the masses and command constant attention.

title: Accounts
description: * M&M/Mars division of Mars Inc., Hackettstown, N.J., to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, to advertise the new Milky Way II chocolate bar announced last week. A campaign from the agency, which also handles other M&M/Mars brands like Milky Way and Mars, will coincide with the candy's introduction into seven Western states in April.

title: Paine Webber Reports a $46.9 Million Profit
description: Paine Webber yesterday reported quarterly earnings of $46.9 million, lifting the securities firm's yearly profits to a record $150.7 million.

title: Books of The Times; A Personal Approach To Cold War History
description: The Cruel Peace Everyday Life in the Cold War By Fred Inglis 492 pages. Illustrated. Basic Books. $28.

title: Elderly Can Get Help With Their Utility Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: Optimism on Scott
description: St. John's officials were more optimistic yesterday that SHAWNELLE SCOTT, the injured sophomore forward, would be able to play Saturday afternoon against Syracuse. The team's trainer, RON LINFONTE, said that the strained tendon in Scott's right foot was responding to treatment and he listed Scott as a 50-50 possibility to play. The availability of Scott, who was injured with 1 minute 30 seconds to go in the first half of the 75-60 loss to Seton Hall on Monday, is even more important with ROBERT WERDANN, the senior center, out for at least two more weeks with a sprained muscle in his right calf.

title: Meredith Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflected a special reserve of $ 6 million, established in the prior year for a pending legal settlement related to a government contract for relocation services.c-Included an after-tax gain from the disposition of Sail magazine of $ 3,553,000, or 21 cents a share.d-After income from discontinued operations of $ 8,280,000, or 49 cents a share.e-After income from discontinued operations of $ 60,302,000, or $ 3.58 a share, reflecting primarily the September 1990 sale of the Meredith/ Burda printing operations and income tax credits from the disposition of subsidiary operations.

title: Space Shuttle Is Set For Blastoff Today On Science Mission
description: Preparations to launch the space shuttle Discovery and a menagerie of roundworms, fruit flies, yeast, bacteria, slime mold, frog eggs and astronauts went almost flawlessly today, leaving unusually cool weather the only major concern.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * The Apparel Group Ltd., New York, named Charles McConnell president of its B.D. Baggies division. * Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, announced three new appointments: Wesley M. Thompson president of its international consumer products businesses, George L. Fotiades president of its consumer products unit in Japan and Richard H. Malyan senior vice president-international business development.

title: Wisconsin District to Assign Pupils On Basis of Income to Disperse Poor
description: Amid much debate, the La Crosse school district next fall will become the first in the nation to use family income as the criterion for assigning elementary students to schools.

title: Capriati Succumbs to Pressure As Sabatini Steps to Semifinal
description: Jennifer Capriati, with tears welling in her eyes, struggled to explain a collapse that led to her ouster from the Australian Open today and instead found herself pouring out the frustrations of a 15-year-old rising star on the women's tennis circuit.

title: Saudis Say They'll Trim Oil Output
description: Yielding to increasing pressure from other OPEC members, Saudi Arabia said today that it would cut oil production by about 100,000 barrels a day.

title: Allies Differ Over Aid
description: A 47-nation conference for coordinating aid to the former Soviet Union opens today in Washington, with tensions between the United States and its allies bubbling just beneath the surface over how best to help Russia and the other republics, officials and experts involved say.

title: Vietnam Admits K.G.B. Interrogated American
description: The Government of Vietnam has confirmed that it allowed at least one American prisoner of war to be questioned by the K.G.B.

title: Bills Say Their Loss Could Be Colts' Gain
description: Win or lose on Sunday, the Buffalo Bills players feel certain that they will lose their offensive coordinator, Ted Marchibroda, after the Super Bowl game against Washington. Marchibroda is among the leading candidates to become the Indianapolis Colts' head coach.

title: Charges Against Hurdle
description: CLINT HURDLE, a former major league player and the manager of the Mets' top farm team at Tidewater, has been charged with stealing some Valentine's Day items worth $1.79 from a grocery store, the police in Williamsport, Pa., said. The 34-year-old Hurdle was arraigned on a charge of retail theft and released on $200 bail after his arrest Monday. He retired from the Mets in 1987 after a 12-year career that included stints with the St. Louis Cardinals, the Kansas City Royals and the Cincinnati Reds. (AP)

title: McKesson Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $ 7.3 million, or 19 cents a share, in the quarter and year, from discontinued operations.

title: Galileo Electro-Optics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossThe company said improved results are attributable to the effects of restructuring implemented in fiscal year 1991 which have resulted in a lower cost structure.

title: Harris Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Net lossc-Included an after-tax charge of $ 72.9 million in connection with the restructuring of the company's semiconductor sector.

title: Ameritech reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $ 73.6 million from the initial public offering of Telecom Corp of New Zealand shares. As reported, included in the fourth quarter was an after-tax restructuring charge of $ 141 million.The company said the latest quarter included the effect of one-time restructuring charges related to work force reductions, the writedowns of certain assets and intangibles as well as other non-recurring charges in unregulated businesses and the early retirement of debt. The charge reduced earnings for the quarter by about 53 cents a share.

title: Dow Loses 30.64 as Nasdaq Loses Track
description: Stock prices pulled back yesterday for the second day in a row, with investors apparently sounding a note of caution after a giddy ride in recent weeks. Also weighing on the market was a computer problem that prevented the main Nasdaq indexes from being calculated for most of the day.

title: Florio Signs An Overhaul Of Welfare
description: Gov. Jim Florio signed a legislative package today that mandates sweeping revisions in the welfare system, among other things making New Jersey the only state in the nation to deny additional payments to welfare mothers who have more children.

title: Jostens Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Citicorp and 2 Other Banks Post Losses as Loans Sour
description: The decline in the California real estate market has caught up with some of the state's largest banks, and yesterday Wells Fargo & Company and the Security Pacific Corporation announced large fourth-quarter losses as a result. And Citicorp, as expected, posted losses for the fourth quarter and the year.

title: Treasuries Move Up in Price Again
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher and interest rates fell again yesterday, as the recovery from the sharp selloff of the last two weeks continued.

title: Picturetel Deal Set With A.T. &T.
description: The Picturetel Corporation said that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had agreed to resell Picturetel's videoconferencing systems. Videoconferencing systems, using television cameras and monitors, allow employees of several companies to hold meetings from their offices, with the video signals transmitted over telephone lines.

title: Review/Television; About Canada, 5 Programs' Worth
description: Given the standard American attitude toward Canada, something between indifference and unconsciousness, it is an act of daring for "Firing Line" to devote five programs to the country. The first two offerings of "Canada on the Firing Line" -- one on the environment and one on the condition of women -- have already demonstrated their relevance to concerns south of the Canadian border. And tonight, at 10 on Channel 31, and Saturday at 10 A.M. on Channel 13, William F. Buckley Jr., conservative, takes on Bob Rae, the socialist Premier of Ontario, in an amiable debate.

title: Whites Defy Pretoria's 'White' Draft
description: The repeal last year of South Africa's bedrock laws enforcing apartheid has left the Government with a quandary bedeviling its armed forces.

title: U.S. IS CRITICIZED ON AID TO RUSSIA
description: The 47-nation conference on coordinating aid to the former Soviet Union opens at the State Department on Wednesday, with a host of tensions between the United States and its allies bubbling just beneath the surface over how best to help Russia and the other republics, officials and experts involved say.

title: Thiokol Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats; Clinton Moves on 2 Fronts To Widen Support in South
description: Long before the Southern primaries on March 10, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas is trying to sew up the support of the mostly white Democratic establishments in those states and also garner enough endorsements from black officials to shore up his standing with minority and liberal voters.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The switchboard at the offices of the National Abortion Rights Action League was deluged with calls yesterday from supporters of abortion rights who wanted reservations for the organzation's fund-raising dinner, to be held tonight in Washington.

title: Soviet Myths Die Hard: Bolsheviks Didn't Overthrow the Czar; Stalin's Leninism
description: To the Editor:

title: 2d Suspect Arrested In Teacher Shooting
description: A man wanted in connection with the shooting of New York City schoolteacher left critically wounded when her car was caught in the midst of a gun battle in the Bronx was arrested by the San Diego police on Jan. 18 and brought back to New York City last night, a New York City police spokesman said.

title: Quote of the Day
description: "Let's get everything out that is sealed anywhere." -- REPRESENTATIVE LOUIS STOKES, calling for the release of documents relating to President John F. Kennedy's assassination. [ A14:4. ]

title: Saatchi Advertising Tightens Command
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, New York, is tightening its chain of command, almost six months after an elaborate restructuring left some doubts as to who was in charge.

title: Bridge
description: If one conducted a survey of bridge teachers around the world and asked them to estimate how many people have taken their lessons, a safe prediction is that the estimate by Bill Root of Boca Raton, Fla., would be far greater than any other, perhaps double the next number. He is well into his fourth decade of teaching large groups, often 100 students or more, although he has abandoned his native New York and now confines himself to teaching in Florida.

title: A Man Who Wants Respect For Lintas New York's Work
description: WHAT agency created "The Magic of Macy's" campaign? If enough people in the advertising community can guess correctly, then F. Stone Roberts will have less work to do in his new post as president of Lintas New York.

title: Pittsburgh Mayor Seeks New Image: From Grandmother to Tough Leader
description: Mayor Sophie Masloff was in her elegantly appointed office talking to a reporter when her chief of staff stepped up to her desk and interrupted. "Sophie," he said, "I popped a button off my jacket and I was looking for you to sew it on for me."

title: Teacher Going on Trial Again in Love-Triangle Murder
description: The love-triangle murder trial that turned the image of the quiet, colorless suburbs on its ear with tales of infidelity, conspiracy, romantic obsession and the shadowy world of private detectives is about to start all over again.

title: United Technologies Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After restructuring charges of $ 1,275,500,000 and a $ 256 million pre-tax charge to increase environmental reserves in the quarter and year.c-Net income

title: Exabyte Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
No Barcelona Hotel Crush
description: After months of talk about a severe housing shortage for the 1992 Summer Olympics, it now appears there could be a housing surplus as organizers here have canceled 400 first-class hotel reservations, many of which were set aside for use by corporate sponsors.

title: Theater in Review
description: Tom Scallen's Ice Capades Madison Square Garden Seventh Avenue and 33th Street Manhattan Through Sunday Produced and directed by Willy Bietak and Mr. Scallen; choreography by Sarah Kawahara; production design, Robert W. Rang; Firebird costumes, Pete Menefee; other costumes, Jef Billings; lighting, John McLain; musical direction and arrangements, Euromusica Design Group. Presented by L'eggs Sheer Energy Panty Hose. WITH: Yelena and Vladimir Bogolyubov, Rick Boudreau, Angelo D'Agostino, Dave and Joey, Tom Dickson, Angelique Gandy-Doud, Brad Doud, the Foy Flying Ballet, Kitty Kelly, Catarina Lindgren, Kristan Lowery, Chip Rossbach and Steve Wheeler.

title: Art Gallery At Yale Gets
description: The Yale University Art Gallery has received $10 million from Teresa Heinz in memory of her husband, Senator John Heinz 3d of Pennsylvania. It is the largest gift in the gallery's 160-year history.

title: Borden Chemicals & Plastics Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Real Estate; Girl Scouts Come to Aid Of Developer
description: BEATEN UP and scarred, in the words of its own consultant, the Hammerson Property Investment and Development Corporation was on the verge of quitting New York City when it was rescued by the Girl Scouts.

title: Jews and Saudis Hold First Talks in Saudi Arabia
description: Leaders of an American Jewish group held talks yesterday with the Foreign Minister of Saudi Arabia in Riyadh in what was apparently the first such meeting ever on Saudi soil.

title: Clarcor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss of $ 448,000 for the quarter and income of $ 297,000, or 3 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations.c-After a loss of $ 29,000 for the quarter and income of $ 1,200,000, or 12 cents a share, which included a 4-cent-a-share loss from sale of assets, for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: CHRONICLE
description: You can go home again if you are a Supreme Court justice. THURGOOD MARSHALL, the 83-year-old former Associate Justice, returned yesterday to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan, where he had served in the 1960's. Along with Judge JON O. NEWMAN and Judge AMALYA L. KEARSE, Justice Marshall heard arguments in four cases. He is expected to sit on the court again tomorrow, when a case involving the Rev. AL SHARPTON is on the docket.

title: Fortis Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Improved Play of Blaylock Keeps Anderson on the Bench
description: When looking for reasons why Kenny Anderson, the team's No. 1 draft choice, is not getting more playing time with the Nets this season, those wondering point to Anderson's size, his age, his lack of National Basketball Association experience or some grudge between him and Coach Bill Fitch.

title: Lukens Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net income

title: What Free Market?
description: As delegates from 47 nations meet in Washington today to discuss ways to aid Russia and the other former republics of the Soviet Union, they may have overlooked a basic contradiction in Boris Yeltsin's "free-market plan," which will likely be the economic model for the other republics. The plan has very little to do with free markets.

title: No Time to Be Stingy With Russia
description: Western Foreign Ministers gathering today in Washington need to concentrate on one urgent task: arranging a substantial transfusion of aid to Russia and a beleaguered Boris Yeltsin.

title: Georgia Redistrict Plan Rejected; Black-White Battle Seen as Likely
description: The United States Justice Department today rejected as racially discriminatory a redistricting plan approved last year by the Georgia Legislature. The move raised the possibility of a battle between black and white legislators over how to draft a new plan.

title: Union Camp Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
1992 CAMPAIGN: Washington Memo; Senate Jousting Is a Lesson in 'Bipartisan' Debate
description: The 1992 election campaign arrived on Capitol Hill today, as senators called for bipartisan efforts to solve national problems and then split on party lines over education legislation.

title: Review/Rap; Big Biceps, Bare Chest, No Blushing
description: Marky Mark, leading an outfit called the Funky Bunch, kept his pants on at the Ritz on Friday night, but barely. A soft-core rapper and brother of Donnie Wahlberg of New Kids on the Block, Marky Mark has all the requisites for being a teen-age idol: a handsome face, bulging biceps and a shameless attitude. Bare-chested, wearing baggy boxer shorts over briefs, he strutted back and forth across the stage while the almost exclusively female teen-age audience threw flowers, stuffed animals and condoms at him. He was a rapping Atlas, a few steps shy of a Chippendales dancer. He was an R-rated New Kid.

title: Washington Energy Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Benjamin Gilbert, 84, Private Investor, Dies
description: Benjamin Davis Gilbert, a private investor who was involved in widely divergent enterprises, died suddenly on Jan. 15 at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 84 years old.

title: Personal Health
description: THE side effects of chemotherapy have become a fact of life for millions of Americans as cancer researchers continue to demonstrate the life-saving potential of an ever-growing list of cell-killing drugs.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Decline 0.7% on Big Board
description: Short-sale figures are reported monthly by each exchange and by the National Association of Securities Dealers and represent the "short interest" for that period.

title: Essef Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossThe company said its tax provision has been reduced by $ 109,000 related to utilization of net operating loss carryforward in accordance with Financial Accounting Standards Board No. 96, which the company said it adopted effective with the first quarter of fiscal 1992.

title: Here's a Way To Fight Japan
description: The Congress will soon be asked to cut taxes to combat the recession. Cuts for the middle class would be fair and might encourage more consumer spending. But the economy needs more than a quick fix -- an extra $300 in every middle class family's bank account. It needs a large-scale, aggressive, long-term Government-business partnership for growth.

title: Maxtor Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Included a net gain of $ 5.5 million primarily from the sale of a facility in Penang, Malaysia.c-Net lossd-Net income

title: INSIDE
description: Reversal for Japanese Pact

title: Tandy Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 10,619,000 from the cumulative effect on prior years of change in accounting for extended warranty and service contracts.

title: Richfood Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 4
Ruling Favors Taxes In Indian Properties
description: New York State won a victory in the Supreme Court today in its long-running effort to collect taxes on cigarettes and other goods sold on Indian reservations to non-Indian customers.

title: Food Notes
description: Super Bowl Tasting Menu

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Japan Tries Damage Control
description: The Government today raced to contain the damage in the United States after one of Japan's top politicians called American workers illiterate and lazy, saying the Government did not share his views and then contending that he had been misinterpreted.

title: Remember Red-Meat Orgies In the Cave? Your Taste Buds Do
description: Talk about nostalgia for old-fashioned food. While some people nurse memories of grandma's cooking, the anthropologist Lionel Tiger's fixation is caveman food -- Upper Paleolithic caveman food that is, from 10,000 or so years ago, the dawn of civilization. And like it or not, he says it's what we long for, too.

title: Prosecutors Describe Kremlin Coup Plot
description: The men who organized the unsuccessful hard-line coup in Moscow last August had counted on the prospect that Mikhail S. Gorbachev would eventually join their conspiracy to put the country back under authoritarian rule, Russian prosecutors said today.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE combination of chicken and rice has always seemed especially soothing to me. Perhaps it is something inherent in the textures and flavors of the two ingredients, or, more likely, it is my memory at work, recreating happy meals of my youth.

title: Schools Order Students to Dress for Safety's Sake
description: In many urban schools today, wearing a blue bandana, red stitching on a baseball cap, a Raiders' jacket or expensive athletic shoes can be enough to set off a fight and even a killing.

title: Book Notes
description: Endowing Free Speech

title: Georgia Gulf reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 17.1 million one-time restructuring charge taken in the second quarter.

title: Cardinal Distribution Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Riley Fined For Comments On Officiating
description: Knicks Coach Pat Riley has been fined $2,500 for criticizing the officiating after last Saturday night's game, the National Basketball Association announced yesterday.

title: David Distributing reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: Dinkins Bid to Put Gay Irish In Parade Spurned by Sponsor
description: An attempt by Mayor David N. Dinkins to assure a gay organization a place in the St. Patrick's Day Parade hit a major snag yesterday when the Irish order that he chose to direct the parade announced that it, too, planned to bar the gay group.

title: I.B.M. Introduces Low-End Work Station
description: I.B.M. introduced its least expensive work station and other new products yesterday in an effort to move more aggressively into the rapidly growing market for network computing systems for scientific and commercial users.

title: By Any Other Word, Tasker Is Special as Bills Look for an Edge
description: Steve Tasker sat in the stands of the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome this morning, unnoticed and undisturbed, balancing a newspaper crossword puzzle on his left knee.

title: Howard To Leave Michigan For Pros
description: Desmond Howard ran his first predictable reverse yesterday.

title: Stride Rite reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: The share net reflected 2-for-1 stock split paid Dec. 18.

title: Incentives for Research On Drugs Are Debated
description: A proposal to limit Federal incentives for companies to develop drugs for people with rare disorders touched off intense debate today among patients and drug companies at a Congressional hearing.

title: Stocks Rise in Japan
description: Stock prices surged in Tokyo today after four days of losses, with a rally heating up in the afternoon. The Nikkei index of 225 shares finished up 675.82 points, or 3.24 percent, to end the trading session at 21,534.12. The Nikkei lost 55.52 points on Tuesday.

title: New San Jose Coach
description: RON TURNER, the offensive coordinator at Stanford for the last three seasons, has gone to San Jose State as the school's new head football coach. The man he succeeded, TERRY SHEA, left San Jose to go to Stanford as an assistant to the new head coach, BILL WALSH.

title: Gotti, the Sequel, Begins With Roundup of the Usual Suspects
description: John Gotti arrived at Federal Court in Brooklyn from jail by van in a solemn five-car police motorcade yesterday. Invisible behind blackened windows, Mr. Gotti was driven into an underground parking lot from a side-street entrance to the courthouse -- a decidedly less dazzling performance than his last court appearance, when he danced to his waiting limousine after being acquitted of assault charges in Manhattan in 1990.

title: Orchestra Reaches Pact With Musicians
description: The New York Philharmonic and negotiators for its musicians reached a tentative agreement on Monday for a four-year contract. The agreement provides for salary increases, an extension of the orchestra's current health benefits at a reduced cost to the players and a new arrangement to give the players a voice in running the orchestra. It was presented to the musicians yesterday and they will vote on it today, spokesmen for both sides said.

title: 47th St. Photo Files for Bankruptcy
description: Embroiled in legal squabbles and unable to pay its creditors, 47th Street Photo Inc., whose stores epitomize the feisty, combative world of consumer electronics retailing, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday.

title: Cuba Announces Crackdown On Dissident Organizations
description: The Cuban Government put dissidents on notice today that they faced an all-out security and political crackdown. The warning came the day after the execution of a right-wing Cuban exile convicted of sabotage and terrorism.

title: Japanese Trade Surplus Surged Last Year
description: Japan's trade surplus has reversed course after a three-year decline, surging by 50 percent in 1991, the Government said today. The announcement is likely to fan increasing resentment in the United States and other nations upset because the surplus, they say, stems from Japan's adherence to unfair trade policies.

title: Woodhead Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Included a gain of $ 2,404,000, or 16 cents a share, from the sale of the VHDL product line in the quarter and year; the year also included restructuring charges of $ 10,528,000.c-Net loss

title: General Electric Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 1,799,000,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Review/Music; Melodies of Jerome Kern
description: As the production of new Broadway musicals slows to a trickle, increasingly the only way to enjoy the musical theater is by rummaging through its past. That is exactly what the 92d Street Y's Lyrics and Lyricists series has been doing ever since it exhausted the supply of eminent living songwriters willing to talk about their work. Since 1988, the series, which is written and directed by Maurice Levine, has devoted a season each to the careers of Irving Berlin, the Gershwins, Cole Porter and Richard Rodgers. This year, the series, which opened its 22d season on Sunday, is devoting all five of its programs to Jerome Kern.

title: Bank Fund, C.D. Yields Down Again
description: Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit dropped for the week that ended yesterday, but the pace of the decline slowed, according to figures released yesterday by The Bank Rate Monitor, a publication that follows bank rates. The explanation, however, does not give much solace to savers hoping for an end to the rate declines.

title: Women's Liberty, on the Line
description: "Has the Supreme Court overruled Roe v. Wade, holding that a woman's right to choose abortion is a fundamental right protected by the United States Constitution?" Abortion rights advocates put that question to the Court in seeking review of Pennsylvania's anti-abortion laws. In granting review yesterday, the justices rephrased the question in less dramatic terms, but the liberty of women is on the line just the same.

title: A Stick-to-the-Ribs Meal With a Light Exotic Touch
description: IN cold weather, I always long for something hearty and earthy -- substantial stick-to-the-ribs fare. This menu satisfies this yearning, with three robust dishes seasoned in an Oriental way.

title: Will Women Runners Overtake Men?
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Time to Come Home, Now: Those Little Local Spots Are Back
description: ROLL out the red-checked tablecloths. The little place around the corner is back. The neighborhood restaurant that isn't too fancy, isn't too expensive and isn't too far away.

title: 47th St. Photo in Bankruptcy
description: Embroiled in legal squabbles, the chain, which epitomizes the feisty world of electronics retailing, filed for bankruptcy protection. Page D1.

title: Dr. Joseph G. Allen Is Dead at 79; Professor and an Expert on Blood
description: Dr. Joseph Garrott Allen, an expert on blood who was a professor emeritus and a former chairman of the department of surgery at Stanford University's School of Medicine, died on Jan. 10 at his home on the Stanford campus. He was 79 years old.

title: A MOVE TO UNSEAL THE KENNEDY FILES
description: The chairman of a Congressional committee that investigated the assassination of President John F. Kennedy said today that he would ask Congress to order the release of all Government documents on the slaying. He said such a move would serve to relieve public suspicions that the Government had been involved in a conspiracy to kill the President.

title: Ashland Coal Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Stronger Family Tie Seen in Suicide
description: ONE out of every four people who attempt suicide has a family member who also tried to commit suicide, a study sponsored by the National Institute of Mental Health has found. The number is higher than previous estimates.

title: Deluxe Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NBC Surrenders Videotapes of Drug Investigation
description: In an unusual case that is seen as a test of how closely journalists may work with Government agents without forfeiting First Amendment protections, NBC has turned over 12 videotapes of a Federal drug smuggling investigation to the Justice Department.

title: Economic Scene; The Economy Is In/Out of Woods
description: FORECASTING, the economic wits say, is difficult especially about the future. But these days you can't even put much faith in descriptions of the present.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-8 LIBYA SAID TO ADD CHEMICAL ARMS

title: Texaco Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains of $ 202 million in the quarter and $ 224 million, or 87 cents a share, in the year, both from tax refund and asset sales. The periods also included charges of $ 173 million, which were related to: reserves relating to on-going evaluation of environmental remediation programs and probable legal settlements; prior-year foreign income tax adjustments; reduction in the carrying value of certain assets, and on-going foreign pension costs.c-Included $ 85 million reserve for environmental remediation in the quarter and year.

title: In Letter, Khrushchev Tells Of Mockery Over Cuba Crisis
description: Among the most embarrassing aspects of the conclusion of the 1962 missile crisis for Nikita S. Khrushchev was the mockery it exposed him to from China and other Communist countries, according to a document made public today.

title: Champion International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of 16 cents a share related to several non-recurring items including sales of some of the company's west coast Timberlands.c-Included gains of $ 93 million related to sale of west coast Timberlands and total charges of $ 33 million relating to several other non-recurring items.

title: Alcan Aluminium Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net after-tax restructuring and other charges of $ 5 million in the quarter, and the year included net after-tax charges of $ 60 million.c-Net income and included after-tax non-operating gains of $ 114 million, or 51 cents a share, in the quarter, and the year included after-tax gains of $ 196 million, or 87 cents a share.

title: Shortage of Professors Is Envisioned
description: The nation could run short of researchers and college professors in the arts and sciences in the next several years unless graduate programs at American universities are strengthened by new financing and greater attention to students, according to a study on graduate education.

title: Wang Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $ 1.6 million, or 1 cent a share, from discontinued operations, in the quarter and 6 months.c-After income from discontinued operations of $ 200,000 in the quarter and $ 600,000 in the 6 months.The loss from continuing operations in the year-ago 6 months' results included non-recurring pre-tax gain of $ 11.8 million from the sale of real estate.

title: The Mentors Behind Monk
description: Crowds of reporters gathered around Art Monk. The Washington Redskins' 35-year-old receiver spoke deliberately, not expansively, explaining that he didn't like the limelight, preferred to keep his thoughts to himself, but would go along with the hoopla of the Super Bowl.

title: Los Angeles on Verge Of Ending Japanese Pact
description: Smoldering American resentment against Japanese economic competition has flared into a political firestorm in California, and Los Angeles County officials appeared today to be on the verge of canceling a $122 million contract they awarded just a month ago to a Japanese company to build rail cars for a new mass transit line here.

title: Yanks Sign Stanley
description: The Yankees signed MIKE STANLEY, a free-agent catcher, to a minor league contract yesterday, and he will attend spring training as a nonroster player. The 28-year-old Stanley hit .249 with 3 homers and 25 runs batted in last season for the Texas Rangers, but was sent outright to the minors after the season.

title: Assembly Plant For Ford Exports
description: The Ford Motor Company said it planned to export to Europe 6,000 Explorer utility vehicles assembled at its plant here, beginning next year. The No. 2 United States auto maker -- which said it had total export orders for a record 51,500 vehicles in 1991 -- said Explorers intended for sale in Europe would be modified to meet European Community standards at a plant in which it was investing more than $500,000.

title: Thieves Rob Police Officers In Queens
description: Two New York City police officers, one on duty, were robbed at gunpoint early yesterday morning in separate incidents by what the police believe was the same band of thieves in Queens.

title: Mattel in Venture
description: Mattell Inc. said it would jointly develop a line of activity toys with Nickelodeon, a cable television station that produces children's television programming. Nickelodeon is part of Viacom International Inc.

title: Correction
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday misidentified the parent company of the Sherwood Securities Corporation. It is the Sherwood Group Inc., a public holding company.

title: I.R.S. Drops LYON Case
description: The Internal Revenue Service has abandoned its effort to block companies from using the tax advantages of a popular financing tool, zero-coupon convertible bonds, which companies have used to raise more than $11.5 billion in capital.

title: Sports of The Times; Old Vikings Remember The 4 Losses
description: THERE is a school of thought that the Giants won their two Super Bowls and the Jets won their only Super Bowl out of a cynical insight into the unforgiving and unforgetting mind of New York football fans, who boo the first time their team goes third-and-long. The Giants and the Jets did not dare lose.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FIGURE SKATING Russians Take Lead Yelena Bechke and Denis Petrov edged the defending champions, Natasha Mishkutienok and Artur Dmitriev, in the original program to take the lead in the pairs competition yesterday as the European figure skating championships began at Lausanne, Switzerland. The couples, both from St. Petersburg, Russia, performed for the Commonwealth of Independent States, a name decided on after last-minute talks with international skating authorities. Bechke and Petrov, runners-up last year, earned marks in the 5.6-5.8 range. The maximum is 6.0. The original program is worth one-third of the total mark. The free skating takes place today and is worth the remainder.

title: Review/Television; Some Loners Struggle With Love and Survival
description: The small circle of truly significant American film makers, among them Martin Scorsese and Woody Allen, may be gearing up to admit some new members. One candidate is Gus Van Zant ("Drugstore Cowboy"). title: John Everett, CUNY Chancellor And New School Head, Dies at 73

title: Files to Be Opened, From Lenin to Gorbachev
description: The first batch of millions of secret documents culled from the Communist Party's archives in Moscow are to be released this fall, beginning with the files collected by the party on major leaders of the Bolshevik Revolution, a British publishing company said today.

title: With Some Misgivings, East Europe Snaps Up German Money
description: Germany's entrepreneurs and industrial giants are moving into Eastern Europe, spreading prosperity but stirring unease in a region that well remembers the horrors of World War II.

title: Miscellany

Eric Allovche, who founded Marketing Art in 1985, will become a creative director at Bozell France. * Greenstone Roberts Advertising Florida, a unit of Greenstone Roberts Advertising Inc., Melville, L.I., has acquired the assets of Sandhaus International, Orlando, an agency that specializes in travel advertising. Sandhaus will be consolidated with Greenstone's Orlando office, which will be renamed Greenstone Roberts/ Sandhaus.

Robert Frankel is Midwest ad manager and is based in Chicago; Marc Gordon is West Coast ad manager and is based in Los Angeles.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media; Sound Bites Become Smaller Mouthfuls
description: Tom Brokaw of NBC News recently bemoaned "the cancer of the sound bite" afflicting Presidential campaigning, a description that accurately summarized the prevailing contempt toward those snippets of speech on the evening news. But it may not have been the best metaphor. Cancer tumors are invidious because they keep growing. Sound bites seem only to shrink.

description: JIM LEYLAND just might get his wish. "I'd like to manage in Pittsburgh for my whole career," the 47-year-old manager said yesterday after agreeing on a new five-year contract offer from the Pirates. "Sometimes the grass looks greener on the other side of the fence, but, to me, it looks pretty green in Pittsburgh."

title: David Bernstein, 98, Civic Leader on L.I.

title: G.E. Cutting Jobs
description: A General Electric Company military systems plant here will eliminate 500 jobs this year because of cuts in spending by the Pentagon. The factory, which employed about 5,000 people in the mid-1980's, now has a work force of 2,900. A spokesman said the layoffs could begin late this quarter.

title: Mets Trade Carreon to Tigers for Gibson
description: The Mets, completing an exhaustive and often exhilarating off-season reconstruction project, yesterday did their final bit of reassembling when they obtained left-handed reliever Paul Gibson from the Detroit Tigers for outfielder Mark Carreon and reliever Tony Castillo.

They are secured by 69 diesel electric locomotives.

He's No Gary Hart

The nation is wondering if it will learn that once again a smart, young charismatic Democratic candidate has disillusioned his followers by hiding extramarital affairs.

title: Sports of The Times; Racial Slurs Not Confined To Buffalo
description: Here is some very disturbing news for Bruce Smith: There are racists in Denver, where he tried to sign a contract three years ago. There are racists in L.A. There are racists in Chicago. Hard as this is to believe, there are even two or three racists around New York City.

title: Accounts
description: * Tree Top Inc., Selah, Wash., a processor and marketer of fruit products like juices and apple sauce, to Evans/ Kraft, Seattle, from McCann-Erickson, Seattle, for advertising, marketing and product publicity. The agency, which was assigned the account following a review, estimated billings at $2 million to $3 million. * Ciatti's Restaurants, a chain of Italian restaurants in Minnesota and Wisconsin, to Chuck Ruhr Advertising, Minneapolis, for its $1 million advertising account. The account had previously been at K & H Advertising, Minneapolis.

title: Husker Enters the Draft
description: Tight end JOHN MITCHELL has decided to shed Nebraska red for what he hopes will be National Football League green. Motivated by a desire to help his family -- especially his grandparents in Mississippi -- the 6-foot-3-inch, 250-pound sophomore said he would enter the N.F.L. draft. Last month, Mitchell said he would stay with the Cornhuskers for the 1992 season. A third-team all-American, Mitchell had a team-leading 31 catches for 534 yards and 5 touchdowns. . . . MAZIO ROYSTER, who became only the third Southern Cal sophomore to surpass the 1,000-yard mark in rushing when he gained 1,168 yards in 1990, announced he would skip his final year of eligibility to enter the N.F.L. draft. (AP)

title: John Remme, Performer, 56
description: John Remme, an actor, singer and cabaret performer, died on Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 56 years old.

title: Ingersoll-Rand Net Up
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company said today that its fourth-quarter net income rose to $54.7 million, or $1.06 a share, from $45.7 million, or 88 cents, a year ago. Sales at the maker of industrial equipment fell 3.4 percent, to $933.9 million from $967 million. For 1991, Ingersoll-Rand said its earnings fell 18.7 percent, to $150.6 million, or $2.91 a share, from $185.3 million, or $3.55, in 1990. Sales fell slightly, to $3.59 billion from $3.74 billion. Ingersoll-Rand's shares closed today at $58.625, up 87.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: New Campaigns
description: * A 15-second television commercial for the pain killer Nuprin features Jim Kelly, quarterback of the Super Bowl bound Buffalo Bills, with Joe Montana, the injured San Francisco 49ers quarterback. In the spot, created by J. Walter Thompson, New York, Mr. Kelly says, "Next year, Joe, you and me." Mr. Montana's response: "I'll send you tickets." A newspaper advertisement with a Super Bowl theme, featuring Mr. Kelly, will also run. Both athletes have appeared in previous Nuprin spots.

title: Los Angeles to Distribute Condoms in High Schools
description: The Board of Education here voted on Tuesday night to make condoms available at all public high schools to combat the spread of AIDS, making this the fourth big city school system in the country to adopt such a policy. The board rejected a proposal to become the first district in the nation to make condoms available to junior high school students.

title: Lukens Posts a Loss
description: Lukens Inc. on Tuesday reported an $8.55 million loss in the fourth quarter because of a 15-week strike at its main steel plant and weak seasonal demand for some of its products. In the comparable period last year, the company earned $9.26 million, or $1.06 a share. Sales fell 16.5 percent, to $132.09 million, from $158.27 million in the fourth quarter of 1990. About 1,300 workers at the Lukens steel plant in Coatesville returned to work last week after a strike that started Oct. 1. The company announced layoffs of more than 300 workers last week.

THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans; President and G.O.P. Take Aim At Abortion on Roe Anniversary
description: Preparing for a campaign in which abortion could become a powerful issue, President Bush today delivered a speech that showed no sign of flexibility in his position, and the Republican Party named a strong anti-abortion advocate as chairman of its platform committee.

description: Albert V. Casey, chief executive of the Resolution Trust Corporation, told Congress today that more time would be needed than Congress has allowed for the savings and loan rescue, and he asked the lawmakers to extend the deadline by which the agency must spend or forfeit the $25 billion approved by Congress last fall.

CHRONICLE
description: Could it be that the son of James Bond is a coward? Certainly not, a jury in London ruled on Monday, awarding JASON CONNERY, son of SEAN CONNERY and the actress DIANE CILENTO, $:35,000 (about $63,000) in a libel suit he had brought against The Sun, a London tabloid, for branding him a coward.

description: There were no per share earnings that were meaningful as the company did not complete conversion to stock form of ownership until Dec. 19, 1990.

Home Video
description: It's not every day that adults storm video stores to buy films with dancing mushrooms and Mickey Mouse. In November when Disney released the animated classic "Fantasia" on tape for the first time, strange things began to happen. "It wasn't the kids coming up with the parents saying 'I want that, Mommy or Daddy,' says Ron Castell, the senior vice president of Blockbuster, the country's largest video chain. "It was the parents who came in looking for it specifically."

title: Cray in Pact To Use Chip Made by Sun
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. and Cray Research Inc. said today that Cray would develop a new line of computers in the $1 million to $3 million range based on Sun's Sparc microprocessor technology. The companies also said they would share hardware and software technology to allow Sun computers and Cray supercomputers to work together more easily.

title: Supreme Court Limits Political Asylum Claims
description: The Supreme Court today narrowed the grounds on which people fleeing service in foreign armies may qualify for political asylum in the United States.

title: G.O.P. Leader to Back Benefits Extension
description: In the first test of the politics of the recession of the new Congressional session, Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader, is expected to testify Thursday in favor of another extension of unemployment insurance benefits.

title: In Connecticut, Mourning for an Old Friend: Manufacturing Jobs
description: It may be months before the pink slips go out to the 2,400 workers and managers at the yellow-brick Pratt & Whitney plant on Main Street here, where generations of workers have built aircraft engines.

title: Poor Children in Tough Times
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo concedes that his new New York State budget isn't good news but says it's not "a doomsday budget" either. Put more directly, it is a bad news budget, filled with sobering cuts in everything from Medicaid to the state work force. No sector is immune from pain, but in a trying time Mr. Cuomo at least makes an effort to maintain his commitment to children.

title: Mercantile Buying Maison Blanche
description: The Mercantile Stores Companyhas agreed to buy Maison Blanche Inc., a chain of 16 department stores in Louisiana and Florida, for an undisclosed amount. Details of the agreement still have to be worked out, said Hans Sternberg, chairman of the family-owned Maison Blanche.

title: Failure of Dinkins Plan Puts Parade in Disarray
description: The St. Patrick's Day Parade was thrown into a swirl of uncertainty yesterday after the collapse of Mayor David N. Dinkins's delicate maneuvering to assure that a gay organization would be allowed to march.

title: Bronx Teacher Shot in Crossfire Dies After 2 Weeks in Hospital
description: A junior high school teacher who was caught in crossfire at a Bronx intersection two weeks ago died of her wounds yesterday morning at Lincoln Hospital, and two suspects in the case were charged with second-degree murder.

title: Blyleven Signs Pact
description: Right-hander BERT BLYLEVEN, a winner of 279 games who hasn't pitched since 1990, agreed yesterday to a minor league contract with the California Angels.

title: Astronauts From 3 Countries Ride Shuttle Into Orbit
description: Seven astronauts from three countries sailed flawlessly into orbit today aboard the space shuttle Discovery and began a busy week of medical and scientific experiments.

title: Genus Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 2 million charge from write-off of inventory in Genus' east coast division.

title: Federal Paper Board reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Reflects previously announced non-operating after-tax charges of $ 7.3 million, relating to machinery write-offs, increased reserves for environmental matters and increased reserves in connection with previously sold or closed facilitites, and $ 2.5 million related to an increased in the effective tax rate for both the quarter and year.c-Included a non-cash after-tax charge of $ 11 million for the retirement of assets primarily associated with the Augusta, Ga., phase II expansion project for both the quarter and year.

title: At the Sundance Film Festival, Art and Commerce Square Off
description: High-stakes Hollywood games have been played here at the Sundance Film Festival since Steven Soderbergh's "Sex, Lies and Videotape" went straight from Park City to win the grand prize at the Cannes International Film Festival three years ago. Now art and commerce battle each other here as if they were good and evil twins in a B movie. The good twin wants a happy truce, maybe some money. The bad twin wants to sell its soul and perhaps still be an artist. For film makers and others with business to do, Sundance can be nerve-racking. But for a critic, this is partly avant-garde heaven, partly a voyeuristic peek into Hollywood deal-making.

title: Market Place; High-Flier May Be Airworthy Again
description: A LITTLE over a year ago, Sequent Computer Systems Inc. hit the invisible wall that seems to lie in wait for high-flying high-technology companies. Sequent, which is based in Beaverton, Ore., and makes superminicomputers, missed its earnings forecast for the fourth quarter of 1990 and spent the first three quarters of 1991 mired in red ink.

title: Rangers Start Road Trip in a Tie
description: The Rangers may have looked at their 4-4 tie tonight with the Calgary Flames as somewhat unsatisfying, but what they probably should have seen was this: It ended a five-year drought and a six-game losing at the Saddledome.

title: Dr. Eileen Halsey Pike, Professor Emeritus, 73
description: Dr. Eileen Halsey Pike, a professor emeritus of microbiology at New York Medical College in Valhalla, N.Y., died on Jan. 7 at the Ruth Taylor Institute, a nursing home in Mount Pleasant, N.Y. She was 73 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Israel-China Relations Nearly Official
description: Foreign Minister David Levy of Israel arrived in Beijing today for a four-day visit that is expected to lead to the establishment of diplomatic relations between China and Israel.

title: BPI Environmental Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Included special state workmen's compensation charge of $ 130,000.c-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $ 67,354, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter which reflects a $ 33,000 gain from forgiveness of interest and a $ 34,354 gain from early extinguishment of debt and $ 178,116, or 5 cents a share, for the 9 months which consisted of $ 132,000 in forgiveness of interest and $ 46,116 from early extinguishment of debt.The company said the increase in shares outstanding reflects a secondary offering completed in June 1991. Shares outstanding in the 1991 third quarter are actual shares outstanding, while shares outstanding in the 1991 nine months are weighted average shares outstanding.

title: First Savings Bank-S.C.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank said per share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend issued in February 1991.

title: Key Rates
Haley Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe company attributed its latest results to a decline in activities in the commercial and military sectors of the aerospace industry.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Bombardier Agrees to Buy De Havilland From Boeing
description: Bombardier Inc., the Montreal-based transportation conglomerate, said today that it would acquire the Boeing Company's ailing de Havilland division, a maker of commuter jets and Ontario's largest industrial employer. In the complex deal, valued at nearly $600 million, public authorities will provide nearly $500 million in subsidies.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about talks between American Jews and Saudi officials in Riyadh misstated the relationship between the Saudi Foreign Minister, Prince Saud, and King Fahd. The Prince is the King's nephew, not his brother.

title: George S. Odiorne Is Dead at 71; Developed Theory of Management
description: George S. Odiorne, developer of a management concept that became popular with businesses around the world, died on Sunday at Humana Hospital-Northside in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 71 years old and lived in St. Petersburg, where he retired three years ago.

title: Caning the Old and New
description: Yorkville Caning 31-04 60th Street (near Northern Boulevard), Woodside, Queens 11377; (718) 274-6464.

title: Knicks Are Pounded So Hard That They Fall Out of First
description: Once the Philadelphia 76ers got the Knicks down tonight, they never let them back up.

title: Irwin Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Dec. 30, 1991.

title: Review/Theater; Weird Epic Of History And Myth
description: People who know nothing about the Baltic nations and Central Europe in the Middle Ages should not try to find out anything before seeing "When Lithuania Ruled the World, Part 3" by Kestutis Nakas at the Courthouse Theater of the Anthology Film Archives. It is enough to know that the history of that region is saturated with myth, romance and continuing ferocious controversy. Besides, Mr. Nakas is a very clever subverter of all versions of history; mere knowledge won't keep anyone a step ahead of him.

title: Sumitomo Bank of Calif.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge
description: The past two decades have seen a revolution in the attitude of tournament players and organizers toward smoking. In earlier years a majority of bridge players smoked cigarettes, cigars or pipes, and the nonsmokers were a neglected minority. But the realization that smoking can be highly hazardous to the smoker and to a lesser extent a danger to those around him has changed that.

title: Dinkins Wants Former Chicago Bank Chief in Top Economic Post
description: Barry F. Sullivan, a longtime banker and the retired head of the First Chicago Corporation, is the Dinkins administration's top choice to be New York City's new Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, and is to tell Mayor David N. Dinkins as soon as today whether he wants the job, mayoral aides said yesterday.

title: Bandag Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Armor All Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Minnesota Power & Light reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax gain of $ 10.1 million from a favorable court decision, $ 6.7 million from the sale of water plant assets and $ 9.2 million from operations and the disposition of steam plant assets.

title: Review/Television; Feminism Invades London Police In New Three-Part 'Mystery' Tale
description: Public television's "Mystery" goes into a change-of-pace mode tonight with "Prime Suspect," a four-hour British production from Granada Television. Tonight's special two-hour installment is on Channels 13 and 49 at 9 and Channel 21 at 10. There are no mildly eccentric detectives snooping around quaint English villages in this one. The scene is contemporary London. The problem is a sadistic serial killer. The upshot is a thumpingly powerful police drama, on a par with the best of the commercial kind done by Americans, who excel in this particular genre.

title: Bowe Bout Is Off
description: RIDDICK BOWE's Feb. 1 fight against JOSE RIBALTA at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., is off. Bowe suffered an eye injury during a sparring session against KING IPITAN on Monday. "The right eye is bruised," said ROCK NEWMAN, Bowe's manager, "and there is a hairline fracture of a little bone that separates the sinus membrane from the eye socket. It absolutely does not jeopardize a fight against EVANDER HOLYFIELD." Bowe was said to be the next in line to fight Holyfield, the undisputed heavyweight champion, in a bout that is targeted for April 24 in Las Vegas. . . . The former champions GREG HAUGEN and RAY MANCINI, both 30 years old, will fight in Reno on April 3 in a scheduled 12-round outing, the fighters said yesterday.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Kenny Kirkland Fat Tuesday's 190 Third Avenue (at 17th Street) Manhattan Through Sunday

title: Citizens First Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossThe latest fourth quarter's results included gains on loan sales of $ 1,058,000 and profits on securities sales of $ 3,476,000, which approximately offset foreclosed real estate expense of $ 3,086,000 and legal fees and other credit and collection expenses of $ 995,000.

title: Tecumseh Products Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring after-tax provision of $ 19.2 million for environmental clean-up costs.

title: People
description: * Merle Schell has been named senior vice president and director of business development at Backer Spielvogel Bates, New York. She had previously been a group management supervisor at Grey Advertising, New York. * Mark Minkin has been named senior vice president of new-business development at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Advertising Inc., Boston. He had been director of worldwide advertising at Groupe Bull, Paris.

title: Next Computer's Revenues
description: Next Computer Inc., the company started by Steven P. Jobs, said today that its revenues for 1991 totaled $127.5 million, more than four times the $28 million recorded in 1990.

title: Eagle Precision Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Merger of New York's Transit and City Police Is Still a Bad Idea; Better Subsidy Deal
description: To the Editor:
