description: b-Net lossThe bank said the results for the latest year included a $ 5.4 million settlement cost of a nine-year-old lawsuit.

title: Robes Fit for an Emperor, to See and Buy
description: MEMBERS of the Chinese court dressed for ceremonial occasions in clothes dictated not by whimsy or fashion but by protocol. Pearls the size of marbles would top an emperor's hat. A ruby finial would perch on the hats of nobles and top officials. Clothes and accessories revealed status.

title: U.S. CONSIDERS MOVE TO CUT MULTIPLE-WARHEAD MISSILES, CORE OF THE NUCLEAR FORCE
description: In preparation for President Bush's State of the Union address next week, the White House and the Pentagon are considering plans to sharply reduce or eliminate long-range nuclear missiles with more than one warhead, Administration officials said today.

title: Britain Names Head Of Fair Trade Agency
description: The Office of Fair Trading, Britain's equivalent of the Federal Trade Commission, has appointed Sir Bryan Carsberg, the country's top telecommunications industry regulator, as its director general.

title: New Chief Is Named At Crum & Forster
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that Joseph W. Brown Jr. had been named president and chief executive of its Crum & Forster Inc. insurance subsidiary, replacing Robert J. Vairo, who is retiring at the age of 61. Mr. Vairo has been with the company for 17 years, the last three as chief executive.

title: Norwest Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossResults for 1990 have been restated to include United Banks of Colorado, which was acquired on April 19, 1991.Norwest originally reported 1990 fourth quarter net income of $ 70.7 million, or 70 cents a share.Norwest reported 1990 net income before restatement of $ 280.6 million, or $ 2.73 a share.The 1990 figures for credit loss provisions included $ 70 million in the fourth quarter and $ 138 million in the year of special provisions at United Banks of Colorado.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Douglas Aircraft Co., Long Beach, Calif., a division of McDonnell Douglas Corp., named Ronald L. O'Kelley vice president and chief financial officer. * GE Capital, Stamford, Conn., the financial services unit of General Electric Co., promoted Stephen Berger to executive vice president from president of its unit, Financial Guaranty Insurance Corp. He will be succeeded by Ann C. Stern.

title: Dole Food Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Included $ 5.1 million after-tax charge for reserve for a severe freeze in California.The company was formerly named Castle & Cooke Inc.

title: Editorial Notebook; Success, Then Anxiety, in Korea
description: South Korea's rush toward first world economic status has dazzled admiring outsiders. But it leaves many Koreans anxious that material advances may have come at a spiritual cost.

title: Corrections
description: Two articles and a picture caption yesterday about the racketeering trial of John Gotti rendered the name of his lawyer incorrectly. He is Albert J. Krieger.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: BRIGHTENING a room by applying wallpaper can be a gratifying antidote for the midwinter blues, even if you have never attempted such a project.

title: Consumers Need Rules, Not Stunts
description: President Bush is about to declare a three-month halt to new Federal regulations, according to White House sources who choose to remain anonymous. And well they might. This idea is the purest campaign prattle.

title: Ingersoll-Rand reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 7.1 million operating income benefit from a restructure of operations recorded in the first quarter of the year.

title: A Hint on Question No. 6: They Called Him Cal
description: TIME flies when you're having fun. This year is the 200th anniversary of the construction of the White House.

title: Conseco Deal Set; Stock Price Jumps
description: Shares of Conseco Inc. rose $5 today, after it said a partnership it controls would acquire the Bankers Life and Casualty Company and its Certified Life Insurance Company unit from a subsidiary of the ICH Corporation for $600 million.

title: Dun & Bradstreet reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included restructuring charge of $ 15 million for restructuring actions in Dun & Bradstreet Information Services, Nielsen Marketing Research and Donnelley Directory for both the quarter and year.

title: Budgetary Brinkmanship; Dire Threats to Cut Essential Services Are Often Just a Ploy
description: As tax receipts slip and budgets come under the knife in statehouses, city halls and private institutions, the region is witnessing the flowering of a kind of brinkmanship in which officials seek to protect their budgets by threatening to cut where the pain will be worst.

title: Aspect Telecommunications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomec-After an extraordinary reversal of tax-loss carryforwards of $ 23,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 1,856,000, or 19 cents a share, for the year.

title: Israel Said to Step Up Construction of Settlements
description: Three new studies issued recently, based on both official documents and unofficial estimates, confirm that over the last year Israel has built housing for Jewish settlers in the occupied territories on a scale that far outstrips previous construction programs.

title: How to Make a Quick Economic Turnaround
description: To the Editor:

title: Shelby Williams Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included restructuring charges of $ 5.3 million related to writedowns of certain manufacturing equipment in the textile distribution division and other facilities consolidation.c-Net income

title: 47th STREET JOURNAL; A Bankrupt but Still Popular Mecca
description: The leafleters were on the street corners, making that crisp snapping sound as they handed out their blue and yellow fliers as always. The elbow-to-elbow crowd at the counter was pointing and shooting point-and-shoot cameras and aiming extremely powerful binoculars at the farthest thing that they could find, which in this case was the cashier.

title: Ambush at Home Ends Life and Dreams of Immigrant
description: A 29-year-old Ukrainian immigrant, returning home after a business meeting Tuesday night, was shot and killed as he entered his Queens apartment lobby, the police said yesterday.

title: Fulton Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank said per share earnings for 1990 have been adjsuted to account for the 10 percent stock dividend paid to shareholders Dec. 2.

title: Conner Peripherals Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said latest fourth-quarter and year results include a gain of about $ 11 million for the sale of the Malaysian headstack operation to Read-Rite Corp. The gain was offset entirely by charges associated with actions taken during the 1991 quarter to adapt to changes in the marketplace, reduce its worldwide work force and reposition its manufacturing capacity.

title: Bills Stay The Course Despite Detour of Distractions
description: Buffalo, a team that has pointed to its focus as one of the main reasons that it returned to the Super Bowl this year, is beginning to show signs of distraction a few days from its showdown with Washington.

title: Revco Has New Plan To Block a Takeover
description: Revco D.S. today renewed its battle to remain independent, two weeks after the retail pharmacy chain appeared ready to accept a $1 billion takeover bid by the Jack Eckerd Corporation.

title: Hal Roach Recalls His First Century
description: The cinema celebrates its 100th birthday next year, but Hal Roach got there first. The man who paired Laurel with Hardy, put black glasses on Harold Lloyd and cranked out more than 200 Our Gang comedies began his second century last week, and Thursday night the Smithsonian Resident Associate Program will honor him at the National Museum of Natural History here.

title: John H. Harland reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included restructuring charge of $ 8.7 million after taxes covering discontinued lines of business and taxes on repatriation of earnings from the company's Puerto Rico operations for both the quarter and year, and the year also included a charge of $ 2,385,000 from a cumulative effect of the early adoption of the accounting standard for post-retirement benefits.

title: At Home Abroad; 'It Is Our Only Hope'
description: Dov Frohman is one of Israel's high-technology business stars, a vice president of the California microcomputer company Intel and general manager of Intel Israel. Last year he won the Israel Prize for engineering and technology. A jolly man with a large beard, he has had an international career.

title: Train Nonviolent Offenders at Former Bases; Treat Drug Convicts
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Prison Escapees Charged in Robberies
description: Two recaptured escapees from a Connecticut prison were charged today with robbing a jewerly store and a food store in Bergen County while they were fugitives and staying at a motel in Spring Valley, in Rockland County, N.Y.

title: TV Weekend; Mailer Plugs Himself Instead of His Book
description: You don't have to be as fascinated with Norman Mailer as Norman Mailer always has been or as David Frost seems to be to enjoy their conversation tonight. Mr. Mailer gives good talk. There is a high intelligence operating along with a sometimes original perspective; at his most engaging, he manages to be off the wall and on the mark at the same time. And his language has a way of rescuing his thoughts from drifting out into space.

title: Long-Term U.S. Issues Off Steeply
description: Treasury bond prices fell sharply and long-term interest rates rose further yesterday, as anxiety mounted among credit market participants about the coming battle in Washington over fiscal policy.

title: Ontario Is Placed On Credit Watch
description: The Province of Ontario and its state-owned utility, Ontario Hydro, have been placed on credit watch with negative implications by Standard & Poor's Inc. The long-term debt of the province and the power company now bears an AA+ rating.

title: Charge at Scott
description: The Scott Paper Company said it would cut another 3,800 employees and take a fourth-quarter charge of about $183 million, or $2.49 a share. The company, which has about 37,000 employees, said operating income would be about 35 cents a share for the fourth quarter and $1.54 a share for the fiscal year. Scott, which will announce 1991 earnings on Jan. 30, said the charge included the job cuts, asset restructuring, accounting changes and a $63 million gain from the sale of its 50 percent stake in a Japanese joint venture to its partner.

title: With 700 Supporters Rallying Round, Birmingham Mayor Goes to Prison
description: After leading hundreds of his supporters, some of them draped in chains, from the 16th Street Baptist Church to the Federal courthouse in a scene evocative of the civil rights marches of the 1960's, Mayor Richard Arrington Jr. surrendered to United States marshals today under a contempt of court citation.

title: I Tried to Buy a U.S. Car (Sigh)
description: Before entering the car market in the spring for the first time in 15 years, I resolved to buy American -- a four-door Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme. After a broker and I expressed contempt for Americans who buy imports, I specified the features: antilock brakes, front-wheel drive, console gear shift, lumbar seats. I asked about an airbag.

title: Centel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $ 918,000 and income of $ 49,402,000, or 58 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations and included a gain of $ 36,987,000 on sale of discontinued, an extraordinary charge from early retirement of notes of $ 334,000 for the quarter and $ 1,906,000 for the year.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 4,305,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 17,540,000, or 21 cents a share, for the year.The latest quarter and year's income from continuing operations of $ 25,678,000, or 30 cents a share, and $ 112,352,000, or $ 1.31 a share, respectively, included after-tax gain of $ 13.9 million, or 16 cents a share, from the sale of a 50 percent stake in its Omaha, Neb., cellular system, and the year also included net gain of $ 36,800,000 from exchange of telephone properties.

title: Amerada Hess reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe company said fourth quarter 1990 earnings included $ 87,300,000 from the settlement of business interruption insurance claims.

title: McCloud Fined $10,000
description: Indiana Pacer guard GEORGE McCLOUD has been fined $10,000 and suspended without pay for one game for punching Cleveland's JOHN BATTLE after the Cavaliers' 119-115 victory Wednesday in Cleveland. (AP)

title: Dow Down By 29.07, To 3,226.74
description: Blue-chip stocks fell sharply yesterday in heavy trading, almost erasing Wednesday's gains, while the broader market was mixed. Investors grew cautious, analysts said, as many earnings reports failed to justify the market's current lofty levels, and a weak bond market failed to offer support.

title: For Children
description: 'You Won't Believe This, But' Paper Bag Players Symphony Space Broadway and 95th Street Manhattan (212) 864-5400 Recommended ages: 4 to 9 Through March 8

title: Islanders Play 8 Minutes, but Leafs Play Whole Game
description: The Islanders solved a three-goal deficit with a midgame scoring spurt tonight, but because they did more aimless scrambling than intelligent skating, they found no solution to match Toronto's fourth goal and wound up with a 4-3 defeat at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Approval of Japanese Bid to Buy Mariners Unlikely
description: Last year two of the Yankees' limited partners were looking to sell their shares of the club and were approached by some Japanese businessmen.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media; Brown Finds Political Calendar Full of Radio Days
description: It was 10 past the hour on a recent Wednesday morning in Manhattan, and Edmund G. Brown Jr., former Governor of California and contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination, was already into his second radio talk show of the day.

title: Tisch Is Offering to Buy Macy's In Rescue From Huge Debt Load
description: In an apparent solution to R. H. Macy & Company's overwhelming financial troubles, Laurence A. Tisch, chairman and chief executive of Loews and CBS, has offered to buy the tottering retail company.

title: Arco Chemical Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 43 million from a cumulative effect change in accounting priniciple for income taxes. The company adopted SFAS No. 96 in the first quarter of 1990 and changed from the deferred method to the liability method of accounting for income taxes (45 cents a share effect).

title: Asteroids Implicated in a 2d Mass Extinction
description: New geological evidence in Italy suggests that impacts of extraterrestrial objects, like asteroids or comets, could have been the cause of a mass extinction of life like the one in which the dinosaurs died out.

title: Drifter Is Chief Suspect In Florida Church Fires
description: A drifter who has been jailed for two months on loitering and trespassing charges is now the leading suspect in at least 12 church fires in Gainesville and Tennessee last year, the authorities say.

title: Mets and O'Brien Agree
description: The Mets reached agreement yesterday with catcher CHARLIE O'BRIEN on a one-year contract. O'Brien, who had been seeking $450,000, avoided arbitration by settling for $370,000. The 30-year-old catcher, who is expected to be a veteran backup for the rookie TODD HUNDLEY this season, hit .185 in 69 games for the Mets in 1991 and has not hit above .200 since 1989. The Mets had filed an arbitration figure of $285,000, down from O'Brien's 1991 salary of $300,000.

title: Quaker Oats Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $ 30 million from discontinued operations in the quarter and 6 months.

title: Hannaford Bros Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: The company said its 1991 results included sales of Alexander's supermarket chain which Hannaford purchased in December 1990.

title: Boy Scouts Don't Qualify as Private Group
description: To the Editor:

title: Neediest Cases Surpasses '91 Total
description: Setting records is nothing new for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Fifty of its 80 annual appeals have raised more money than any before them.

title: At the Bar; Two Comedy Writers Aren't Laughing After Laurel and Hardy Routine Is a Flop in Court.
description: "Legal humor" may or may not be an oxymoron. But attempts at it can prove costly, as two comedy writers thrust into the generally unfunny world of litigation recently learned.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press last Friday about a Connecticut Supreme Court proceeding in the case of Murray Gold, who faces a fifth trial in the 1974 slayings of his former in-laws, misstated the position of James A. Killen, an Assistant State's Attorney. He argued that in ordering a new trial, a judge had erred in concluding that medication taken by Mr. Gold had interfered with his competence to assist in his defense.

title: Party Animals on Wall Street
description: Only at rare intervals on Wall Street do two and two equal four. The market is a volatile institution, and the mood of the crowd is changeable. In 1992, the mood is manic, and the sum of two and two is arguably closing in on six. Sooner or later, it will come crashing back to four.

title: Ashland Oil Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Collegiate Chorale
description: The Collegiate Chorale is to present a concert in honor of its 50th anniversary, tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. The chorus, under its director Robert Bass, will present Haydn's Te Deum, excerpts from Poulenc's Gloria and Mendelssohn's "Elijah," the Triumphal Scene from Verdi's "Aida," and the premiere of William Bolcom's "Dancers." Guest artists are the sopranos Martina Arroyo, Harolyn Blackwell and Leona Mitchell, the mezzo-soprano Mignon Dunn, the bass John Cheek and the New York City Gay Men's Chorus. Tickets are $15 to $55. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Foreign Affairs; Ousting Saddam or Trapping Bush
description: President Bush could be trapping himself into a lose-lose strategy of overthrowing Saddam Hussein in much the same way he cornered himself with the "jobs, jobs, jobs" strategy on his recent trip to Japan.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Music and Comedy

title: Deal in Britain By Blockbuster
description: The Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation said Cityvision P.L.C., Britain's largest videocassette rental operator, had accepted a $135 million buyout offer. Blockbuster, the largest video rental company in the United States, said it would use the acquisition to expand into Europe. Blockbuster owns 34 stores in Britain butnone in Continental Europe. City vision operates 875 stores in Britain.

title: A Corporate Nudge Onto U.S. Wheels
description: Corporate America is going to bat for Detroit. Companies like Monsanto Chemical in St. Louis and the Tosco Corporation in Stamford, Conn., and the Brown Paper Company of Greenwich, Conn., are all offering their employees $1,000 each toward buying an American car.

title: Review/Theater; A Physical Approach For an Israeli 'Hamlet'
description: To kill or not to kill, that is the question in Rina Yerushalmi's provocative adaptation of "Hamlet" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. In reassessing Shakespeare's text from her contemporary Israeli point of view, the director offers a Hamlet as a man of moral conviction. From her perspective, no killing is justified even if the motive is revenge for fratricide or, for that matter, crimes against the state. The Cameri Theater production, performed in Hebrew (retranslated into English over headsets) is running through Sunday as part of a festival entitled Israel: the Next Generation.

title: Karl New Sonics Coach
description: GEORGE KARL, the former coach of Cleveland (1984-86) and Golden State (1986-88), yesterday became coach of the Seattle SuperSonics. Karl quit Sunday as coach of Real Madrid, which was 17-7 in the Spanish League.

title: Review/Theater: The Visit; Revenge and Common Greed As the Root of Much Evil
description: NO one need go to the theater to learn that people will do anything for money. So why does "The Visit," Friedrich Durrenmatt's drama about a town that sells its soul for a fortune, still exert a chilling grip nearly 35 years after it shook up genteel Eisenhower-era audiences who had been drawn to it by the star power of Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne?

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chicago Mercantile Exchange re-elected its chairman, John F. Sandner. His term will be two years. * Great American Communications Co., Cincinnati, named John P. Zanotti president and chief operating officer of Great American Broadcasting and executive vice president of the parent company.

title: Centel Says It's Studying Possible Sale
description: The Centel Corporation, one of the country's largest non-Bell telephone companies and one of the few large cellular telephone properties not owned by a giant phone company, said yesterday that because of increasing industry consolidation, it might put itself on the auction block.

title: Factors That Drive Up Detroit's Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: On Any Given Sunday, Try Reading a Book
description: I don't care what the President said, there are at least 10 good reasons for not banning football, all of them on display this weekend.

title: Boston Edison Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 15,824,000, or 41 cents a share.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: 'Mad Forest,' Mad Theater

title: Amdahl Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-After an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 6,190,000, or 6 cents a share, for both the quarter and year.c-Net income

title: Officials Defend Policies To Protect Bond Market
description: Government officials who oversee the Treasury securities market asserted at a Senate committee hearing today that the changes they mandated on Wednesday would not disrupt trading and that they would move slowly before imposing the more contentious proposals.

title: Running Hard for Office At Great Neck's Library
description: While we all eagerly await the momentarily meaningful results in New Hampshire's presidential primaries, there's another election campaign under way. It too has a four-year term. It pits a younger opponent against an incumbent. The candidates call for change or continuity. They point with pride or derision. They acknowledge tough times, vowing fiscal responsibility. Both profess an inability to understand why the other is running. Both predict victory. Both want to be a trustee of the Great Neck Library.

title: Critics' Choices/Music; Sauve Enough to Slide
description: In "The Fabulous Bud E. Luv Show," an amusing tongue-in-cheek impersonation of the quintessential Las Vegas lounge singer, Robert Vickers, a mustachioed performer from San Francisco, portrays Bud Euripides Luvalopolis Jr., a fictional star who suggests a hybrid of Sonny Bono, Tony Orlando and Robert Goulet. Wearing a phony smile, Bud E. runs through a repertory that ranges from lounge classics like "Mack the Knife" and "(You're) Having My Baby" to originals like "The Ballad of Sheila Cornucopia," the sleazy saga of his fifth marriage, to a former Miss Idaho.

title: Restaurants
description: In 1985, the conservative French food establishment in New York City went into a swivet when La Caravelle, that fortress of classical French cuisine, took on an American chef, Michael Romano. It was the first time in memory that a non-Frenchman had run the kitchen of an old-line Gallic institution in the city, something like having a Pakistani as grand marshal of the St. Patrick's Day parade.

title: Chinese Wait for Deaths of Their Leaders, Who Just Get Older
description: With China's octogenarian leaders now at least as fragile as they are powerful, the whispers in Beijing these days are of tracheotomies and cancer and eventually funerals. There are signs that mortality may finally be catching up with some of those who run the country.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "This was the year the little guy came through. It shows that when times are tough, New Yorkers are still there to help one another." -- MSGR. TIMOTHY McDONNELL, chief financial officer for Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York. [ B1:2. ]

title: BUSINESS DIGEST

title: William G. Weart, Journalist, 85
description: William G. Weart, the Philadelphia correspondent of The New York Times for 21 years until his retirement in 1966, died on Saturday at the Lehigh Valley Medical Center in Allentown, Pa. He was 85 years old.

title: Intel Is Planning Several New Chips
description: The Intel Corporation said it would introduce more than 30 new variations of its 486 and 386 SL processors in 1992. The company's chief executive, Andrew S. Grove, told securities analysts in New York that the new chips would include faster versions and some that operate on lower voltages for battery-powered computers.

title: BRIEFS

description: Clyde Connell Arthur Roger Gallery 136 Prince Street SoHo Through Feb. 1

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House Leader and Salesman; Bush Turns to Power of Incumbency And Tries to Defuse Revolt in Party
description: After apologizing for the state of the economy and assuring Americans that he cares, President Bush this week has moved to a new phase of his re-election campaign in which he is trying to use the power of his incumbency to demonstrate that he is doing something about the nation's problems.

title: Thomaston Mills Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Security Council to Pledge To Stop Global Aggression
description: President Bush and heads of government from the other 14 members of the United Nations Security Council will be asked at a meeting on Jan. 31 to commit themselves to reverse acts of aggression and affirm that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq must comply fully with their terms for ending the Persian Gulf war.

title: Public Service Co. of Colorado reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Taking Communists to Court: Road Strewn With Nettles, Czechs Say
description: The trial of three former high-ranking Communist officials is exposing the difficulties of punishing those responsible for the damage that most Czechoslovaks believe the previous Government did to their country.

title: Shell Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Hubbell Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
5 Hindu Militants Slain on Kashmir Trip
description: Gunmen disguised as police officers opened fire with AK-47's just north of here this afternoon on several busloads of political workers, killing 5 people and wounding 40, news agencies reported. The buses were part of a caravan, led by the leader of India's right-wing opposition party, that was headed for the strife-torn Vale of Kashmir.

title: Drug Makers To Subsidize Prescriptions
description: In the face of Congressional attacks on high drug prices, one drug maker announced a program yesterday to provide free prescription drugs to poor and elderly patients who are unable to pay for them, while another drug company introduced a rebate plan.

title: Winn-Dixie Stores Inc.  reports earnings for 16wks to Jan 8
Austria Offers Legislation to Make It Easier to Prosecute Neo-Nazis
description: The Austrian Government said today that it would propose creating a new law and amending an old one to make it easier to prosecute crimes such as advocating Nazi ideas or denying the Holocaust.

title: Arthur M. Fishberg, Physician, 93
description: Dr. Arthur M. Fishberg, a retired hospital official and an authority on hypertension, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93 years old.

title: Hartmarx Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included net provision of $ 9 million to cover costs associated with consolidation of certain administrative functions for both the quarter and year.c-Included net provision of $ 51 million for restructuring.The company said the latest quarter included a tax benefit of $ 7,390,000 while the year-earlier quarter had a similar benefit of $ 2,725,000. For all of fiscal 1991, Hartmarx had a tax benefit of $ 21,630,000, compared with a $ 33,265,000 benefit in the previous fiscal year.

title: Sterling Chemicals Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Tandem Computers Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe latest first quarter's results included a pre-tax restructuring charge of $ 98 million, or $ 80.5 million after taxes.

title: Chemical Bank Official To New Midlantic Post
description: Alan M. Silberstein, an 18-year employee of the Chemical Banking Corporation and now the bank's executive vice president responsible for the consumer banking group, was named yesterday to a new position as executive vice president and director of retail banking for the Midlantic Corporation.

title: Coca-Cola Begins 24-Hour Campaign
description: Beginning at 6 this morning, Eastern time, the Coca-Cola Company will sell around the clock, in its first 24-hour global television advertising bombardment.

title: Olden Tunes By Fiddlers With the Lilt Of the Celts
description: Back in the early days of this century, an Irish fiddle player named Michael Coleman left his home in County Sligo and came to America. Coleman was revered in Sligo as one of the best fiddlers the county had ever produced; he was famous for jigs and reels, and his name was synonymous with a kind of local pride. When Coleman arrived in New York, he was exposed to all kinds of ethnic music through the city's vast immigrant population: German polkas, Italian love songs, Harlem jazz. These new forms must have had subtle influences on his playing. Coleman became one of the first Irish musicians to make recordings. His disks found their way back to County Sligo, where he was celebrated yet again for bringing Irish music to the land of opportunity.

title: Review/Photography; 4 Shows That Borrow From the Past in Technique and Treatment
description: Ever since photography was invented, artists have tried to bend it to their will, to impose their own stamp upon the seemingly neutral transcriptions of visual information that it provides. By far the most popular way has been to try to make photographs look like something else, usually something with a greater cachet as art, whether oil paintings, watercolors or charcoal drawings.

title: SJW Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Moody's Review Of Upjohn's Debt
description: The Upjohn Company's $520 million in debt is under review for a possible downgrade, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday. Some of the debt now bears an AA-2 rating.

title: Beatrice I. Lerner, 76, Democratic Party Aide
description: Beatrice I. Lerner, a longtime Democratic party worker and government aide in New Jersey and a leader in Jewish, cultural and charitable causes, died on Monday at the Cedar Grove Manor Convalescent Home in Cedar Grove, N.J. She was 76 years old and was a resident of South Orange, N.J.

title: 2 Greenwich Youths Die In a Murder-Suicide
description: Two boys, seniors at Greenwich High School, were found shot to death in a wooded park here Wednesday night, and today the state medical examiner declared the deaths a murder-suicide.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Cray Research Inc., Minneapolis, said Ford Motor Co. would install a Cray Y-MP C90 computer at its engineering center in Dearborn, Mich. * Exxon Corp., New York, said that its affiliate Esso Nederland B.V. would build a $200 million hydrocracking unit at its Rotterdam factory.

title: Johnson Is All-Star Amid More Questions
description: Hours after a medical officer with the Australian Olympic Committee said he would recommend that his team not play if Magic Johnson was on the court, the former Los Angeles Laker star, who has tested positive for the virus that causes AIDS, was selected as a starter for the National Basketball Association All-Star Game next month.

title: 3 Are Killed In Car Wreck In Queens
description: Two automobile accidents on rain-slick streets in Queens and Brooklyn left 3 people dead and 11 injured yesterday, the police said. One of the dead and six of the injured were children.

title: Lord, Dentsu Wins Amati Ad Account
description: On Madison Avenue, where the world divides into agencies that have automobile accounts and those that do not, Lord, Dentsu & Partners yesterday joined the ranks of the "haves."

title: Data General Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
Review/Art; Masterpieces of the Pen, Including 2 Rembrandts
description: The current exhibition of "17th-Century Dutch Drawings" at the Pierpont Morgan Library comes from a single private collection for which "must see" is now the adjective of everyday use. It burns small, and it burns slowly. But in the memory, it blazes up.

title: Shady Stores for Moscow Night Owls
description: Russia's free-market groping is taking on a dark but promising edge as pioneer shopkeepers invent the all-night convenience store, Moscow style.

title: Plan Offered By Holtzman For M.A.C.
description: New York City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman proposed yesterday that the city use $200 million from the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation to pay for streamlining the city government through technological changes and early-retirement programs.

title: Tale of Briton's Hanging May Get Epilogue
description: In 1968, 15 years after Derek Bentley was hanged for the slaying of a police officer, his family won permission to move his remains to a cemetery from the yard of the prison where he was executed and buried. Anticipating the reburial, his father, William, had the words "Victim of British Justice" chiseled on a tombstone.

title: Train Nonviolent Offenders at Former Bases
description: To the Editor:

title: Bills Say They Get No Respect At All
description: Bruce Smith is angry that the Redskins don't respect the Bills' defense. Thurman Thomas, the consensus selection for most valuable player this season, doesn't believe he gets enough respect or recognition and has resigned himself that he "will have to live with the title of best all-around back."

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about new interest in fragrances that were popular in the 1960's misstated sales figures for musk oil at Kiehl's Since 1851, a pharmacy and natural cosmetics store in Manhattan. Musk oil accounts for 60 percent of the store's sales of scented oils.

title: Fidelity Investments Shores Up Retail Arm
description: In what Fidelity Investments called part of a planned expansion in retail brokerage, Thomas E. Meade, a manager with experience supervising regional brokerage outlets, was named yesterday as the president of Fidelity Brokerage Services Inc.

title: CBS's Success in Super Bowl
description: CBS said yesterday that it had sold all but one of the 56 commercials that the network plans to run during its telecast of Super Bowl XXVI on Sunday.

title: Louisiana Land & Exploration Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EX-SOVIET LANDS TO GET SWIFT AID
description: The 47-nation conference on aid to the former Soviet Union ended today with some general proposals on how to expand and accelerate humanitarian assistance but with lingering uncertainty over how to pay for the programs and carry them out.

title:
Middle-Class Development;
Work to Start on New Jersey Condos
description: Over the next few months, on a mostly vacant block on the edge of the business district here, work will begin on the initial phase of Riverwatch, a development of 600 condominium units intended for middle-class buyers.

title: Telephone Earnings Depressed
description: A.T.& T., as well as three of the regional companies known as Baby Bells, posted depressed fourth-quarter and full-year earnings yesterday. Their reports generally reflected furious competitive pressures to cut costs and employees, plus a slowdown in the growth of telephone calls attributed to the persistent economic recession.

title: Court Refuses Grand Jury Records
description: An appeals court yesterday rejected the Brooklyn District Attorney's request to release the secret grand jury minutes and records concerning the death of a 7-year-old black child in an automobile accident last year in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 586 money market mutual funds increased by $7.52 billion, to $506.82 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 217 institutional funds increased by $3.45 billion, to $177.78 billion. The assets of the 280 general-purpose funds were up by $2.31 billion, to $180.37 billion. The 89 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.76 billion, to $148.67 billion, the institute said.

title: Israel Agrees to Ties With China, Aiding Beijing Role in Talks
description: China and Israel established diplomatic ties today, paving the way for Beijing to participate in the Moscow round of Middle East peace talks next week.

title: Trinova Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special charge for the writeoff of certain intangibles (primarily goodwill) and other charges amounting to $ 166.4 million, or $ 156.4 million net, in the quarter and year.c-Net incomeThe latest year's net loss included a gain of $ 2.3 milion ($ 1.4 million after tax, or 5 cents a share) from settlement of outstanding litigation associated with the purchase and installation of automated factory equipment at one of the company's production facilities.The 1990 year's net income included a gain of $ 5.2 million ($ 2.8 million after tax, or 9 cents a share) from settlement of certain terminated defined-benefit pension plans.

title: Bush Weighs Health Benefits Tax And Cap on Medicaid Payments
description: As part of President Bush's effort to curb spending on health care, Administration officials want to limit how much Federal Medicaid payments can grow each year, and they want to impose a new tax on high-income people with health insurance purchased by employers.

title: Corrections

Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the killing of a Ukrainian immigrant in Flushing, Queens, rendered the name of the victim incorrectly. He was Jeff Ostrovsky.

title: Vans Vie Illegally for New York Bus Riders
description: One every two minutes, the unmarked vans scoot into city bus stops along Flatbush Avenue, scooping up clumps of waiting commuters. Sometimes, the vans simply cut the buses off in a brazen race to the curb. As soon as one is pulled over by the police -- and they often are -- its passengers slip out and around the corner, where another idles out of sight of the law.

title: Clorox Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSH TO ASK MORE FOR BASE CLEANUPS
description: The Bush Administration has sharply increased its estimate of the cost of cleaning up pollution on military bases, and plans to ask Congress for an immediate increase of $1 billion for this purpose beyond the $2.7 billion already included in this year's military budget.

title: St.-Leger Journal; Europe's Homebred Imams, Preaching Tolerance
description: In a rambling chateau on a misty wooded hillside in deepest Burgundy, a dozen or so young men with stubbly beards have enrolled in an ambitious experiment aimed at eliminating one of the principal causes of social tension in Europe today.

description: Democrats went on the offensive today over another extension of unemployment benefits and dared Republicans to delay the measure by objecting to its financing.

description: One sure-fire way to get new music performed is to dangle it in front of music students. Although some are content to concentrate on Beethoven and Brahms, many are attracted both by the technical challenges that new music offers, and not least by the opportunity to play daredevil in public.

title: Italy Is Nice, But Addison Likes the Nets
description: One of the ways to uncover what's behind the Nets' upswing these days is to do what Coach Bill Fitch has been doing with regularity and success: Go to the bench.

title: Deadly Strain of Tuberculosis Is Spreading Fast, U.S. Finds
description: Particularly dangerous forms of tuberculosis have struck in 16 states, and the spread of the disease is out of control, Federal health officials said today.

title: Market Place; Edgell May Show the Way To Heal Buyout Casualties
description: Edgell Communications was in many ways a prototypical leveraged buyout of the 1980's, forced by a raider into assuming so much debt that it soon collapsed. Now Edgell is emerging from bankruptcy with a deal that may set a pattern for the 1990's.

title: Israeli Military Panel Cancels Order to Deport a Palestinian
description: An army panel today recommended the canceling of an order to deport a Palestinian suspected of terrorist activities in the occupied territories, revoking one of 12 expulsions ordered this month by the Government. The decision represents the first cancellation of a deportation order by the military since 1979.

title: Sports of The Times; Some Teams Succeed On Turmoil
description: Thurman Thomas is visibly seething because he feels undervalued. Bruce Smith is also seething because some creeps have written him ugly letters. They both look as if they would like to hit somebody. In their line of work, this is not such a bad state of mind.

title: Rohm & Haas Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Police Join Spectators At Fellow Officer's Trial
description: In a rare twist for a criminal trial, police officers are turning out strong here each morning to show their support for a defendant.

title: Sara Lee Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: The latest 6 months' share earnings included a gain of 60 cents a share in the first quarter, reflecting the sale of the company's European-based pharmaceutical business.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about RU-486, the drug known as the "French abortion pill," referred incorrectly to the campaign to make it available in the United States. The Feminist Majority Foundation is studying the possibility of a boycott of the Hoechst Celanese Corporation, which holds the American rights to the drug; the group says it is not advocating a boycott.

title: Freddie Bartholomew Is Dead; Child Star in Films of the 1930's
description: Freddie Bartholomew, a Hollywood child star whose name became synonymous with the proper, curly-haired little English boys he played in "David Copperfield" and "Little Lord Fauntleroy," died yesterday at Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Sarasota, Fla. His age was variously reported as 69 and 70. He lived in Bradenton, Fla.

title: Saul Z. Cohen, 65, Labor Lawyer, Dies
description: Saul Z. Cohen, a labor lawyer who was active in Jewish philanthropies, died yesterday at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: The Comics Break New Ground, Again
description: After nearly a decade of battling evil around the globe, the comic book hero Northstar has revealed to the 100,000 or so people who follow his exploits that he is gay.

title: U.S. Said to Give Deadline to North Korea
description: The United States has given North Korea a deadline for allowing inspections of its nuclear sites and will propose that an American air base be opened simultaneously for inspections, the South Korean news agency Yonhap reported today.

title: Houghton Mifflin reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax costs and operating losses totaling $ 4.9 million related to the sale of the company's Australian business and provisions to restructure certain corporate and divisional activities in the U.S.c-Included a $ 3.6 million pretax charge for the writedown of intangible assets and a pretax gain of $ 1.4 million from the sale of a secondary school list.d-Included pretax gain of $ 1.8 million from the sale of secondary school lists and the write-down of certain educational and intangible assets.

title: Hess Loses $51.6 Million
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation said today that it had lost $51.6 million in the fourth quarter of last year, as lower crude prices and a big loss in refining hampered operations. In the comparable period in 1990, net income totaled $234.2 million, or $2.90 a share.

title: On My Mind; Thanking Sakurauchi
description: The Japanese -- some of them are beginning to get under our skin. I'm thinking now of that politician who said that American workers are lazy and a third of them couldn't read.

title: 2 Tied to Fatal Crush at Game Are Leaving Jobs
description: Two City College officials whose roles in events leading up to the deadly crush at a celebrity basketball game last month have been questioned are leaving their jobs, the college announced yesterday.

title: Central Maine Power reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
An S.& L. Is Going Back to Basics
description: The savings and loan industry may be putting its notorious past behind it, but the legacy of its headlong rush into deregulation a decade ago continues to haunt some of the nation's largest savings institutions as they scramble to adapt to new regulations and cope with a weak economy.

title: Network Equipment Tech.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Net lossc-After an extraordinary credit of $ 2,379,000, or 17 cents a share.

title: Question of Settlement
description: A judge in California was asked yesterday to determine whether a settlement has been reached in a wrongful death suit filed by the family of Hank Gathers, the Loyola Marymount University star.

title: Billy Graham, 70, Welterweight Boxer
description: Billy Graham, a welterweight boxer noted for stylish and subtle moves that made him a difficult target in the ring, died Wednesday at his home in West Islip, L.I. He was 70 years old.

title: Dallas Journal; Uncompromising Choice Leaves Dallas Undecided
description: A little before 1 A.M. today Lori Palmer, a member of the Dallas City Council, tried to summarize the problem she and her colleagues faced, saying: "Dallas seems to have more difficulty than many other cities in coming to terms with its differences. We seem to have to go through exorcisms."

title: Clinton Denounces New Report of Affair
description: Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas today denounced as "not true" a second wave of accusations of marital infidelity published by the tabloid newspaper Star.

title: A Happy Return for Messier Has Oilers Feeling Blue
description: Mark Messier returned home tonight and was embraced by the fans who followed him for 12 years here. Then he won a game for the Rangers.

title: Read-Rite Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Review/Film; A Dangerous Twist To the 50-Minute Hour
description: Since she won an Oscar nomination for her performance in "Anna" (1987), Sally Kirkland has worked tirelessly but to increasingly small effect in a series of movies whose titles, in all probability, only she remembers. Add to the list: "In the Heat of Passion."

title: Allegheny Power System reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Joe Richards, Writer, 83
description: Joe Richards, a writer and a painter, died on Sunday at the Bay Pines Veterans Administration Hospital in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 83 years old.

title: Quantum Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
A Military Revolt Fails To Oust Rulers in Zaire
description: The streets of the capital were deserted and tanks guarded the national broadcast center today after a group of rebel soldiers tried but failed to overthrow President Mobutu Sese Seko. Two people were killed in the coup attempt, the Zairian military said.

title: Big East, A.C.C. and Irish in Lockstep With 4 Bowls
description: The long-discussed coalition of four major college football bowl games moved within one step of reality yesterday when the Orange, Sugar, Cotton and Fiesta Bowls announced an agreement with the Big East and Atlantic Coast Conferences and Notre Dame.

title: Japanese Bid for Seattle Team Gets Baseball's Cold Shoulder
description: Reaching to Japan in an effort to keep the American national pastime alive in Seattle, this city's leaders announced today that a group led by Japanese investors had made an offer to buy the Seattle Mariners baseball team for $100 million.

title: Independent, Yes, but Estonia Shivers
description: Freshly minted trappings of statehood are in evidence immediately on arrival here: two Soviet-made planes proudly emblazoned "Estonian" stand on the tarmac, fuzzy-cheeked customs agents order arriving Russians to buy visas, youthful police officers wear new uniforms.

title: Sealed Air Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Eastern Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 8,662,000 which reflects early adoption of FAS No. 106.

title: American Telephone & Telegraph reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the 12 months ended Dec. 31, 1991, included a gain of $ 171 million on the sales of AT&T's equity interests in Sun Microsystems, Inc., (8 cents a share after taxes) and a gain of $ 43 million from the sale of equity interests in a subsidiary (3 cents a share after taxes).In September 1991, AT&T merged with NCR Corporation. As a result, approximately 71.4 million shares of NCR common stock were each converted into 2.839 million shares of AT&T common stock. The merger was accounted for as a pooling of interests and, accordingly, the financial statements of AT&T have been restated for all periods prior to the merger to include NCR.

title: Implants and Halcion: the Shadow
description: The U.S. system for regulating and prescribing drugs and medical devices turns on trust that leading manufacturers will diligently test the safety of their products and honestly report the results. That trust has now been shaken by disturbing evidence and accusations in recent liability suits against two major companies.

title: Critic's Notebook; Toward a More Modern Modern
description: BIT by bit and month by month, the Museum of Modern Art has been undergoing a quiet transformation. The change has been taking place at the heart of the institution -- in the second- and third-floor galleries of painting and sculpture, which for years have depicted modern art as an evolution beginning with Cezanne and culminating heroically in Abstract Expressionism. That seamless interpretation, initiated by Alfred H. Barr Jr., founding director of the museum, and cultivated by William S. Rubin, former head of the department of painting and sculpture, unfolded as something authoritative and final. Pop artists, Minimalists and all those who worked in the 1960's and later tended to be relegated to temporary quarters in the galleries of contemporary art.

description: Carl Goldhagen Rosa Esman Gallery 575 Broadway (at Prince Street) SoHo Through Feb. 8

Michael's Tenure With Yankees Grows Shakier

description: Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, who enthralled colleagues with his blitzkrieg victory in last month's Speaker's race, suddenly faces discontent in his chamber because of his handling of legislative redistricting.

The Spoken Word
description: LECTURE AND PERFORMANCE, Juilliard School, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, at 65th Street, Manhattan. "A Day of Mozart," featuring a lecture about the composer's early compositions, tomorrow at noon, given by Bruce Adolphe, a composer and faculty member, and Ore Carmi, a pianist; and performances of Mozart pieces at 3 and 6 P.M. by the Pre-College Symphony and Chorus and Chamber Orchestra. All events are free. Information: (212) 769-7406.

title: Economic Scene; Conservative Plea To Aid Ex-Soviets
description: AID to the former Soviet republics has become an ideological issue in this country, pitting those who say the United States and its partners should move rapidly and generously to provide assistance against those who would wait for them to collapse. Favoring large-scale aid, according to the oversimplified version, are liberals, pragmatists and internationalists, and on the side opposing aid, at least until authoritarian structures are destroyed, root and branch, are conservatives, supply-siders and America Firsters.

title: Chief Executive Is Named At Municipal Bond Insurer
description: The Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, the subsidiary of the GE Capital Corporation that insures securities, principally municipal bonds, has named Ann C. Stern president and chief executive.

title: A Town of One's Own, Emptied by Supet Bowl
description: I CAN hardly wait. Along with millions of other people in New York and the rest of the country, I am getting ready for Super Bowl XXVI on Sunday when the Buffalo Bills meet the Washington Redskins in the greatest of all football battles. What could be more appropriate, Buffalo Bills versus Indians, a classic matchup, right out of the history books. Eagles and Buccaneers don't match, Vikings and Saints don't match, but Buffalo Bills and Redskins are perfect.

2 Fiery Personas, but No Sparks, in Courtroom

But in the end, it seemed to be a normal day at the office for both guests of honor, the Rev. Al Sharpton and former Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall.

title: New York Asks U.S. Help In Tracking New TB Cases
description: Federal health officials are investigating a spate of drug-resistant tuberculosis cases among patients at a city hospital in Queens between late 1990 and June 1991.

title: Corrections
description: A sampling of quotations yesterday, proposed by political strategists, satirists and others as sound bites likely to make the evening news in 1992, misstated the title of a book by P. J. O'Rourke. It is "Republican Party Reptile." In some copies the sampling also referred erroneously, on second mention, to the contributor of one proposed sound bite. The contribution -- "While George Bush putts, America goes down the hole" -- was from David Axelrod, a media consultant with the Clinton campaign, not a "Mr. Stone."

title: As Cabbies Protest, Taxi Panel Decides Against Fare Increase
description: Unlike subway and bus passengers, cab users won't be paying more for their rides -- at least not right away.

title: Knicks Advised to Take the Game Home
description: The Knicks, who have played recently as if they need a change of scenery, will get one starting tonight when they begin a three-game Western Conference road trip against the Golden State Warriors.

title: Ashland Oil Shows Profit
description: Ashland Oil Inc. today reported earnings of $29.5 million, or 50 cents a share, for the quarter ended Dec. 31, saying a good performance by its coal and motor oil operations helped it bounce back from an $10.8 million loss for the comparable period a year earlier.

title: S.E.C. Doesn't Discriminate Against Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: Donors in Need Aid Those Even Needier
description: Instead of spending more on gifts this holiday season, thousands in the New York region gave more to charity instead, producing a surge of small donations that enabled many charities to reach goals that had seemed out of reach in November.

description: NEW YORK CITY THE WAR FOR THE ROADS

title: Rypien Sustains An Ankle Sprain
description: The Redskins got a scare at practice today when quarterback Mark Rypien sprained his right ankle a few minutes before the end of their two-hour practice. The sprain isn't serious enough to keep Rypien out of practice Friday and he's expected to be fine for Sunday's game.

title: G.M.'s Computer Unit In Big Blue Cross Deal
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Massachusetts, one of many insurers under pressure to become more efficient in administration of claims, has awarded the Electronic Data Systems Corporation an $800 million, 10-year contract to provide computer services.

title: Surprise! Surprise! One or Two Might Turn Up at the Metrodome
description: That line about not changing what brought you to the dance at first glance applies to both Washington and Buffalo in Super Bowl XXVI on Sunday.

title: The New Buy-American Auto Sweepstakes
description: Maybe it was President Bush's mixed success in Japan, or the Japanese official who said that American auto workers were lazy and illiterate. Maybe it is the deep slump in Detroit. But all of a sudden, companies around the United States are saying it would be good for America to be good to G.M., and they are offering inducements to their employees to buy from General Motors, Chrysler or Ford.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's not easy for television correspondents to find the time to socialize, so CONNIE COLLINS found her WNBC-TV colleagues more than willing to go to Sag Harbor, L.I., this weekend to help her with a school benefit.

title: More Needed to Clean Bases
description: The Administration has sharply increased its estimate of the cost of removing pollution from the nation's military bases. Page A15.

title: Zale Files Plan For Chapter 11
description: The Zale Corporation, the jewelry store chain under pressure from its creditors, filed for voluntary protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code today.

title: Top Court Could Overturn Roe Without Saying So
description: As thousands of demonstrators took to the streets here this week to mark the 19th anniversary of Roe v. Wade, the obvious question was whether the Supreme Court's landmark ruling on the right to abortion would survive to see a 20th anniversary.

title: Moscow Needs More Than a Gesture
description: The emergency food and medicine that 47 of the world's wealthiest nations have now promised to send to the former Soviet Union amount to a pittance. But the gesture is important. The citizens of the republics, terrified by the collapse of their economies, have at least been told that the West is in their corner.

title: Ex-Officer Found Guilty of $17,000 Bank Fraud
description: After deliberating for less than an hour, a Federal jury today found Robert C. Fioretti, a former New York City police officer, guilty of stealing $17,000 from his first wife's savings account in 1986, two months after she vanished.

title: Attica Judge Issues Order; Jury Rebels
description: The judge in the long-running Attica trial, who left for a Caribbean vacation in the middle of deliberations last week, returned against his will today to find the jurors in rebellion.

title: Senate Rejects Bush Plan to Aid The Poor Who Use Private Schools
description: The Senate dealt President Bush's education program a major defeat today by voting down a proposal to provide Federal aid for disadvantaged families that choose to send their children to parochial and other private schools.

title: Review/Film; Vintage Visconti, at Full Length
description: "Rocco and His Brothers" was shown as part of the 1991 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 21. The film, in Italian with English subtitles, opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street in Manhattan.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Arms Makers Criticize Plan That Puts Focus on Research
description: The Bush Administration's proposal to shift the Pentagon's focus from building costly weapons to an approach revolving around laboratory research would be the most radical change in the military-industrial relationship since the birth of the modern arms business that mushroomed after World War II.

title: Service Merchandise Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28

title: Springsteen to Release 2 Albums at Once
description: If Guns 'n' Roses can release two albums at once, so can Bruce Springsteen. In early spring, Mr. Springsteen will release "Human Touch" and "Lucky Town," his first new albums since "Tunnel of Love" in 1987. "I'm excited about being finished and am looking forward to getting out on the road," Mr. Springsteen said in a statement.

title: Peruvian Rebels Assert Role In Downing of a U.S. Copter
description: Peruvian rebels claimed responsibility today for the downing of an American helicopter this month in a coca-producing region. Three Americans aboard the helicopter were killed.

description: Sales of cars and light trucks built in North America declined 1.9 percent in mid-January, auto makers reported today.

title: Venezuela Is Said To Seek Citgo Sale
description: Officials at Venezuela's Ministry of Energy and Mines have proposed selling 50 percent of the United States gasoline distributorship known as Citgo to help finance Government spending, according to people familiar with the ministry. Venezuela's state oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela S.A., which owns Citgo, is said to be vigorously opposed. A spokesman for the company had no comment.

The periods also included an after-tax $ 26.4 million gain, or 45 cents a share, on the sale of Micromedex Inc., a medical information subsidiary, and after-tax charge of $ 21.6 million to cover the costs of safeguarding landfills, consolidations within some business units, and previously incurred engineering costs.c-Net lossd-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 54.2 million in the quarter and $ 74.8 million in the year, and extraordinary credits of $ 800,000, or 1 cent a share, and $ 6.9 million, or 11 cents a share, in the quarter and year, respectively, from gains on early retirement of debt.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats; Mayors Appear Unmoved by the Major Candidates
description: After hearing pitches from the Democratic Presidential contenders on how they would revive America's cities, dozens of mayors meeting here today seemed to agree on one thing: the single candidate who truly understands urban needs is Larry Agran.

title: MILITARY PROPOSES TO END PRODUCTION OF MOST NEW ARMS
description: In a shift that could save billions of dollars in future military spending, the Pentagon plans to suspend production of most new weapons after developing test models, senior Defense Department officials said today.

description: Surge in Charity Spending

title: CHRONICLE

He will retire next Friday from the two radio programs he does for ABC Radio: "Speaking of Sports," a two-minute program broadcast daily on about 200 stations nationwide, and "Speaking of Everything," a weekly half-hour program on about 100 stations.

title: 12 Indicted On Violence In Drug Ring
description: Twelve people described as members of the "Supreme Team," which Federal authorities call a drug ring that terrorized southeastern Queens during the 1980's, were indicted yesterday in a string of violence that included at least nine murders.

Austin Named to Hall
description: TRACY AUSTIN's first reaction when she heard that she had been elected to the International Tennis Hall of Fame at the age of 29 was to laugh. "It came so out of the blue," Austin said at a Hall of Fame press luncheon yesterday in New York. "A lot of athletes make their retirement, then after five years talk starts about the Hall of Fame. I never felt like I retired."

title: Reviews/Art; William Wegman's Versatile Humor Survives Man Ray
description: For people who believe art and humor are strange bedfellows, a visit to the 20-year retrospective of William Wegman at the Whitney Museum of American Art may make them think again.

title: Edward Yorio, Professor, 44
description: Edward Yorio, a professor at the Fordham University Law School, died on Sunday at Mount Vernon Hospital in Mount Vernon, N.Y. He was 44 years old and lived in Mount Vernon.

description: GEORGE BRETT, 38, the three-time American League batting champion of the Kansas City Royals, will marry LESLIE DAVENPORT of Kansas City, Mo., in the "near future," Royals spokesman DEAN VOGELAAR said. (AP)

On Thursday, the Nikkei rose 46.60 points.

description: There were signs yesterday that the argument earlier this week between General Manager Gene Michael and Daniel McCarthy, the managing general partner, may be sending the Yankees back into another period of stagnation.

Parading Bigotry
description: The Irish of New York were the victims of discrimination for centuries. That makes it all the more deplorable that organizers of the St. Patrick's Day Parade, the Ancient Order of the Hibernians, persist in preventing a gay Irish organization from marching as a unit in the celebration on March 17. Their obstinate bias insults a proud history and a proud city.

title: Smithfield Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: Two employees of a check-cashing company were ambushed and critically wounded yesterday by robbers who stole $25,000 that the men were delivering to a warehouse here, the police said.

Just Who Can Raise the Shades and Peek Into Private Matters?
description: Louis Brandeis once said that "privacy is the most comprehensive of all rights."

title: Buying Almost-New Cars With a Past
description: When car dealers started selling current-model cars used by rental companies like Hertz and Avis at sharp discounts, many consumers found attractive deals. But those deals are about to become less attractive. Why? Because car manufacturers, hurt by poor new-car sales, are requiring the rental companies to keep the cars longer before they buy them back for resale.

description: Gil ShahamViolinistCarnegie Hall

description: Shaken by scandals and new frictions with Washington, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa opened a new session of Parliament today pledging to "make every effort to cooperate" with the United States to solve its economic problems.

title: Topics of The Times; King Cat
description: One morning this week, the owner of two cats watched horrified while the older and fatter, Leo, explored what to him was a new continent. It was a long shelf, eight or so feet off the floor, lined with a lifetime's collection of pottery. None of it had come cheap.

title: Cards to Play Japanese Squad
description: Commissioner Fay Vincent announced yesterday that the St. Louis Cardinals would play a team of Japanese all-stars in two exhibition games March 14-15 in Barcelona, Spain.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Never mind all those musty case textbooks that are used to teach law: In the classroom of STEPHEN GILLERS, professor of legal ethics at New York University School of Law, it's the folks from NBC's television show "L.A. Law" who incite the most provocative classroom discussions.

title: A Studied Calm on Algeria's Day of Prayer
description: The first Friday prayers in Algeria since the arrest of a senior Muslim fundamentalist leader were held peacefully today, as militant opponents of the Government apparently heeded their party's advice to maintain an outward calm.

title: U.S. Expected to Push Germany to Cut Rates
description: When the Group of Seven finance ministers meet Saturday on Long Island, the United States will continue its campaign to put pressure on Germany to lower interest rates as a way to promote economic growth around the world, American officials say.

title: Possibility of Orion Bid
description: The Turner Broadcasting System is considering a bid for the Orion Pictures Corporation, according to several movie industry executives. But a spokesman for Turner declined to comment yesterday. Turner's chairman, Ted Turner, had previously considered bidding for Orion as well as MGM/UA Entertainment.

title: Head of National Gallery Is Retiring
description: J. Carter Brown, who oversaw the transformation of the National Gallery of Art in Washington from a specialized museum into one of the largest art institutions in the country, announced yesterday that he would retire as its director by the end of the year. Only the third director in the National Gallery's 50-year history, he has held the position for 22 years.

title: From Russia with Hope: In America to Stay - A special report; Seeking Shelter in U.S. After the Soviet Storm
description: The scene is familiar. Immigrants are crowded onto cots in the back rooms of a church in Los Angeles. But these are not Latin Americans escaping poverty and civil war. They are penniless Russians, members of a new wave of underground immigrants to the United States.

title: Cars That Sell Themselves? Indeed
description: In an industry suffering from a severe slump, the Swanson Chrysler Plymouth car dealership here has found that the best way to improve sales is to get rid of the sales staff, cut the prices and let car buyers shop in peace. No haggling. No pressure. Just a yellow sign on each car's windshield, with a take-it-or-leave-it price.

title: Cuba Rally Scheduled Despite Security Concerns
description: A rally by a group calling for improved ties with Cuba, canceled by the Jacob Javits Convention Center because of fears of possible violence and overcrowding, will go on as scheduled today.

title: Unfriendly Skies for Libya
description: For too long, terrorism in the air has been a crime without punishment for outlaw states that shelter wanted suspects. This week, for the first time, the United Nations held Libya directly accountable for its involvement in "deeply disturbing" terrorist acts. It is a salutary precedent that can hasten the end of a dirty business.

title: Hanan J. Ayalti, 81; Wrote Yiddish Works
description: Hanan J. Ayalti, author of many Yiddish and Hebrew works, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Chester, Conn.

title: Your Taxes; Mail-Order Rule Likely to Change
description: If the Justices' questioning during oral arguments is any guide to their ultimate decision, the Supreme Court seems likely to overturn a landmark 1967 ruling and decide this spring that a state may levy sales taxes on mail-order merchandise from outside its borders.

description: A Federal bankruptcy judge today gave the Zale Corporation approval to pay $6.7 million in employee commissions, wages and severance.

title: Company Settles Lawsuit Over Exposure to Dioxin
description: The Diamond Shamrock Company, which for years has fought claims that it recklessly endangered the health of workers and residents near a former herbicide plant by exposing them to dioxin, has agreed to a $1 million settlement.

title: Oh How the Mighty Have Fallen
description: PETE INCAVIGLIA, ignored as a free agent in spite of his 135 home runs in six major league seasons, finally got a job yesterday. The Houston Astros signed the outfielder, who never played in the minors, to a minor league contract, but they expect him to make their youngster-laden team.

title: Observer; It's Only A Story, Bill
description: Not a single vote cast, and Governor Clinton has already won the press. He is now the Front-Runner! Evidence is everywhere. The cover of Time. The New Republic dazzled. New York magazine fascinated. Grocery tabloids leering with hints of scandal. What could be firmer evidence of front-runnerhood than hints that the man is worth a grocery leer?

title: CHRONICLE
description: CAROL THATCHER, the 38-year-old daughter of MARGARET THATCHER, the former Prime Minister of Britain, has said she has no desire to have children and that watching her mother juggle career and family probably had something to do with her decision. Ms. Thatcher, who is single, made her comments on a British television program called "The Truth About Women," which was broadcast on Thursday morning. She was one of several women who discussed their choice of career over children.

title: Aceto Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: De Klerk Vows Black Vote on Reform
description: President F. W. de Klerk promised today to include South Africa's disfranchised black majority in any referendum on political change, but at the same time he reiterated that the white minority would have an opportunity to veto the terms of transition to a new nonracist constitution.

title: New York Sets Out on Legal Path To Allow Gay Irish Unit in Parade
description: Seeking to force the sponsors of New York City's St. Patrick's Day Parade to admit a gay Irish group, the Dinkins administration yesterday charged the organizers with illegal discrimination and asked to have a city hearing officer oversee admission of marchers in a "non-discriminatory" way.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the spread of tuberculosis included incomplete information from the Centers for Disease Control about states that have reported cases of the drug-resistant form of the infection. Since 1989, 17 states have reported cases. Deadly outbreaks occurred in Florida and New York. At least one drug-resistant case has also been reported in each of these states: Alabama, Arizona, California, Georgia, Hawaii, Illinois, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Texas, Utah, Virginia and Washington.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about the novelist Pietro di Donato misidentified one of his books. It is "Three Circles of Light," not "Three Circles of Life."

title: How Do You Stop Coleman? Nights Like This, You Don't
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 24 --

title: U.S. Will Assist Peru's Army in Fighting Cocaine and Rebels
description: After months of Congressionally imposed delays, the Bush Administration is preparing to release $10 million in military aid to Peru as the first stage of a new policy to help the Peruvian military fight drug traffickers and Maoist guerrillas involved in the cocaine trade.

title: Evidence in Massacre Points to Croats

description: Jerome Robbins's "Goldberg Variations" is a contemporary experimental work, not in spite of its celebrated Bach score but because of it. title: Detective Shoots Suspect
description: An off-duty New York City police detective shot and killed a man who tried to hold him up at gunpoint in the Bronx last night, the police said. The detective, Roger Gibson, was walking past 25 East Mosholu Parkway in Bedford Park when the gunman approached him and demanded money. The detective fired three times at the suspect, hitting him once, the police said. The suspect, Roger Garcia, 25 years old, died at Jacobi Hospital.

title: MacDermid Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Allied-Signal Plan for Layoffs
description: The Kansas City division of the Allied-Signal Aerospace Company, expecting budget cuts of up to $40 million over two years, is offering employees voluntary layoff incentives. The incentives, including early retirement, encourage employees to volunteer for job cuts that could affect 750 to 850 workers, said a spokesman, Floyd Walker. Other Allied-Signal plants are not affected.

title: Motorists and Neighborhoods Brace for Gowanus Rebuilding
description: Motorists who use the Gowanus Expressway and residents of the western Brooklyn neighborhoods it cuts through could get their first sour taste this weekend of an effort to rebuild a four-mile elevated stretch of the busy and battered highway over the next 10 years.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Play That Improves as It Travels From Place to Place
description: Caryl Churchill's "Mad Forest" is a rare case of a play that has been strengthened in its travels from theater to theater. Despite that fact and the enthusiasm of the audience, which has filled the Perry Street Theater ever since the work opened in December, "Mad Forest" is scheduled to end its brief run next weekend. Producers have apparently been unable to arrange for a move to another, equally hospitable theater. But the premature closing should not detract from the process that brought the play to this highly creative point.

The German Government said on Wednesday that the consignment had been intercepted at the Frankfurt airport last month, minutes before the plane carrying it had been due to take off for Libya.

description: Two armored-car guards delivering money to a crowded check-cashing store in Queens walked into an ambush yesterday morning, as masked gunmen opened fire, killing one of them, critically injuring the other and also wounding a 78-year-old woman walking by, the police said.

title: Goodyear Sale
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it expected to sell some units in the first quarter for a total of $450 million to $500 million. A spokesman said the company was considering properties in its films divisions, located in Pennsylvania, Ohio, California and Georgia, as well as a polyester plant in Point Pleasant, Va. The operations represent a small portion of Goodyear's general products group, which has $2 billion a year in annual sales, the spokesman said. Last year, Goodyear sold its textile plant in Scottsboro, Ala., for $95 million.

title: Dow Gains 6, but Drops 32 for Week
description: Stock prices rose slightly yesterday, again showing resiliency after a hefty pullback on Thursday. The Dow Jones industrial average finished at 3,232.78, up 6.04 points for the day but off 32.20 for the week.

title: New President Named For Pacific Exchange
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange has promoted Robert M. Greber to the post of president and chief operating officer, effective immediately. Mr. Greber had been the exchange's executive vice president, director of marketing and strategic planning, since July 1990.

title: Scientist Rebuts Officer on Teaneck Youth's Last Actions
description: A forensic scientist testified today that Phillip Pannell was facing Officer Gary Spath of the Teaneck police, and not turning toward him, when the policeman's first shot pierced the lower left corner of the youth's parka.

title: 8 Embark on Quest for Challenger's Slot
description: It is the eve of racing for eight international sailing teams that have challenged the San Diego Yacht Club for the America's Cup. On Saturday they will begin a three-month series of trial races to determine which will win the Louis Vuitton Cup for the right to challenge the United States in the America's Cup final in May.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the trial to determine New York State officials' liability in the 1971 Attica prison uprising misstated the amount of damages sought by former inmates. It is $2.8 billion.

title: It's a Wrap: Rypien Says Ankle Is No Problem

description: Coach Tom McVie kept reminding the Devils all week what an insurmountable task it has been over the years for New Jersey to win at the Capital Centre, especially after falling behind the Washington Capitals. No wonder. In their 10-year history, the Devils had won only four games in 33 visits here.

title: Death, Life and the Presidency
description: It's no surprise that three of the five Democratic candidates for President now say they support the death penalty as heartily as any law-and-order Republican. Their positions are misguided, and there is good reason to wonder if they have spoken too soon.
