Warren, N.J. 432,000 128 Old Stirling Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; master suite w/den, full basement; taxes $6,500.

title: A Scarsdale Collector, at Home With About 2,000 Dolls
description: JOCELYN ADELAAR was given her first doll by a neighbor when she was 5 years old. It had ringlets and wore a bonnet and dress, but the little girl wanted a boy doll. So she cut off its hair and named it Billy and has kept it to this day.

title: Technology; Bombproofing the Skies
description: Since a terrorist bomb weighing less than a pound destroyed Pan American flight 103 over Scotland in 1988 and caused 270 deaths, the Federal Aviation Administration and research firms have been trying to figure out how to make planes immune to such explosives.

title: Homeowners Warned About Leaky Fuel Tanks
description: THOUSANDS of homeowners in southern and western Connecticut may have a financial and environmental problem oozing through their backyards. The State Department of Environmental Protection is warning that old and rusting underground fuel storage tanks could leak heating oil, contaminating ground water and ultimately drinking water supplies.

title: BUSH BUDGET SEEKS AID FOR CHILDREN AND END OF A TAX
description: Sprinkling largess among diverse constituencies at the start of an election year, President Bush wants to repeal the luxury tax on yachts and will propose a substantial increase in the Federal budget for feeding and vaccinating poor children.

title: Page Alexandra Andes Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Andes of Villanova, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Page Alexandra Andes to Christopher Steven Morocco, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Morocco of Athens, Ga. A September wedding is planned.

title: Michael Shields Engaged to Jennifer Ressler
description: Jennifer Ressler, a manager at the Van Den Bergh Foods Company in Lisle, Ill., and Michael Ray Shields, a product sales analyst for Lever Brothers in Westmont, Ill., are engaged to be married in June.

title: Texas Remapping Battle Heats Up, Threatening to Singe the Democrats
description: Historically, the redistricting of the Texas Senate has been a private, gentlemanly affair in which members of that small, powerful chamber looked after their own, but this year it has turned into a raucous political battle that some participants liken to a civil war.

title: Tossing Our Cookies
description: THE HUMORIST SAM Levenson used to tell of a little boy who reported that all the children in his class had been asked to stand up and do a turn on their first day at school. "And what did you do, Johnny?" asked his parents. Replied the boy: "I vomited."

title: James Biddle to Wed Kristin Cater

title: Results Plus
description: SKIING Tomba Clinches Title Alberto Tomba of Italy clinched the World Cup slalom title for the season yesterday by winning the last slalom before the Winter Olympics in France, where he will be defending the two gold medals he won at the 1988 Olympic Games. Tomba nailed his seventh victory of the season in Wengen, Switzerland, with a two-heat total of 1 minute 34.34 seconds, which was 62-hundredths of a second ahead of the overall World Cup leader, Paul Accola of Switzerland. Armin Bittner of Germany was third, 85-hundredths of a second behind. Tomba, who also leads the season giant slalom standing, showed that almost nothing can stop him. A gate pole he uprooted fell in front of his skis in the first run. But he still was second-fastest behind Ole Christian Furuseth of Norway, who fell in his second run. On Tomba's second run, he nearly fell over backward at the top of a slope and then, near the finish, someone threw a snowball in his right eye. Tomba won the slalom and the giant slalom at the Calgary Olympics and is the favorite in the events at the Games in the French Alps. Accola now has 1,270 points in the overall standing, and Tomba 1,060. (AP) Compagnoni Takes Slalom Event: Deborah Compagnoni switched to longer skis and tamed a lightning-fast course in Morzine, France, yesterday to win a supergiant slalom, ending a six-year World Cup drought by Italian women. A two-time world champion, Ulrike Maier, was second, followed by Norway's Merete Fjeldavli and American Diann Roffe, whose fourth place (1:11.64) was the best supergiant finish by a United States skier this season. Compagnoni, 21, a giant-slalom specialist who usually prefers technical races to those in which speed is predominant, completed the 1.1-mile course in 1:11.02. Maier, an Austrian who won supergiant world titles in 1989 and 1991, finished in 1:11.46. Fjeldavli, whose best previous finish was a tie for ninth earlier this season, was third in 1:11.61. The women will complete their three-day World Cup series today in Morzine with a giant slalom. (AP) HORSE RACING Thunder Rumble Wins Thunder Rumble shook off an early challenge from Speaker Phone and ran off to a two-length victory yesterday in Aqueduct's $70,700 Count Fleet Stakes for 3-year-olds. The winner, owned by Konrad O. Widmer, carried 123 pounds and Herb McCauley to his second start in two races this year, covering 1 mile and 70 yards on the fast track in 1:43. (AP)

As they near their destination, they fragment into a burst of separate nuclear bombs, each headed for a different target. Now, suddenly, the end of that destabilizing peril has come into view.

title: Review/Rock; Fans Urged to 'Go Crazy' and They Do
description: Waterproof eyeliner must have been invented for performers like Ozzy Osbourne, who regularly punctuated his concert on Friday night at the Paramount by dipping his head in a bucket of water, then flinging the contents into the front rows. Mr. Osbourne is rock's most cheerful ghoul, singing about strange compulsions, unholy desires, mass destruction and Judgment Day. His concerts, however, are like pep rallies, where Mr. Osbourne urges his fans to sing along and "go crazy." At the Paramount the audience, overwhelmingly male and mostly wearing black T-shirts, stayed on its feet throughout the set; "I love you all!" Mr. Osbourne kept shouting.

title: For Bills, A Bitter Taste Of Defeat
description: Bills linebacker Darryl Talley, draped in a white terry cloth robe with a blue Super Bowl XXVI insignia on the breast pocket, was one of the first Buffalo players in the interview room after the team's 37-24 loss to the Washington Redskins.

title: The Redskins, and the Roof, Fall on the Bills
description: This Super Bowl was supposed to be a high-scoring affair. It was.

title: Integra Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included one-time charges of more than $ 4 million for realignment and reorganization.c-Net loss

title: SUPER BOWL XXVI: Sports of The Times; The Bills Just Loked Like Rank Outsiders
description: IN the Super Bowl, even the gatecrashers arrive in limousines. One can imagine chief executive officers drinking vintage wine in the leather-lined sanctuaries of their stretches while their corporate vice presidents work the streets looking for tickets.

title: Andover Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossThe bank said the latest fourth quarter includes tax benefits of $ 7.5 million, compared with $ 1.7 million in the year-earlier quarter.

title: The Devils Adopt Stylish Black Look
description: The red, green and white colors of their uniforms have been the one consistent aspect of the Devils' 10 years in New Jersey, but the colors, too, are in the process of being changed. Starting with next season, the Devils will dress in red, black and white, which, in the eyes of some of the team's executives, are more attractive and more marketable colors.

title: Sikhs Kill Punjab Candidate
description: Sikh militants demanding a boycott of elections next month in Punjab State shot a candidate to death today, the police said. Investigators said Harpal Singh, who would have been the nominee of the Communist Party of India, was killed by two gunmen near the town of Bhatinda in the southern Punjab.

title: Bancorp of Mississippi reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Interface Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Best Performer? It's Madden in a Rout
description: At 6:31 P.M. Central Standard Time yesterday evening, after a Gerald Riggs touchdown put the Washington Redskins up by 17-0 in the Super Bowl, John Madden gave up on the hapless Buffalo Bills. He used his TeleStrator to show a blimp equipped with a remote-controlled camera tethered to the Metrodome roof.

title: Courier Defeats Edberg To Close In on No. 1
description: It was Australia Day, a celebration of the nation's birth, but it was an all-American celebration at the Australian Open after Jim Courier won the year's first Grand Slam tournament and stood poised to become the first United States man since John McEnroe in 1985 to be ranked No. 1 in the world.

title: Southwest Airlines Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Washington Makes Its Presence Felt
description: From the day they began preparing for this game, the Washington Redskins wanted to punish the Buffalo Bills: make the runners not want to run, the receivers not want to receive and the quarterback not want to throw.

title: INSIDE
description: Overhauling Taxi Industry

title: Ms. Reps Wed To B. J. Smith
description: Cathy Ellen Reps, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Cantor of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Bryan Jeffrey Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Smith of New York. Judge Gerard H. Rosenberg of the Civil Court of the City of New York officiated at the Zinno Restaurant in New York.

title: First Reversal on Touchdown
description: The first touchdown reversal caused by instant replay in Super Bowl history -- when a replay caught Redskins receiver Art Monk's foot out of bounds in the first quarter -- "will make it awfully hard to say you're not going to use it anymore," said Sandy Grossman, who directed the game's broadcast for CBS.

title: Rival Factions in Cambodia Pledge to Uphold Peace Plan
description: Cambodia's four rival political factions pledged today to uphold a fragile peace agreement despite recent cease-fire violations, diplomats said.

title: Palestinians, After Debate, Decide to Go to Peace Talks
description: With the next round of Middle East peace talks scheduled to start in Moscow on Tuesday, Palestinian leaders ended their debate with a decision to take part in the negotiations.

title: Fast Data-Storage Systems Are EMC's Big Opportunity  BYL>By JOHN MARKOFF
description: For more than a year the computer industry has been eagerly anticipating a ground-breaking new product code-named Iceberg from Storage Technology Inc., the disk-drive maker.

title: Can 4 Magazines Stay in Fashion?
description: Like the shiver of expectation that sweeps through the fashion world at the hint of a new look, Hearst's snapping up of the editor in chief of British Vogue to head Harper's Bazaar has sent a frisson through the fiercely competitive world of fashion magazines.

title: Gloomy Moment For Levy
description: Not every coach can talk about "the most bitter defeat I can remember in 40 years of coaching," because most coaches don't last that long in the business.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Advanced Medical Inc.'s $60 million of convertible subordinated debentures were offered on Friday, priced at par, with a 7 1/4 percent coupon, through Kidder, Peabody & Co. The San Francisco-based company makes infusion systems for the health-care industry. Common Stock * UCC Investors Holding Inc., parent of Uniroyal Chemical Co., Middlebury, Conn., plans to file for $400 million of common stock, plus $300 million of senior notes. * Chicago and North Western Holdings has filed for 8.75 million common shares. The Chicago-based company is the parent of the Chicago & North Western Railroad. Underwriters will be Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette; Goldman, Sachs, and Morgan Stanley. Ratings * Port Authority of New York and New Jersey's $100 million consolidated bonds have been rated AA- by Fitch, which said that rating also applied to $4 billion of similar bonds of the agency. * Pfizer Inc.'s triple-A rating on its senior debt has been affirmed by Standard & Poor's Corp., based on a proposed settlement of claims arising from difficulties with a mechanical artificial heart valve. Pfizer is based in New York.

title: Nothin' but a Hound Dog Idea
description: Early next year, the United States Post Office will issue a stamp for Elvis Presley, the first stamp in the new Fall of Man series, which also may be honoring American trucking with Jimmy Hoffa and American health care with Typhoid Mary.

title: Letters Capture Spirit of the Neediest
description: "I am sorry." Dozens of letters to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund begin with that three-word refrain of sympathy that seems better than any other to capture the spirit of giving in these tough times.

title: I.S.G. Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: Kuwaiti Gave Consistent Account of Atrocities; Retracted Testimony
description: To the Editor:

title: Independence Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Mille Lacs Lake Journal; Minnesota Winter Puts Fishing on Ice
description: Atop the frozen surface of this expansive lake, Ruthie Stowowy dropped two fishing lines into holes through nearly three feet of ice. About 30 minutes later, she pulled in her first catch of the day: a three-pound perch, its yellow scales gleaming as it squirmed in her hand.

title: Dynatronics Laser reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Democrats See Support for Capital Gains Tax Cut
description: The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, said today that Democrats in Congress could support a cut in the capital gains tax if it was part of a generally "fair and progressive tax package."

title: CHRONICLE
description: GRO HARLEM BRUNTLAND, the Prime Minister of Norway; JACQUES DELORS, president of the European Community's executive commission in Brussels; the Cable News Network, and the National Museum of Anthropology and History in Mexico City are the winners of the 1992 Onassis International Prizes, which will be presented in Athens in May. The awards, carrying a stipend of $100,000 each, are given by the Alexander S. Onassis Public Benefit Foundation, which was established by Aristotle Onassis in 1975 to honor his son, who died two years earlier in a plane crash.

title: 'Buy American': Remedy or Tunnel Vision?
description: Intended or not, President Bush's trade mission to Japan has now stirred an emotional wave of "buy American" fervor across the recession-pocked land. But economists and trade experts say the movement is a dubious remedy for the underlying ills of the American economy.

title: American Bank of Connecticut reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Portuguese Flavor Irks Church's Old Guard
description: The street sign in front of St. Casimir's says Pulaski, but the shop windows across from the church say Teixeira's Bakery, Brazil Restaurant and Favo de Mel food store.

title: Rypien Is Most Thankful About One That Got Away
description: Mark Rypien, the Redskins' quarterback, who was chosen as the most valuable player of the Super Bowl tonight, figured that maybe the single finest moment in the most important game of his career came not on any of the 18 passes he threw for 292 yards in Washington's victory over the Bills. Not even on either of the two scoring passes he threw. It came, he said, on an incomplete pass.

title: Going Up the Downhill Slope
description: It was his first World Cup victory of the season, the first after the worst start of his career, a start that prompted many experts to conclude that Marc Girardelli had used up the last of his 99 lives and was on his way to being a former champion.

title: A Crisis Built on Debt; Despite Its Strong Reputation in Retailing, Macy's Choices in the 80's Left It Crippled
description: The formidable Herald Square flagship of R. H. Macy & Company is a New York landmark and one of the world's best-known stores. Yet for all its name recognition and loyal following the 134-year-old retailer has come to the brink of filing for bankruptcy protection.

title: Who (and What) Decides How City Budget Rates
description: WHEN Mayor David N. Dinkins delivered his State of the City address earlier this month, one sentence in the 18th paragraph finally inspired his audience to spontaneous applause: "Bond ratings are important," Mr. Dinkins declared, "but we are judged against a higher standard."

title: BBDO to Assist On Doritos Account
description: Tracy-Locke, which has spent several months working on changing the creative approach of the advertising for Doritos snack chips, has called in an in-house rival, BBDO New York, for assistance. The agency said it had not determined exactly what help it would need.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY A PICTURE OF BIAS

title: George Lucas on Issues, Ideas and Indiana Jones
description: In the lush valley enclave of his Skywalker Ranch, the film maker George Lucas is in the grip of perhaps the riskiest odyssey of his career: a major television series about the young Indiana Jones.

title: First Commercial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
1992 CAMPAIGN: Players; Onetime Insider Adapts To Low-Key Campaign
description: Peggy Connolly, once a consummate Washington insider as spokeswoman for the Democratic National Campaign Committee, left the capital in 1988 right after George Bush's election. She said she believed that a Democrat would not be elected President until the year 2000.

title: Federal Signal Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 2,388,000, or 10 cents a share, which included a gain of $ 2,288,000 on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Oshkosh Truck reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We worked day and night to find a suitable solution and ultimately came to the conclusion that filing for Chapter 11 was best for Macy's future. I am convinced that beginning this rehabilitative process is the best way to protect our valuable franchise." -- EDWARD S. FINKELSTEIN, chairman of Macy's. [ A1:6. ]

title: Health Costs Up 12.1% Last Year, a Study Says
description: Employers' health-care costs rose by 12.1 percent nationwide, to $3,605 per employee last year, or about four times as fast as overall living costs, according to a survey released yesterday. What is more, analysts said the annual increase in 1992 would be higher.

title: New Unit Head At First Boston
description: CS First Boston said yesterday that Robert Diamond had been named president and chief executive officer of CS First Boston Pacific, replacing Allen Wheat, who stepped down to concentrate on the investment banking firm's derivative-products business.

title: Policy Management Systems Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Atlantic Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

The quarter also included a gain of $ 18 million from the sale of assets, and the year included a charge of $ 43 million for the early retirement of debt, and a loss of $ 53 million from an adjustment in accounting.c-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 101 million, or 40 cents a share, on a gain from the settlement with Iran over the 1979 seizure of certain assets, and income of $ 137 million, or 55 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Largely offsetting the gains in the latest quarter was a $ 244 million additional writedown of Phillips' offshore California investments and charges totaling $ 30 million for project cancellations, the shutdown of the Avtel advanced composites facility and work force reductions that took place during the fourth quarter.The company said it also took in the latest fourth quarter a $ 2 million charge for environmental projects, compared with a $ 57 million charge in the year-ago period.Results for 1991 also included gains of $ 33 million from the final settlement of business interruption insurance claims, gains of $ 108 million from asset sales and $ 19 million from the settlement of interest claims concerning federal excise taxes on crude oil.Those gains for 1991 were partly offset by the $ 244 million writedeown of offshore California investments, and by a charge of $ 13 million for environmental projects and $ 30 million for project cancellations, a business shutdown and work force reductions.Phillips said that in 1990, non-operational items increased net income by $ 148 million, partly offset by environmental charges of $ 57 million.In addition, foreign currency transactions resulted in losses of $ 32 million in 1991, compared with gains of $ 30 million, a year ago.Revenue represented total revenues.

title: Loctite Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $ 4,434,000 for restructuring costs.

title: Land and Health Also Erode in Haiti
description: The fields are still green here, but they do not mask the ominous signs that the international economic embargo intended to force a return to democratic rule in Haiti is accelerating land and environmental damage, and threatening already precarious food supplies for the hemisphere's poorest people.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AGS Computers Inc., White Plains, a unit of Nynex Corp., appointed Paul J. Cosgrave president, succeeding A. T. Engkvist, who retired. * ARCO Chemical Co., Newtown Square, Pa., named Ronald R. Remick vice president and treasurer.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Macy's Bankruptcy

title: Kia, of Korea, Plans to Sell Vehicles in U.S
description: The Kia Motors Corporation of South Korea said today that it would develop a dealer network in the United States to start selling subcompact cars and small sport-utility vehicles in 1993.

title: Bills Pack Up and Grumble Off to Buffalo
description: The Bills, having lost their second consecutive Super Bowl on Sunday, headed back to Buffalo today, trying to come to grips with their dismal performance and wondering whether they have what it takes to make it back for a third attempt.

title: Books of The Times; A Telephone Novel Based on an Adult Party Line
description: Vox By Nicholson Baker 165 pages. Random House. $15.

title: Gaseous Envelope
description: A British astronomer has found that the scattering of radio waves caused by turbulent interstellar electrically charged gases, or plasma, is present in areas of the galaxy where it had not been previously proven to exist.

title: Critic's Notebook; The Super Bowl on TV: Too Much Pumping Up?
description: Over the years, the phenomenon has become unsettlingly familiar: Super Bowl turns out to be Super Bloat. That certainly was the case on Sunday. After weeks of publicity hype, the game fizzled to the point where television cameras in the second half were panning to fans in the stands who were either yawning or nodding off. In hindsight, an omen was offered early on by Harry Connick Jr., whose version of the national anthem was laconically determined to prove that anything you can do he can do slower.

title: SETBACK AT POLLS FOR MITTERRAND
description: The governing Socialist Party of President Francois Mitterrand, battered by a weak economy and mired in a leadership crisis, suffered a humiliating defeat in parliamentary and municipal by-elections on Sunday as support for the far-right National Front surged.

title: Tyson Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
Victorious Knicks Get to Travel Home in First
description: The Knicks have had their troubles on the road this season, but not this trip. They have soared and slumped at various times, but suddenly appear unstoppable.

title: Observer; Before Much Longer
description: "Welcome, election fans, to 'Meet the Adulterer,' the Emmy-Award-winning news show that lets Presidential candidates tell their own revolting stories of squalid and sordid conduct with models, actresses, bimbos and --"

title: In Retreat, Supreme Court Limits Scope of '65 Voting Rights Act
description: In an important ruling on the Federal Voting Rights Act, the Supreme Court today adopted a narrow view of the 1965 law and rejected arguments the Bush Administration had put forward on behalf of black elected officials in two Alabama counties.

title: Accounts
description: * Domecq Importers, Old Greenwich, Conn., to Berenter Greenhouse & Webster Advertising, New York, from Deutsch Inc., New York, for its Sauza Tequila and Presidente Brandy lines. A Berenter spokeswoman said that the account has billings of $3 million. * Andrew Jergens Co., Cincinnati, to Lewis & Gace, Fort Lee, N.J., for a new skin-care product. Billings were not disclosed. The assignment includes professional advertising to dermatologists as well as direct marketing to consumers in doctors' offices.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the growth of capitalism in Kazakhstan misattributed the final quotation. It was Dr. Chan Young Bang, an American adviser to the Government, who said: "We do not have a lot of time. Within two years there'll be fresh stagnation, and then big social unrest, unless positive and very radical change can happen."

title: CHRONICLE
description: SUE ELLIOT does not seem to be fazed by the fact that she is engaged to marry BARRY TUCKWELL, whom many consider the world's pre-eminent player of the French horn.

title: Crane Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from cumulative effect of an accounting change of $ 22,341,000.

title: Grumman Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said results for the 1991 year included a $ 46.5 million non-recurring charge from the settlement of claims against the bankrupt Tracor Aviation, Inc., and the release of $ 30.7 million in tax reserves no longer required. Both items were reported in the first quarter.The company said without the one-time charge in the first quarter, 1991 operating income increased 4 percent to $ 235.2 million from $ 226.8 million in 1990. Interest expense dropped 14 percent in 1991, to $ 85.2 million from $ 98.8 million the previous year.

title: Merrill Lynch & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: Revenue represented total revenues.The net revenues for the latest periods totaled $ 1,873,952,000 in the quarter and $ 7,256,501,000 in the year, compared with $ 1,389,884,000 and $ 5,786,916,000 in year-ago periods, respectively.Share earnings are after payment of preferred stock dividends.

title: George Sweazey, 86, Presbyterian Official
description: The Rev. Dr. George E. Sweazey, a senior official of the Presbyterian Church and professor emeritus of homiletics at Princeton Theological Seminary, died on Thursday at the Monroe Village Health Care Center in Jamesburg, N.J., where he lived. He was 86 years old.

title: U.S.-Japan Auto Parts Rift Grows
description: In tones reflecting the increasingly combative exchanges between Japan and the United States, the head of a Japanese auto group said today that it was "incomprehensible" that Detroit had not accepted Tokyo's offer to buy $19 billion more in American-made auto parts. He said top Japanese executives "have no intention" of discussing the issue again with the Big Three.

title: Music in Review
description: New York Festival of Song Renee Weiler Concert Hall Greenwich House Music School

title: Colombian Blood, U.S. Guns
description: On Dec. 16, 20 indigenous peasants, including five women and four children, were murdered as they met to discuss a struggle over land rights in the village of El Nilo in southern Colombia. News reports indicated that the gunmen were drug traffickers who had been seizing land in the region to grow opium poppies to produce heroin.

title: Record Year For Merrill As Net Jumps
description: As if anyone needed yet another sign of how well Wall Street has been doing, Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday reported quarterly earnings of $170.1 million, raising its yearly profits to a record $696.1 million.

title: Advocates of Disabled File Complaint About the Empire State Building
description: Using a wheelchair because of multiple sclerosis, Daniel Robert has never been able to visit the top of the Empire State Building since it meant climbing two flights of steps from the 86th floor.

title: What Courier Must Do To Take the No. 1 Spot
description: JIM COURIER could overtake STEFAN EDBERG and claim the No. 1 spot in the Association of Tennis Professionals ranking if he gets to the final of the Volvo Tennis tournament in San Francisco next week, according to an A.T.P. spokesman.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League CLEVELAND INDIANS -- Agreed to terms with Brook Jacoby, third baseman, on a minor-league contract.

title: Worst-Case Scenario: Bills Lose 3 in a Row
description: All the Buffalo Bills' worst fears turned into reality in Super Bowl XXVI. The Washington Redskins' 37-24 thumping on Sunday was so complete and so embarrassing for the Bills that they left here with what was for them the worst possible scenario: being compared to the Denver Broncos and the Minnesota Vikings as teams that can be counted on to turn Super Bowls into Super Flops.

title: Apple Is Said To Set Price Cuts
description: Apple Computer Inc. will slash prices on some desktop Macintosh computers by 17 to 36 percent next week, the industry newspaper Macweek reported today. Macweek, which attributed its information to anonymous sources, said the cuts would come on various Macintosh II models as well as on the Macintosh LC and the Macintosh Classic II. An Apple spokeswoman said the company had no comment.

title: Baker, Fentress & Co.  reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Latest per share earnings are after $ 1.15 long-term capital gain distribution paid in December 1991.Net income represented net asset value.

title: Bad News for Bush as Poll Shows National Gloom
description: In his State of the Union Message tonight, President Bush will address a nation that is gloomier than it has been in 13 years, more disapproving of his Presidency than ever and increasingly willing to try a Democrat in the White House, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Afraid and Hurt, Young Turn to Clinics
description: The girl had just turned 13 and complained of acne when she came to the adolescent medicine clinic at Oakland Children's Hospital last week.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Health page on Wednesday about sexually transmitted warts referred incompletely to the treatment of infected men. Although the viruses that cause the warts can be impossible to detect, the warts themselves can be detected and treated.

title: St. John's Judge Allows Evidence
description: A New York State judge yesterday denied a defense motion to limit testimony in the trial of a 22-year-old former St. John's University student accused of sodomy and other charges in a sexual attack on a former female student.

title: By Design; Hayride in Paris
description: Paris is off on a hayride. Left behind at the spring couture shows are the usual luxurious trimmings of satin ribbons and lace. Instead, the braids, edgings, fringes and accessories are mostly of straw or raffia. In the sensitive fingers of couture artisans, these materials have been transformed into gilded objects. The prevailing whim is to dip the straw into gold paint.

title: Practicing Acupuncture Made Easy
description: Dr. Doreen Chen first studied acupuncture 40 years ago in rural Chinese villages. She did not press her first silver needle into a patient's skin until her teachers were satisfied that she understood the philosophies of harmony and equilibrium that guided the needle. And she did not receive her license in to practice acupuncture on her own until she had completed a long and rigorous apprenticeship.

title: G.M. Plans Issue Of Class C Stock
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it had filed for $750 million of a new class C preference stock to be sold here and abroad to help strengthen its balance sheet.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Never mind that JODIE FOSTER went to Yale: yesterday she was named 1992 Woman of the Year by the Hasty Pudding Theatricals at Harvard, and she is to be honored with a parade through Harvard Square on Feb. 11.

title: S.E.C. Names Top Economist
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had named Susan Woodward, a former economist for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, to be its chief economist.

title: Briggs & Stratton reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Commodore International Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cyprus Minerals Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe company said during 1991 it recorded a $ 31.8 million after-tax charge for the sale of its talc business and several other miscellaneous accruals.Full year 1990 results after tax writedowns of $ 63.2 million including the Kanawha coal and Tonopah Molybdenum operations.

title: Review/Fashion; In Paris, Diverse Dreams
description: Three Italian designers kicked off the French haute couture openings for spring and summer over the weekend, enhancing the cosmopolitan quality of this city. A fourth, Gianfranco Ferre, led the house of Christian Dior into the fashion fray this afternoon.

title: Amended Charge for Howe
description: Federal prosecutors have decided to amend their misdemeanor charge against Steve Howe, the Yankee pitcher who was arrested near here last month for possession of cocaine. The new charge has come three days before the 33-year-old athlete was to go on trial and will force the trial to be postponed.

title: New York City To Korey, Kay
description: Korey, Kay & Partners in New York has been awarded a widely followed pro-bono assignment to create a marketing theme and an image campaign for New York City. The campaign is scheduled to coincide with the Democratic National Convention and the quincentennial celebration of Columbus's voyage to America.

title: Boy Accuses Schoolmate In Sex Case
description: New York City police and school officials are investigating an incident in which a 9-year-old boy said an 8-year-old boy sexually molested him last week as the two stood in line inside a Bronx school waiting for a bus.

title: Indictment in Taxi Scheme
description: The manager of an organization of taxi owners that for decades provided Election Day services to New York City has been indicted on fraud charges alleging that he billed for work that he did not provide, City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman said yesterday. The man, Herman Sherman, the manager of the Independent Taxi Owners Group, was indicted by a Queens grand jury last week.

title: Dow Edges Up 7.83 and Closes at 3,240.61
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, with blue chips posting small gains while the broader market was weak. Many cautious investors moved to the sidelines in anticipation of the President's State of the Union Message tonight.

title: Palestinians Refuse to Attend Moscow Peace Talks
description: Middle East peace talks opened in Moscow today without a Palestinian delegation.

title: Future Ads Expected to Project 'Business as Usual' Image
description: The decision yesterday by R. H. Macy & Company to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection is not expected to alter its marketing efforts significantly, advertising executives said. But they said they anticipated a tightrope-walking act, in which executives at Macy and its agency must balance the retail chain's short- and long-term needs.

title: Anatomy of Integrated Program For Macs
description: PROGRAMS that can do more than one thing are tempting for many computer users, particularly novices, or even veterans whose demands are relatively light. If you do not need all the features and complications of WordPerfect, dBase and Lotus 1-2-3, but do need to write, keep track of data and manipulate spreadsheets, a so-called integrated program may be just the ticket.

title: Haute Cuisine vs. the Vegetarian Menace
description: To the Editor:

description: New Orchestra of Westchester State University College at Purchase

title: Successor Nominated For Top Unilever Posts
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch food and consumer goods giant, has nominated Michael S. Perry, who oversaw an expansion in cosmetics, to be chairman of its British corporate entity and a vice chairman of its Dutch entity.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Thursday about protests surrounding the French abortion pill RU-486, and a correction in this space on Friday, referred incorrectly to the target of the protests, the Hoechst Celanese Corporation. Horace S. Webb, vice president for communications and public affairs, says Hoechst Celanese in 1985 gave up all rights to market the pill.

title: Consolidated Freightways reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Making Painful Choices on Deformed Fetuses
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: International A3-9 YELTSIN DIAGNOSIS: BUSINESS

title: Around the World With Balloon And Gizmos
description: FOR more than two centuries aeronauts have dreamed of circumnavigating the world in a balloon, the last great aeronautical challenge remaining to be conquered. All the adventurers who previously attempted the daunting 22,000-mile voyage have failed, but this week an American balloon ace, a seasoned aeronautical mechanic and a senior Russian astronaut are completing preparations for the launching of Earthwinds, the most complex and advanced balloon ever built.

title: A Judge Who Often Aids Debtors
description: R. H. Macy & Company will have its day in court in front of one of the favorite judges of lawyers representing bankrupt clients. Judge Burton R. Lifland, the 62-year-old chief judge of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, has a reputation for giving debtors the benefit of most doubts.

title: Disney (Walt) Co. (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chess
description: The apprentices of the sorcerer, Gary Kasparov, have treated him with less respect in the last 12 months than in the previous nine years, when he won every competition he participated in. In Linares, Spain, in February, the world champion had to take second place behind the Ukrainian grandmaster Vasily Ivanchuk. In Amsterdam in May, he tied for third place behind the winners, the grandmasters Valery Salov of Russia and Nigel Short of Britain. And now, in the Reggio Emilia International Tournament, which ended Jan. 6 in northern Italy, he shared second place with the Russian grandmaster Boris Gelfand behind the 23-year-old Indian grandmaster Viswanathan Anand.

title: INSIDE
description: Late Changes on Health Plan

title: Redskins Are Just One Big Happy Family
description: Solid.

title: Store Manager Was Shot
description: The New York City medical examiner has determined that the assistant manager of The Gap Kids store in midtown Manhattan died of a gunshot wound to the head as well as multiple stab wounds to the neck. The 22-year-old victim, Lisa Steinberg, was found bound and gagged Saturday morning in the store at 250 West 57th Street where it was apparent she had been stabbed numerous times with a screwdriver. But an autopsy on Sunday revealed that she had also been shot once in the head, Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the medical examiner, said yesterday.

title: Fox Stole Ratings but Not the Show From CBS
description: A few final notes on Super Bowl XXVI:

title: On My Mind; The Clinton Couple
description: The Clinton couple of Arkansas have presented to the American public a gift and a testing opportunity.

title: Florida Progress reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 2,400,000 for both the quarter and year.c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 15,000,000.

title: An Australian Novelist With a Full-Tilt Pace And Ferocious Humor
description: Peter Carey is proof that a bad party can make a good novel. A few years ago, the Australian writer found himself at a tony social gathering in Sydney, when the subject turned to Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen, the archconservative premier of Queensland, who had decided to run for Prime Minister on a tax-cutting policy.

title: China Reports Freeing 9 Democracy Campaigners
description: China said today that it had recently released nine people who had been held in connection with the Tiananmen democracy movement of 1989.

title: A.N.C. Leader Sees a Threat From Rightists
description: The secretary general of the African National Congress, Cyril Ramaphosa, said today that he took seriously the threat to South Africa from white racial militants who have warned of civil war if a black government comes to power.

title: Court Shifts California's Political Lines
description: In a move that alters the political landscape of California, the State Supreme Court today imposed a new redistricting plan that is widely expected to accelerate Republican gains in the largest state. Political experts say Republicans could take control of the state's huge Congressional delegation this year and possibly both houses of the State Legislature within two to four years.

title: First the Fidgeting, Then the Fame
description: Backstage, the members of the cast are starting to fidget, and for good reason: Final reviews are about to be rendered and championships bestowed for last year's performances, and the curtain is about to rise on the new year's national racing drama.

title: Intergraph Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 5,196,000, or 11 cents a share, on sale of a long-term common stock investment.c-Included gains of $ 753,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter, and $ 2,326,000, or 5 cents a share, in the year, on sale of a long-term common stock investment.

title: Computers Are Distributed Containing Software Virus
description: A personal computer manufacturer has notified its dealers that in December the company accidentally shipped as many as 500 personal computers with a potent computer virus.

title: Donations to Neediest Made in Memory of Others
description: "Please accept this contribution in memory of my niece, Heather Renee Orthmann, who was killed at the age of 25 in an automobile accident last summer," wrote Nan Orthmann Sharp of Bergenfield, N.J., in a note accompanying a $100 donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. "Heather loved to help people! She had spent some summers teaching handicapped children to swim and was studying to be an interpreter for the deaf."

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY GOTTI TRIAL: PLEA TO THE JUDGE

title: Rites of Grief, Signs of Strength
description: The mourners filed silently out of Sacred Heart Basilica, next to the golden dome on the Notre Dame campus. They set out on foot, three and four abreast on paths cleared of last week's snow, across campus and down Notre Dame Avenue to the cemetery that became Meghan Beeler's resting place.

title: Hammer-and-Sickle Falls Out of Fashion in Brazil
description: Drawing back from a 70-year effort to bring Marx to Brazil's masses, the Brazilian Communist Party has voted to drop the hammer and sickle as its symbol and to change its name to the Popular Socialist Party.

title: Leers, Smears and Governor Clinton
description: At times, voters can legitimately ask about a political candidate's financial, sexual or other personal conduct; it can bear on one's capacity for public service. At other times any such inquiry amounts to no more than leers, smears or smug moralizing.

title: RMI Titanium reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included restructuring charge of $ 37,124,000 in the quarter and year.c-Net income

title: Late Changes Are Ordered on Health Budget
description: Top officials at the White House today ordered Richard G. Darman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, to pull back and rewrite crucial provisions of the national health-care plan that was to have been sent to Congress this week as part of President Bush's budget package.

title: Mattel Doll Deal
description: The toy maker Mattel Inc. announced a licensing agreement with Rollerblade Inc. of Minneapolis to market two skating doll lines in 1992, including a Barbie that uses in-line roller skates. "This sport is becoming increasingly popular among children," said Rita Rao, Mattel's executive vice president for marketing. In addition to Rollerblade Barbie and friends, Mattel will create Baby Rollerblade, a 15-inch doll that is supposed to look as if it is skating.

title: Skinner Chavez-Melo, Church Musician, 47
description: Skinner Chavez-Melo, an organist, conductor and composer who was music director at the St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan, died on Saturday at New York Downtown Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Haitians Fleeing Again to U.S. Asylum
description: After a lull of several weeks, hundreds of Haitians have begun fleeing over the last seven days, the Coast Guard said today. More than 1,100 were pulled from the sea today, a record daily number.

title: Safeco Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 29,791,000, or 47 cents a share, on a tax benefit, in the quarter and year.

title: These Tax Cuts Stunt Growth
description: To judge by advance leaks to reporters, the "growth" tax cuts that President Bush will announce in his State of the Union address tonight and his budget tomorrow will promote precious little growth. Taken individually, they range from inconsequential to destructive. Taken together, they would put billions into undeserving pockets -- and wreck the tax code.

title: Crawford & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In the Retail Desert, Fortunoff Is Planting a Mall on L.I.
description: Macy's, 47th Street Photo and other big-name retailers are in various stages of bankruptcy, but Alan Fortunoff is undaunted. He is putting his family's housewares and jewelry business on the line with plans to build a $194 million shopping center here.

title: 2d Sayville Fire in 8 Days Kills 2 in Business District
description: A fire in a row of 19th-century buildings killed two men in the genteel business district of this South Shore hamlet today and is terrifying shopkeepers and residents who fear the unseen hand of an arsonist.

title: Crompton & Knowles reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
Erhardt Joins Steelers
description: RON ERHARDT, the New York Giants' assistant head coach in charge of the offense last season, was named offensive coordinator of the Steelers yesterday. (AP)

title: Making Painful Choices on Deformed Fetuses; For Honest Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Painful Choices on Deformed Fetuses; What Declaration Says
description: To the Editor:

title: Careers; Schooling Engineers in Environment
description: TOMORROW'S engineers -- and today's as well -- must be grounded in environmental science, says Dr. George S. Ansell, president of the Colorado School of Mines, in Golden, Colo. Two reasons he cited were the growing contamination of the environment and the need for a broader education to assure jobs.

title: Elizabeth Walters, 86, An Author of Manuals
description: Elizabeth Ogg Walters, the author of many public affairs studies, died on Jan. 14 at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. She was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ARCO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 323 million gain from cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes, and $ 185 million in after-tax gains resulting from an accident settlement and asset sales. These gains were partially offset by net charges totaling about $ 400 million after tax, which consisted primarily of provisions for tax and royalty issues and charges for future environmental remediation costs.The latest year's results included about $ 295 million after tax in net charges related primarily to personnel reductions and property sales and writedowns.Share earnings for fiscal 1990 reflects the impact of adoption of SFAS 96 on earnings per share was $ 1.95.

title: Cordis Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
St. Paul Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Tyson Stays Silent; His Supporters Don't
description: The television lights abruptly fired up and, at 8:54 o'clock here this morning, Mike Tyson came striding through the revolving door of the City-County Building.

title: Cascade Shares Were Shifted
description: Three days before Victor G. Incendy, the former chairman of Cascade International Inc., disappeared in November, he gave 8.3 million shares in the company to the interim chairman's law firm.

title: Ithaca Bancorp Search
description: Ithaca Bancorp said Arthur M. Pivirotto, its president and chief executive, was considering retiring from all his positions with the company and its Citizens Savings Bank unit. The company has begun a search for Mr. Pivirotto's successor and expects the management change to be made by the end of February, Victor Del Rosso, Ithaca's chairman, said in a statement. Mr. Pivirotto has been president and chief executive of Citizens Savings, Ithaca's sole unit, since 1983. He is also a director of Ithaca and Citizens Savings.

title: G.M. to Close High-Tech Parts Factory
description: General Motors' "factory of the future" will become part of the auto maker's past in August, when it plans to close the Saginaw, Mich., plant.

title: 61 Acts of Bias: One Fuse Lights Many Different Explosions
description: Since Jan. 6, when a gang of white youths yelling racial epithets squirted white sneaker polish on two black children in the Bronx, bias incidents have rained down hard and heavy in New York City.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Limits Placed on Union Organizers on Employers' Property
description: The Supreme Court today sharply limited the ability of labor union organizers to go onto an employer's property to distribute literature or urge workers to join the union.

title: Water-Meter Service Files for Bankruptcy
description: The Vanguard Meter Service Inc., which dominated New York City's water-meter installation program until it was charged with fraud, filed for bankruptcy reorganization last week, citing $21 million in liabilities against $17 million in assets.

title: Miscellany
description: * CBS and The New York Times Company Women's Magazines have agreed to co-sponsor a 25-market shopping-mall tour next year that will include personal appearances by Times magazine editors and stars of CBS programs. As part of the promotional arrangement, the first between a big network and a leading magazine publisher, advertisers who commit to combined purchases with the two companies will be prominently featured in the tour.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Citibank, New York, a unit of Citicorp, selected an automation vendor, ISC-Bunker Ramo, a wholly owned unit of Olivetti, to install bank-branch automation systems nationwide. * Edison Brothers Stores Inc., St. Louis, a retail concern, reached an agreement to purchase the 39-store chain of Harry's clothing stores for big and tall men.

title: Review/Dance; Soloist Bounds From Film With Boundless Ambiguity
description: A sketch can be as vivid as a mural. Yancey Dance Theater demonstrated that Sunday afternoon at the Ohio Theater in SoHo when it presented two mixed-media works by Leslie Yancey. A brief piece for a solo dancer was more persuasive than a long work for a cast of 13.

title: Witness in Teaneck Case Disputes Police Account
description: A major state witness in the manslaughter trial of a Teaneck police officer, Gary Spath, finished two days of testimony today by stating that Phillip Pannell, a black teen-ager, had his hands raised when the officer fatally shot him in the back.

title: German Film Makers Express Support for 'Europa'
description: Many of Germany's leading film makers, citing "the special responsibility the past imposes upon us," have joined a protest against the German Export Film Union's decision not to submit "Europa, Europa" for Academy Award consideration as best foreign film.

title: Catching Up With Nate, Aces and a Penny Fund
description: AS we pass this columnist's first anniversary in Our Towns, Nate is enjoying retirement. Lisa Hedley's cinema is doing nicely; so is the baby. The Little League dads couldn't finish the new ball field. But the Greenwich school refurbishing is beautiful. The Philosophy Soirees are on hiatus, which is New Jersey for suspended. Frank Sharkey and Dwayne Franks returned to work after the shootings. The Piermont Library's Penny Fund has crept into four figures. And Edna W. Newman is back at work, no thanks to the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Investor Takes Over As Head of L.A. Gear
description: No one expected Stanley P. Gold to be a passive investor when he bought 34 percent of L.A. Gear Inc. last year for an investment fund he runs for Roy E. Disney. So it came as no surprise last weekend when Mr. Gold became the new chairman and chief executive of the financially troubled footwear company, replacing L.A. Gear's co-founder and chairman, Robert S. Greenberg.

title: Newell Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1990 year's share earnings included a non-recurring gain of 9 cents a share from the sale of securities ins the 1990 first quarter.

title: Detroit Edison reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lyondell Petrochem reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dinkins Plans New Taxes And Job Cuts
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins will propose more big cuts in spending for long-term construction projects, new taxes on gasoline and automobiles, higher income taxes on commuters and a four-year freeze in property tax rates when he presents his preliminary budget for New York City on Thursday, city officials said yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: Giraffe Hypertension

title: Chapter Starting at Macy's, Ending at Federated
description: The bankruptcy filing by R. H. Macy & Company yesterday came just a week before Federated Department Stores Inc., which owns Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus, Rich's and other department stores, is expected to emerge from bankruptcy protection after two years.

title: Brazil Loan Is Expected
description: The International Monetary Fund is expected to approve a $2 billion loan for Brazil on Wednesaday and to support President Fernando Collor de Mello's economic program, Government officials and diplomats said.

title: Butler Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 4 million related to the consolidation of the company's vistawall and naturalite architectural products businessness.c-Net income

title: Security Chief At City College Is Reassigned
description: The security director of the City College of New York was relieved of his duties yesterday for his role at a celebrity basketball game last month at which nine people were killed in a deadly crush, City University officials said.

title: Treasuries Steady in a Light Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in slow trading yesterday, as credit market participants marked time before a number of important events are played out over the next week to 10 days.

title: New York City Schools Can't Afford Any More Budget Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: Unocal Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe latest periods included a $ 62 million after-tax writedown for costs incurred on capital construction projects that were canceled or revised and $ 31 million in after-tax earnings from the sale of company's southeastern U.S. marketing inventories.There were additional $ 5 million in miscellaneous writedowns in the latest quarter and year.Full year 1990's results included a $ 132 million gain from the sale of the company's Norwegian oil and gas interests and $ 95 million in deferred income tax benefits related to cost depletion.The year-ago periods also included an $ 80 million after-tax loss related to an investment writedown.The revenue for the latest periods included consumer excise taxes of $ 257 million in the quarter and $ 1,050,000,000 in the year, compared with $ 233 million and $ 863 million in the year-ago periods, respectively./* //* //* //* //* //* //*

title: Once Again, the Taxi Industry Is Up for Review
description: Like his immediate predecessor, Mayor David N. Dinkins has decided to take on one of New York City's more intractable problems: making order out of the fragmented, even chaotic taxicab industry.

title: Ambac Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cheap Insurance for Hard Disks
description: A HARD disk drive is never more than one second away from disaster. A power fluctuation, a computer virus, a faulty circuit, a corrupted file, a hard knock on the desk, a burglar, an infestation of gremlins; any one of them can render your hard disk as useless as a stone, sending data into oblivion.

title: Armstrong World Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,200,000 and $ 3,800,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary charge of $ 8,200,000 for the quarter and $ 8,600,000 for the year.c-Net incomed-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,000,000 and $ 4,300,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary charge of $ 1,300,000 for the quarter and $ 9,100,000 for the year, and the year also included a gain of $ 8 million, or 20 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes.The company said the extraordinary items in 1991 and 1990 represent a provision for losses on disposition of discontinued businesses.The company also said it had a pretax restructuring charge on its continuing operations totaling $ 13.1 million in the latest year. Last year, the company had a pretax gain on continuing operations of $ 33.5 million, which included restructuring charges of $ 6.5 million, other charges totaling $ 20.4 million, and a gain on sale of woodlands of $ 60.4 million.

title: Pope & Talbot reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included after-tax charges of $ 2.1 million related to a pending sale of an Aiken, S.C., building used in the manufacturing of diapers, writeoff of two tissue machines at two Wisconsin paper mills, and other smaller items. It also included after-tax charge of about $ 900,000 related to Adoption of Financial Accounting Standard (F.A.S.) No. 106, which deals with accounting for post-retirement health-care benefits.c-After an extraordinary charge of $ 6,467,000 reflecting F.A.S. 106 liabilities related to years prior to 1991. title: A 'Lab Mouse' of Coral May Be Several Species
description: A COMMONLY studied species of coral, the "lab mouse" of marine biology, has been found to be three species rather than one, according to a new study.

title: In a Speech, President Returns to Religious Themes
description: Reviving social and religious themes that are seldom heard in his oratory except in election years, President Bush today called for voluntary prayer in schools, pledged to curtail "the decline of the American family" and cited the teachings of Jesus Christ as the moral force behind the Persian Gulf war.

title: Slim Pickings and Hope at Lafayette High
description: Insurrection was brewing one recent afternoon in a first-floor corridor at Lafayette High on Benson Avenue on the edge of Bensonhurst in Brooklyn. Three starting players from Coach Ira Levine's basketball team cornered Kevin Meyers, the assistant coach and academic tutor. Present were Hardin Desire, Lafayette's best all-round player; Tony Rexha, a streaky long-range shooter, and Kareem Sims, a bruising forward.

title: President Puts Final Touches On State of Union Message
description: President Bush today began final preparations for his State of the Union Message to Congress on Tuesday night, reviewing final drafts of the speech and delivering the first of two dress-rehearsal readings to aides in a theater in the East Wing of the White House.

title: Gotti Trial Judge Is Urged To Limit Cross-Examining
description: Prosecutors in John Gotti's racketeering trial urged the judge yesterday to limit the defense's ability to cross-examine three former high-ranking mob figures about murders they had committed.

title: Philadelphia Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included the writeoff of $ 1.18 a share for disallowances made by the Public Utility Commission in the Limerick unit No. 2 rate order; a charge of 70 cents a share associated with the company's early retirement program; and a gain of 51 cents a share due to an accounting change to recognize sales and revenues on a service-rendered basis rather than on an as-billed basis.

title: Analog Devices In Hewlett Tie
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company and Analog Devices Inc. said today that they had formed an alliance to jointly develop mixed-signal semiconductors. Such chips combine digital and analog processing on a single chip, and are increasingly used in automobiles, telecommunications and consumer electronic equipment.

title: Review/City Ballet; Balanchine Meets Mozart in 'Divertimento No. 15'
description: George Balanchine meets Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart in "Divertimento No. 15," and the audience comes away knowing each a good deal better. The ballet, presented by the New York City Ballet in a richly satisfying performance on Saturday afternoon, is essentially about the good manners and vital graciousness of the world of Mozart's music. It is also a prime example of the sensitivity to music that shaped much of Balanchine's choreography. And almost everyone in the cast gets a chance to shine.

title: People
description: * John B. Adams has been promoted to president, from executive vice president, at the Martin Agency, Richmond. He succeeds Donald R. Just, who resigned.

title: In West Bank Town, Curfew Deepens Resentment
description: Living every night under military curfew, Saleh Abdel-Jawad says, means that seemingly small decisions can sometimes loom large.

title: 2 Elections Today For Assembly Seats
description: Special elections for two State Assembly seats are being held today in districts in Brooklyn and Queens.

title: G.M. Unit Settles Mortgage Escrow Suit
description: One of the country's largest mortgage lenders settled a Federal lawsuit yesterday by agreeing to refund tens of millions of dollars to hundreds of thousands of homeowners who officials said had been forced to pay excessive amounts into escrow accounts.

title: Killing Casts a Rare Light On Gay Life in Suburbia
description: Nobody at Pal Joey's wanted to talk much about Henry Marquez, the dark-haired Texas dreamer who loved old cars, country music and Hamptons beaches. At the gay bar, where one would expect outrage at a gay-bashing episode that the police said led to Mr. Marquez's death, the silence instead ran cold, immutable and deep.

title: Hartford Steam Boiler reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cabot Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 5,509,000, or 23 cents a share.The company said it benefited from a $ 1.8 million, or 10 cents a share, gain in the 1991 quarter on the early redemtion of the remaining 10,000 shares of participating preferred stock. The company also benefited from a gain of $ 1.4 million, or 8 cents a share, on the sale of a minority interest in a business in Portugal.

title: Commercials Offer a Fairly Ho-hum Bowl
description: Super Bowl XXVI may have turned out super for the Washington Redskins, but as for the commercials, it was a Satisfactory Bowl, maybe merely an Adequate Bowl, at best.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 20 about the political crisis in Haiti referred incorrectly in some editions to the size of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide's election victory 13 months ago. He won with more than two-thirds of the vote.

title: U.N. Team in Baghdad Jostled as Police Watch
description: Three members of a United Nations Inspection team in Iraq were confronted by 40 demonstrators in the lobby of the Sheraton Hotel Baghdad today as Iraqi policemen stood by and did not intervene, United Nations officials said.

title: Bridge
description: It is well-known, in theory, that if a partnership has a fit in two suits the one that is divided evenly may be more productive. A 4-4 fit, for example, may be more desirable than 5-3, or 5-4, or 6-3, or 6-4, because the long suit can provide discards. But there are many exceptions, and the right time for the 4-4 is hard to spot in practice.

title: Patterns
description: Badgley Mischka Acquired

title: Review/Theater; 'Crazy He Calls Me': Well Yes, He Does
description: At first "Crazy He Calls Me," a new two-character play by Abraham Tetenbaum at the Walter Kerr Theater, seems like just another boy-meets-girl, girl-helps-boy-masturbate romantic comedy.

title: Schering-Plough reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Yeltsin, Out of Sight Again, Prompts Anxiety and Rumor
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia made another characteristically abrupt retreat from public life today, this time stirring a sense of mystery and diplomatic risk on the eve of the Middle East conference here of leading nations whose economic aid he has been courting.

title: To End Terrorism, Punish Its Sponsors
description: The United Nations has served notice to Libya, Iran, Syria and other promoters of terror that the hostage crisis is over for good.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats; CLINTON ATTEMPTS TO IGNORE RUMORS
description: Gov. Bill Clinton started off his day on a sober note, with a prayer delivered by a Mississippi preacher who sought divine intervention for the health of the Arkansas Governor's Presidential campaign.

title: Florio's Budget Plan Charts Collision Course With G.O.P.
description: The Florio administration unveiled a budget today that counts on a turnaround in the economy, a substantial reduction in state payments for pensions, and as-yet-unapproved Federal Medicaid payments to bring it into balance. It also counts on sales tax revenues that the Republicans, who control both houses of the Legislature, have vowed to cut.

title: Setback for Walker
description: KENNY WALKER, a former Knick, injured his Achilles' tendon in a Spanish league game Sunday and is expected to miss the rest of the season.

title: New York City Slips in Survey on Why Businesses Leave
description: On the two issues that most affect business decisions to relocate, New York City's performance is significantly worse than it was five years ago, a survey of city business leaders has found.

title: Rollins Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Du Pont Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: The 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week; For the Front-Runners, Crucial Days Are Here
description: Pace-setters often fade in the stretch. It happens to horses, and it happens to politicians. So this week, which should show something about the staying power of the presumed front-runners in the New Hampshire primary, could turn out to be highly significant.

title: Thomas J. Mackell Is Dead at 77; Former Queens District Attorney
description: Thomas J. Mackell, who resigned as the Queens District Attorney in 1973 after he was indicted on charges of hindering prosecution in a $4.4 million get-rich-quick scheme, died yesterday at his son's home in Douglaston Manor, Queens. He was 77 years old and lived in Douglaston Manor.

title: Swift Gets 3-Year Pact
description: Pitcher BILL SWIFT agreed to a $7.95 million, three-year contract with San Francisco yesterday, pitcher TERRY MULHOLLAND agreed to a one-year contract with Philadelphia and outfielder GARY THURMAN agreed to a one-year deal with Kansas City.

title: Applied Biosystems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Net loss and included a first quarter $ 5 million charge for facilitites relocation.

title: How to Use Debt to Save Russian Forests
description: To the Editor:

title: Greenstone Roberts To Buy Ackerman
description: Greenstone Roberts Advertising, the largest advertising agency on Long Island, yesterday announced its fourth acquisition in the last 10 months.

title: Market Place; Win or Lose, Buyouts Do It Big
description: The bankruptcy filing of R. H. Macy & Company represents yet another leveraged buyout gone bad. But while the list of leveraged failures is long, the list of leveraged successes is also substantial.

title: MDU Resources Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 6.8 million, or 36 cents a share, after-tax effect of an absorption of certain gas supply contract settlement costs.

title: A Brain Cell Surprise: Genes Don't Set Function
description: YOUNG nerve cells can wander far greater distances across the growing brain than anyone previously imagined, two scientists have found. And once the neurons have settled into a particular neighborhood, they learn what they are meant to do from signals that surround them, rather than from an innate genetic program, the researchers said.

title: Potlatch Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
To Stop the Cable Gouging
description: Transmission consent. Exclusive contracts. "12-12-12" broadcast rules. The fierce debate over whether to reregulate the cable TV industry employs an arcane terminology that few cable customers understand. What many customers do understand, all too well, is that they've been socked with unconscionable price hikes and wretched service ever since 1984, when Congress freed cable operators from local regulation.

title: Review/Music; Image of Death Opens Schubertiade Festival
description: In Hermann Prey's haunting performance of the most famous of Schubert's lieder, "Erlkonig," at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night, accompanied by the pianist Leonard Hokanson, there seemed no separation of the singer from the song. By carefully shaping his now considerably darkened baritone, Mr. Prey seemed to change vocal masks from verse to verse. One moment his singing was a sort of heightened speech in the lowest register, the father assuring the feverish child that his visions of the devilish Erlking are just streaks of mist in the night. The next moment Mr. Prey was singing in mock innocence, insinuating, coaxing, seeming to be the voice of the Erlking himself, tempting the child with visions of dance and song and flowers.

title: Invitation for Johnson
description: Basketball Australia said today that it had invited MAGIC JOHNSON to serve as captain of a United States all-star team in a pre-Olympic tournament in July against the country's national team.

title: Experts Say Logging Of Vast Siberian Forest Could Foster Warming
description: THE forests of the Amazon and other tropical regions have been getting attention for some time, and understandably so. They are home to a disproportionate share of the world's living species, they absorb huge amounts of atmospheric carbon dioxide that would otherwise exert a big heating effect on the earth's climate and they are rapidly being destroyed.
