description: b-Net loss

title: N.H.L. Suspends Jagr
description: JAROMIR JAGR, the Penguins' all-star forward, was suspended by the National Hockey League yesterday for 10 games for skating into Referee RON HOGGARTH in the final minute of Pittsburgh's 6-4 loss to Washington Capitals on Sunday.

title: Music in Review
description: Benita Valente and Tatiana Troyanos Alice Tully Hall

title: Sally Mugabe, Zimbabwe President's Wife, 60
description: Sally Mugabe, an anti-colonialist and the wife of President Robert Mugabe, died Monday. She was 60 years old and had suffered from a kidney disease, the Government announced.

title: Betz Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Husband in Triangle Tells Of His Pursuit by Ex-Lover
description: The man who was at the center of an ill-fated love triangle involving Carolyn Warmus today described how Ms. Warmus continued to pursue him after his wife's death despite his refusal to see her.

title: Business Scene; Moonlighting In Moscow
description: A CARDIOLOGIST sees private patients to supplement his salary from a full-time hospital job, which pays him only 2,000 rubles a month, or $10. An office worker, who could afford to buy a small car two years ago, now cruises the streets in it, picking up taxi fares -- a growing freelance activity. And a woman sells plastic bags for 3 rubles apiece to shoppers leaving a high-priced farmer's market with fresh food in their arms. She had purchased the bags for less than half that price by standing in line at a state store.

title: MACY'S ASKS COURT TO PROVIDE SHIELD AGAINST CREDITORS
description: R. H. Macy & Company, the proud retail business whose executives confidently took on billions in debt in the late 1980's, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, finally admitting defeat in its bruising battle with creditors and the deteriorating economy.

title: This Time, Connecticut's Defense Is Much Too Tough for Villanova
description: Chris Smith, Connecticut's leading scorer and all-round main man this season, failed to score a field goal tonight, going 0 for 8 from the floor. It made little difference.

title: Stocks Gain in Tokyo
description: Stock prices rose in Tokyo today. At the end of the afternoon trading session, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 383.41 points, or 1.83 percent, to 21,390.52. On Monday, the index lost 65.04 points.

title: Profit Up 47% At Grumman
description: The Grumman Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter income rose 47 percent, reflecting stringent cost controls and improved cash management.

title: Carter Hawley To Merge Units
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. said it was consolidating two groups within its Broadway division, resulting in the elimination of 240 jobs. The merchandising, sales promotion and administrative functions of the Broadway Southwest unit will be consolidated into the Broadway Southern California division.

title: Five Jurors Chosen as Tyson Trial Begins
description: In the left corner of Courtroom 4 today, Mike Tyson, former heavyweight champion of the world, watched as two teams of lawyers began the tedious process of choosing the 12 Marion County citizens who will determine his fate.

title: State of Union On TV Tonight
description: The State of the Union Message and the Democratic response will be broadcast live on the three major networks and on PBS, CNN and C-Span tonight at 9 o'clock.

title: Montreal Journal; Have the Quebecers Gone Soft? (Just Ask Miami)
description: From the earliest days of French settlement in the 17th century, Quebec has taken a stubborn pride in its winters. Even Voltaire, dismissing Quebec as "a few acres of snow" after France lost the territory to British conquest in 1759, inadvertently contributed to the legend Quebecers have built of themselves as a people who have thrived in the face of bitter chills and blizzards.

title: Sports of The Times; Of Geniuses, Snowshoes And Football
description: THE question came up in a news conference earlier in the football week about winning The Big One. In sporting terms, that means, as Humpty Dumpty said, exactly what the speaker chooses it to mean -- neither more nor less.

title: Key Rates
Fined for Roughness
description: Separate referee-bumping incidents on Saturday night resulted in fines and one-game suspensions imposed yesterday by the National Basketball Association against Nets assistant coach TOM NEWELL and Houston Rockets guard VERNON MAXWELL.

title: Disney Earnings Up by 22%
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that its profits improved 22 percent in the most recent quarter, as several lucrative movies compensated for weak attendance at the company's theme parks.

title: Drug-Resistant TB Makes U.S. Rethink Elimination Program
description: LESS than three years after Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, set 2010 as the target for eliminating tuberculosis in the United States, the resurgent disease is out of control in this country.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Two years ago, a team of Olympic and collegiate women basketball players beat a team of Congressmen by 28 points; last year, the women beat the legislators by seven points. So it is with a certain degree of optimism that 10 Congressmen face the game they are to play next Wednesday in Washington to kick off the 1992 National Girls and Women in Sports Day sponsored by the Women's Sports Foundation.

title: Profits Fall For ARCO And Phillips
description: ARCO and the Phillips Petroleum Company reported sharply lower earnings today for the fourth quarter, steeper declines than oil companies with broader international operations like Exxon, Mobil and Texaco have reported.

title: Pedestrian Killed by Train
description: A man was struck and killed by a shore-bound New Jersey Transit train tonight, a transit official said. The accident delayed rush-hour trains up to one hour. The man was killed instantly when the train hit him at 5:50 P.M. on the North Jersey Coast Line tracks near Fulton Street, just west of the Woodbridge station, said Rosemary Sheridan, a spokeswoman for New Jersey Transit. The name of the victim was not immediately available, and it was unclear whether he was crossing or walking along the tracks when he was hit.

title: Yankees Are Looking At Alan Anderson
description: The Yankees have apparently decided that the quickest way to solve their pitching woes is by adding free agents because they expressed interest in Alan Anderson last week after having already made an initial contract offer to Eric King.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L. Bruins Nip North Stars, 3-2 Vladimir Ruzicka's sixth goal in seven games, a slap shot from the top of the right circle with 3 minutes 6 seconds left in the game, gave the Boston Bruins a 3-2 home victory over the Minnesota North Stars last night. Minnesota had rallied from a 2-0 deficit to tie the game with 11:14 left on goals by Mike Craig and Basil McRae in a span of 1:50. (AP) TENNIS This Time, She Wins Jennifer Capriati saved two match points to defeat Gabriela Sabatini, 6-3, 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-4), yesterday in an exhibition in Hong Kong. Last week when it counted, Capriati lost to Sabatini in the quarterfinals of the Australian Open. In another match, Yayuk Basuki beat Lori McNeil, 6-1, 1-6, 6-3. (AP) Seeded Players Win: The only two seeded players in action, No. 4 Veronika Martinek of Czechoslovakia and No. 7 Susan Sloane-Lundy of Lexington, Ky., won their first-round matches at the Nutri-Metrics Classic in Auckland, New Zealand. Martinek outlasted Kathy Rinaldi of Amelia Island, Fla., 7-6 (7-2), 4-6, 6-4, and Sloane-Lundy breezed to a 6-2, 6-2 victory over Clare Wood of Britain.(AP) HORSE RACING A 'Rowdy' Victory Rowdy Regal took a 1 1/2-length victory yesterday in Aqueduct's $47,000 Time for a Change purse for horses 4 years old and up. Patricia H. Thompson's horse carried 115 pounds and was ridden by Herb McCauley. Island Edition ran second, 8 1/2 lengths ahead of Watamotel. Rowdy Regal covered the mile and a sixteenth in 1:45 2/5 and paid $7.40 for $2 to win. (AP)

title: Israeli Government Survives No-Confidence Vote
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Government survived a string of no-confidence votes in Parliament today, overcoming its first such challenge since two small, right-wing parties defected from the governing coalition last week, stripping it of a majority.

title: Reality Spoiled Merchant's Dream
description: Edward S. Finkelstein tried everything to avoid bankruptcy -- catchy advertising, sales, cajoling suppliers, tapping his circle of wealthy friends to stump up more cash. But in the end, there was nothing the 66-year-old chairman of R. H. Macy & Company, who was once hailed as a marketing miracle worker, could do to keep his debt-laden empire afloat.

title: J.P. Morgan Is BT Customer
description: BT, formerly British Telecommunications, announced yesterday that J. P. Morgan & Company, the huge financial services company, had become a customer for telecommunications services worth $20 million over the next five years.

title: Instanter Journal; What Water Hid, Drought Reveals
description: Frank J. Nitsche sat on the stump of an apple tree, which 66 years ago had shaded his family's home here in what is now a ghost town 100 miles southeast of Erie.

title: Premark International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Included charges of $ 25.3 million related to restructuring and $ 11.9 million from settlement of lawusits.

title: Two Promotions At Leo Burnett
description: In a move to consolidate the chain of command at its American and international units, the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago has named two executives to oversee all client-service and business operations.

title: Shamans and Scientists Seek Cures in Plants
description: FOR ages, traditional remedies derived from plants were the primary form of medical care for the world's people, and for three-quarters of the global population they still are.

title: Ferro Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included restructuring charge of $ 31.7 million.c-Net lossd-Included litigation settlement charge of 41 cents a share for both the quarter and year.

title: Varian Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
Maxim Integrated Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Allegheny Ludlum reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
United Water Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trees That Yield a Drug For Cancer Are Wasted
description: Nearly a year after the Government recognized the Pacific yew as the most valuable tree in American forests because it yields a rare cancer-fighting drug, the precious bark is still being burned as scrap and discarded to rot on the forest floor in wasteful logging operations in the Northwest.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday comparing the R. H. Macy & Company bankruptcy filing with several others misstated the time elapsed since a filing by Revco D.S. Inc., the drugstore chain. It occurred in 1988. The article also referred incorrectly to the bankruptcy plan of the Campeau Corporation. That plan has no relationship to the bankruptcy proceedings of Federated Department Stores Inc., and when Federated emerges from bankruptcy it will have no ties to Campeau, its former parent.

title: Bias Unit Reviewing a Letter to Dinkins
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins has received a letter that includes racist slurs and threats against him and his family, and the police have classified the correspondence as a bias incident, the police said yesterday. The bias unit is investigating.

title: Brinker International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Stolt Tankers & Terminals (Holdings) S.A. (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included amortization of deferred gains of $ 400,000, 1 cent a share, from prior year sale of ships.c-Included amortization of deferred gains of $ 2.1 million from prior year sale of ships and a loss of $ 1.5 million from the scrapping of a ship. The net gain from the two items is $ 600,000, or 2 cents a share.d-Included gains from the sale of ships of $ 11.7 million, or 44 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 32.3 million, or $ 1.20 a share, in the year.

title: Alaska Air Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Fashion; For Men From Klein: Topcoats to Bottoms
description: FOR the finale of Calvin Klein's men's fashion show Monday, the models came out in their skivvies.

title: Micros Systems Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is a majority owned unit of Westinghouse Electric Corp.

title: FirstMiss Gold Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Friends of Victim Testify In Teaneck Officer Trial
description: The prosecution rested its case this morning in the manslaughter trial of a Teaneck police officer accused of killing a 16-year-old youth.

title: Profits Rise 19.8% at Merck; Warner-Lambert Has Loss
description: In a case of good and not-so-good news in the pharmaceutical industry yesterday, Merck & Company added to its string of double-digit earnings gains in the final quarter of 1991, while the Warner-Lambert Company reported losses because of previously announced restructuring and accounting charges.

title: Wicor Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 5.6 million in the quarter and $ 5.5 million in the year.

title: New York Law on Auto Rentals Needs Easing
description: To the Editor:

title: Arbor Capital reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Included other income items totaling $ 635,000.c-Included other income items totaling $ 1,587,000.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Metro-Richelieu Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Dinkins Aides Fear Cuts In Construction Spending
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins's latest proposals for cutting New York City's capital budget for construction took his own city agency heads by surprise when City Hall announced them on Monday, and yesterday many commissioners were still scrambling to figure out what the cuts would mean.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Campaign; After Hoopla, a Repositioning, Not a Call to Arms
description: Billed for weeks by the White House as the kickoff to his re-election campaign, President Bush's State of the Union Message tonight was, by extension, also intended to begin his comeback from an astonishing tumble in the public opinion polls.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAING: Media; Low-Key Tsongas Tries New, Louder Approach
description: At first, Paul E. Tsongas hoped his message alone would carry him through in his drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Mr. Tsongas, the diffident former Senator from Massachusetts, refused to be packaged by consultants like some other candidates.

title: Wine Talk
description: A DOZEN or so years ago, when Alex Hargrave began to produce first-quality white wines on the North Fork of Long Island, he took his success in stride and told anyone who asked, "What I really want to do is make great red wine."

title: Justin Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations (which resulted from sale of unit) of $ 10,359,000, or $ 1.18 a share, for the quarter and $ 10,780,000, or $ 1.23 a share, for the year.c-Included income of $ 110,000, or 1 cent a share, and a loss of $ 283,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.Year-ago results are restated to present results of unit as discontinued operations.

title: Warner-Lambert Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included after-tax non-recurring charges of $ 418 million in the quarter and year, and the year also included an after-tax charge of $ 106 million from an accounting changec-Net income

title: Ukrainians, Rich in Rubles, Hunt Bargains Next Door
description: Moldovans are alternately worried and fatalistic about prices that have multiplied tenfold, thirtyfold, even a hundredfold since the beginning of the year.

title: Scripps (E.W.) Co. (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 12 million charge associated with settlement of litigation involving its Sacramento cable television system.c-Included a $ 36.4 million charge related to an agreement to terminate its Knoxville joint operating agency.

title: Playboy Enterprises Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $ 497,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 871,000, or 5 cents a share, in the 6 months.c-After tax credits of $ 884,000, or 5 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 1,204,000, or 7 cents a share, in the 6 months.

title: Witco Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflected income taxes that were at a lower rate in the latest quarter due to the utilization of foreign tax credit carryforwards.

title: Judge Upholds Ban on Tuna
description: A Federal judge has refused to reverse his earlier decision tha, starting on Thursday will suspend imports of yellowfin tuna from countries that continue buying the fish from Mexico, Venezuela, and Vanuatu in the Pacific Ocean.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We are going to lift this nation out of hard times inch by inch and day by day, and those who would stop us had better step aside. Because I look at hard times and I make this vow: This will not stand." -- PRESIDENT BUSH. [ A17:5. ]

title: Ball Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter's share earnings was a loss of 2 cents a share and it included an after-tax charge of 26 cents a share for costs related to an attempted acquisition.

title: Broker Loses $1.27 Million In Arbitration
description: In an unusually large arbitration settlement, a West Virginia investor has won a $1.27 million award against Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. and a former broker at the firm for what he charged was fraud, unsuitable trading and violation of exchange rules.

title: Israel Warned Again on Loans
description: Leaders of an American Jewish group have stirred controversy among some Israelis by advising Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir that he cannot expect housing-loan guarantees from Washington if he continues to settle Jews in the occupied territories.

title: Another Furor Over a Benetton Ad
description: In what has become a familiar series of events, the Italian clothing company Benetton has created a provocative print advertisement; many people are furious about it, and the ensuing furor is generating copious media coverage.

title: First Mississippi reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: If You Don't Taste as You Cook, None of the Below Will Help
description: THE vegetable soup had been cooking for two days, but it was still missing something. The doorbell was ringing. People were moving toward the kitchen. I begged a friend who happens to be a chef to do something. He tasted, and without hesitation began pouring in balsamic vinegar and Worcestershire sauce. The soup was suddenly better.

title: Economic Scene; Breathable Air For Swap or Sale
description: HOW in the world is the city where nobody walks going to cut air pollutants by 85 percent? Not easily or cheaply: A ballpark estimate by the David Harrison and Albert Nichols of National Economic Research Associates in Cambridge puts the cost of meeting Federal standards at an astonishing $1,200 a year for every resident of the Los Angeles sprawl.

title: Can't See the Forest for the Sleaze
description: The Forest Service simply does not tolerate freedom of dissent; "whistle-blower" is a four-letter word. The agency has become comfortable with lying to the public, ignoring long-festering problems and serving the timber industry as Government agents of environmental destruction rather than environmental protection.

title: McDonnell Douglas Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $ 72 million, or $ 1.90 a shared, in the quarter and $ 68 million, or $ 1.78 a share, in the year. The periods included a gain of $ 32 million, or 83 cents a share, on the settlement of long-standing issues with the Internal Revenue Service.c-Net lossd-After income from discontinued operations of $ 19 million, or 49 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 37 million, or 97 cents a share, in the year.The 1990 results were positively affected by after-tax gains of $ 234 million, or $ 6.11 a share, in the third quarter and $ 142 million, or $ 3.71 a share, in the fourth quarter from the settlement of certain pension fund obligations. They were negatively affected by a $ 58 million after-tax reversal of previously recorded earnings on the C-17 program in the third quarter and a $ 219 million after-tax loss provision in the fourth quarter related to the A-12 program.Prior year amounts have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: Budget Pretense in New Jersey
description: Gov. Jim Florio's new budget for New Jersey offers more spending, no new taxes and no more layoffs. Nice trick if he could pull it off. But there's a new reality in Trenton. The Democratic Governor's budget will be filtered through a Republican Legislature this year, and the Republicans are determined to cut both taxes and spending. At this stage, both he and they are just sparring.

title: Pools of Memory, Waves of Dispute
description: Henry Burkhardt is scheming to ambush the computer industry.

title: USX-U.S. Steel Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe latest fourth-quarter results included restructuring charges of $ 80 million and various litigation and environmental charges of $ 49 million. Litigation and environmental charges totaled $ 61 million in the year-ago fourth quarter.The 1991 operating loss included restructuring charges of $ 402 million.

title: Sun Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an after-tax $ 124 million provision for write-down of assets and other matters, $ 78 million after tax accrual for environmental remediation, and after-tax losses from discontinued operations of $ 255 million, which included a $ 223 million after-tax provision for write-down of assets and estimated loss on disposition.c-Net income and included losses from discontinued operations of $ 12 million in the quarter and $ 26 million in the year; the year also was after an after-tax tax benefit of $ 30 million from the cumulative effect of change in accounting principle.Year-ago periods were restated to conform to 1991 presentation.

title: The Pop Life
description: Sounds of the 70's

title: Pfizer Narrows List For Visine Account
description: In the review for the creative portion of the Visine eye-drops account, the consumer health-care division of Pfizer Inc. has narrowed the field to four New York agencies: Calet, Hirsch & Spector; Grey Advertising Inc.; Partners & Shevack, and Warwick Baker & Fiore.

title: Personal Health
description: FECAL incontinence is not a subject people talk about in polite company. In fact, it is not a subject people talk about at all. And as a result of reticence born of embarrassment and ignorance, many thousands of children and their families suffer needless humiliation and deep social and emotional scars as the problem persists year after year without proper treatment.

title: Centerior Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bank Yields Drop Slightly
description: Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit dropped slightly for the week ended yesterday, according to figures released by The Bank Rate Monitor, which watches bank rates.

title: Illinois Central reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Business Technology; Programmers May Benefit From Thinking the Old Way
description: Today's conventional single-processor computers generally execute one instruction at a time and can carry out a mathematical operation on only two pieces of data at once. In contrast, parallel computers can carry out thousands of simultaneous mathematical operations.

title: South Jersey Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Procter & Gamble Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Arcatao Journal; Rebel Villages Weary of War, but Wary of Peace
description: At first, Arcatao seemed empty or asleep, a setting waiting for the characters in a tropical novel to be introduced.

title: Losses at Weyerhaeuser
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company today reported a loss for the fourth quarter and year that ended Dec. 29. It was the company's first loss since it began publicly reporting financial results in 1933. The fourth-quarter loss of $256.4 million compared with earnings of $58.8 million, or 30 cents a share, in the 1990 quarter. Sales grew 2 percent, to $2.13 billion. Fourth-quarter 1991 results included restructuring charges of $283 million. For the year, the loss of $161.9 million compared with earnings of $393.7 million, or $1.87 a share, in 1990. Sales declined 4 percent, to $8.7 billion. Results for 1991 included a charge of $61 million for accounting changes.

title: Chile to Seek Bush Testimony
description: The Chilean Supreme Court has approved a judge's request for President Bush to testify in an investigation into the killing in 1976 of Orlando Letelier, officials said here today. Mr. Letelier, a prominent exiled opponent of the Chilean military ruler of the time, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, was killed along with his American aide, Ronni Moffitt, by a car bomb in Washington. In 1976, Mr. Bush was Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Manipulation Case Settled
description: The president of Southland Communications, a small Southern California pager company, agreed yesterday to give up $874,000 in profits and interest on his trades in the company's stock, which the Securities and Exchange Commission said he had manipulated.

title: New Shopper's Guide
description: The Council on Economic Priorities yesterday announced publication of its 1992 edition of Shopping for a Better World, a guide to corporate social policies aimed at influencing consumer buying habits. The 1992 booklet rates 166 companies on 10 social issues, ranging from specifics like investment in South Africa to general categories like charitable giving and environmental performance. Listings that cover Japanese and British companies selling products in American supermarkets were included for the first time. They were based on research by Asahi Journal in Tokyo and New Consumer, a nonprofit British organization based in Newcastle.

title: Interleaf Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Bytex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dow Climbs by 31.53, to a Record 3,272.14
description: Blue-chip stocks resumed their record setting in heavy trading yesterday, while the broader market ended the day just about where it began. The Dow Jones industrial average, after taking an 11-day break following a string of records earlier this month, once again climbed to new heights, gaining 31.53 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 3,272.14.

title: Bank Problems Lingering on Long Island
description: Some of the largest banks on Long Island are finding that their problems with bad real estate loans are lingering longer than at many other banks in the Northeast, whose loan problems have begun to subside.

title: Southeast Asia Nations Sign Free-Trade Accord
description: Leaders of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations agreed today to take their first step toward creating a common market, a response to economic alliances being formed in Europe and North America.

title: Memory Returns; Jury Convicts
description: A man was found guilty today in a 1975 killing after the victim's son suddenly recalled what happened the night of the crime.

title: Review/Film; Murderer Whose Chair Is Electric
description: "Guilty as Charged," which opens today at the Eighth Street Playhouse, tries very hard to satirize moral corruption and succeeds only in being a numbingly eccentric melodrama about lawlessness and disorder.

title: Many Surgeons Reassure Their Patients On Implants
description: Like all physicians, Dr. James L. Baker Jr., a plastic surgeon practicing near Orlando, Fla., has spent his professional life making medical decisions in a climate of scientific uncertainty. But he does seem certain about one thing: the safety of silicone gel breast implants.

title: Theater in Review
description: The Home Show Pieces Public/Martinson Theater 425 Lafayette Street Manhattan Through Feb. 16 Written and directed by David Greenspan; set by William Kennon; costumes by Elsa Ward; lighting by David Bergstein. Presented by the New York Shakespeare Festival, Joseph Papp, founder; JoAnne Akalaitis, artistic director; Jason Steven Cohen, producing director; Rosemarie Tichler, associate artistic director. WITH: Ron Bagden, Tracey Ellis and David Greenspan.

Is Islamic Fundamentalism a New Red Scare?
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Notebook; Digging for Water, and Peace
description: Caleb's daughter, Achsah, was a shrewd and forward-looking Old Testament bride. The Bible reports that when the Israelites returned from bondage in Egypt, Achsah asked for land with "springs of water" as a dowry -- a gift so valuable that nations struggle for it still.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY ASSESSING DINKINS'S PLANS

title: Detroit Signs Fielder to a Record Contract
description: The Detroit Tigers reached a contract agreement with Cecil Fielder yesterday, avoiding a battle in salary arbitration that could have resulted in the first baseman walking away with more than 19 percent of the Tigers' projected 1992 payroll if he had won the record $5.4 million he was seeking.

title: A Fancy Food Store Now Stresses the Food Over the Fancy
description: LASH back to the old Dean & DeLuca, one of the fanciest food stores in the world. Fruits and vegetables were works of art. Piled high in the front of the store, they were exotic, frightfully expensive and, for some people, inspirational.

title: Arkansas Freightways Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: We Should . . . (a Lie) Living Theater 272 East Third Street Manhattan Through Feb. 16 By Kenneth Bernard; directed by Robert Press; lighting by Craig Kennedy; costumes by Daniel Cole; original music by Roberto Pace; assistant director and stage manager, Dena Kazmin; producer, Judith Malina; French text translation, Richard Wilbur; French dialect coach, Joan Templeton. Presented by the Living Theater New Directors Series. WITH: Joanie Fritz, Gene, Lois Kagan, Kevin D. Mayes, Victoria Murphy, Joe Pichette and Michael St. Clair.

title: Ruland Out for 4 Weeks
description: A magnetic resonance imaging test has confirmed that Philadelphia 76ers center JEFF RULAND has a partial tear of the right Achilles' tendon. He will miss about four weeks. Ruland returned to the N.B.A. last month after five years in retirement following a knee injury. (AP)

title: Merck & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Scripps Howard Broadcasting Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 12 million charge related to the settlement of litigation involving Sacramento cable television system. The charge reduced net income by $ 7.9 million, or 77 cents a share.

title: Compaq Earnings Off 51%; Sun Microsystems Up 21%
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that its net income in the fourth quarter was about half what it was in the 1990 period. But sales and earnings rose modestly from depressed levels in the second and third quarters of 1991, exceeding Wall Street estimates.

title: Stuyvesant Shines Again in Westinghouse Awards
description: Those who worry about the decay of New York City schools got some good news yesterday: Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan won four of the 40 prizes in the Westinghouse national science competition.

title: Punishing the Victims in Unwed Births
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON THE ELIMINATION OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. General information phone: (212) 963-1234 Tours are conducted 9 A.M.-5:45 P.M.

title: Stuart Hall reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Suit Charges Extortion Bid Over Condos
description: A Manhattan real-estate developer filed a lawsuit today charging that a Westchester neighborhood association demanded $300,000 in exchange for not opposing a condominium development in Purchase.

title: Review/Television; The Box Spouting Those Voices
description: Tonight is alive with the sounds of radio. Anyone old enough to recall the thrill of hearing voices like Franklin D. Roosevelt's ("This generation of Americans has a rendezvous with destiny"), Edward R. Murrow's and the Shadow's should get a tingle out of "Empire of the Air: The Men Who Made Radio." Ken Burns's two-hour evocation of a time when, as the narrator, Jason Robards, says, America was "a land of listeners" can be seen, and heard, at 9 P.M. on Channels 13, 21 and 49. (If you tune in an hour earlier on Channels 13 and 49, you can also catch "The Brooklyn Bridge," a rebroadcast of another fine documentary by Mr. Burns, the producer of "The Civil War.")

title: Man Killed and 15 Hurt in Car-Van Crash
description: A man was killed and 15 people were injured yesterday when a car hit a van carrying 13 mentally retarded adults in Setauket, L. I.

title: Allied-Signal Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included provisions totaling $ 907 million for streamlining, restructuring and environmental costs and the rationalization of facilities. Also included is an after-tax gain of $ 46 million relating to the sale of a number of its businesses. The after tax impact of these one time items is a loss of $ 615 million. Net income before the charge would have been $ 342 million, or $ 2.51 a share.c-Net incomeSales represented net sales.

title: A 60-ish Murray Louis Still Dances (and Thinks)
description: In nearly four decades as a choreographer, Murray Louis has carved a substantial place for himself in American modern dance. The company he runs with Alwin Nikolais opened a two-week engagement at the Joyce Theater last night. While Mr. Nikolais, who describes himself as an abstract expressionist, has enchanted generations of dancegoers as a theater magician of light and shape, Mr. Louis fills the stage with antic, scribbling motion for himself and others.

title: Review/Film; Under Scrutiny: TV Images Of Blacks
description: "Color Adjustment" is Marlon T. Riggs's cogent and thoughtful survey of black America as represented by American television, from the demeaning stereotypes of "Amos 'n' Andy" to the subtler, more insidious ones of "The Cosby Show." It is Mr. Riggs's well-supported opinion that today's would-be positive images of prosperous, assimilated characters are every bit as damaging as the buffoonish images of the past. Mr. Riggs also documents television's continuing identity crisis as he contrasts the idealized black figures seen on sagas and sitcoms with the harsher, angrier ones provided by the news.

A task force established by the new Director of Central Intelligence, Robert Gates, recommends that he make officials and files more accessible and declassify long-held secrets. The question remains, however: Will this be mere window-dressing?

title: Hanson Denies Imperial Bid
description: The chairman of Hansonz P.L.C. said today that the British conglomerate had no current plans to bid for Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. Hanson bought a 2.8 percent stake in Imperial last May, raising speculation that it might make a bid for Britain's biggest industrial company.

title: Cato Family Home Burns
description: A fire broke out Sunday afternoon in the home of Carmel Cato, the father of Gavin Cato, a 7-year-old Brooklyn boy whose death in a car accident led to several days of racial violence in Crown Heights in August. "There was heavy damage to the apartment," said Tom Kelley, a Fire Department spokesman. Fire marshals investigated the blaze and determined it was accidental, he said. The cause was tentatively believed to be children playing with matches. At the time, the Fire Department said, there were about 20 people in the apartment, on the first floor of 1611 President Avenue. The family was relocated by the Red Cross.

The arc encompasses seven mountain ranges that have the oldest rain forest in Africa.

description: Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, restored to good humor and some short-term political stability by news of several polls showing that most New Hampshire voters care little about recent accusations of marital infidelity, today returned to criticizing President Bush about the nation's troubled economy.

title: Sports of The Times; Approve The Seattle Nintendos
description: For those who think of baseball's 26 owners as the only members of a snobbish country club but could never prove it, proof is now available.

description: Yvonne Bryceland, who was best known for her performances in the anti-apartheid plays of her fellow South African Athol Fugard, died on Jan. 13 at Royal Free Hospital in London. She was 66 years old.

description: Allen D. Graves, a former Mobil Oil executive who helped organize the Kuwait National Petroleum Company, died on Friday at his home in Hilton Head, S.C. He was 76 years old.

description: If they happened to be paying attention, delegates and assorted hangers-on at the Moscow peace talks got tipped off to what lay ahead for them as soon as they stepped off the plane.

Brother Ellis, a De La Salle Christian Brother, will succeed the Rev. WILLIAM J. BYRON, a Jesuit priest, who plans to leave in June to pursue writing projects and to assume parish duties at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in the Georgetown section of Washington.

title: So Far, Nothing Has Been Easy for U.S. Hockey Team
description: Can a team learn to win by losing? We shall see.

title: Suppliers Set to Ship To Macy

description: Five months after deporting a Chinese woman who had fled to Japan to claim political asylum, the Japanese Government reacted with embarrassment and concern today over a new report that she had been arrested and imprisoned in her home province.

title: Buyers of New Volkswagens Get Hedge Against Job Loss
description: To ease the worries of skittish consumers and woo them to its showrooms, Volkswagen of America said today that it would cover car insurance and loan payments for up to a year for new Volkswagen buyers who lose their jobs because of the soured economy.

title: I.B.M. to Invest $100 Million in Groupe Bull
description: I.B.M. will pay about $100 million for a stake in Groupe Bull, France's troubled state-owned computer maker, under a wide-ranging technical and commercial agreement announced today.

title: Man and Woman Die in Brooklyn Shootings
description: A man and a woman were shot to death in separate incidents in Brooklyn last night, the police said. In both cases, the killers escaped.

title: Many Orders For Storage Technology
description: The Storage Technology Corporation said yesterday that it had orders for more than 150 of its radical new Iceberg computer storage systems and that it expects to sell as many as 1,200 of the systems during 1993.

title: ARAB-ISRAEL ON REGIONAL ISSUES START IN MOSCOW

title: U.S.-Japan Group to Explore Big Energy Field Off Siberia
description: Russia today granted a Japanese and American consortium the right to explore what are believed to be huge reserves of oil and gas just off Sakhalin Island, in what may be one of the biggest and, for the Japanese, politically most important business deals since the dissolution of the Soviet Union.

title:
Real Estate;
New Concept And Face Lift For a Mall
description: THE 100-acre enclosed South Hills Mall, which opened on Route 9 here in 1974, has lost much of its luster and customer appeal over the years. Now, to remain competitive, it is undergoing a $25 million renovation and expansion that is transforming it from a full-price mall to an off-price "power" center.

title: STATE OF THE UNION: Looking to Short Term; Economists Say Bush Offers Gifts for Many But Probably Won't Deliver Lasting Growth
description: But as for strengthening the economy over the longer term -- which economists consider far more fundamental than whether $20 billion or $50 billion is pumped in the short term -- many experts saw the President as proposing little new to help.

description: The South African police arrested almost the entire leadership of a far-right white organization early today.

description: Activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was highlighted yesterday by new issues from big bank companies, including Citicorp's first public debt sale in the domestic market since November 1989.

title: VIETNAMESE TO GET FULBRIGHT AWARDS
description: This year, for the first time since the end of the Vietnam War, Washington will be offering scholarships for Vietnamese to study in the United States under the 46-year-old Fulbright fellowship program.

title: Corrections

title: Once a Cold Shoulder, and Now Open Arms

While the meet will be an early test of her ability in an Olympic year, Mutola has something more personal at stake: She will be competing in front of some of the people who questioned her credentials as a scholastic athlete less than a year ago.

title: City College Chief to Seek Removal of Jeffries as Department Head

The company is still in the throes of wrenching operational changes since its merger in 1990 with the Utah Power and Light Company.

description: b-Included a $ 35.8 million after-tax amortization and write-off of all remaining goodwill related to previous acquisitions for the quarter and the year included gain of $ 213,000, or 2 cents a share, on the early extinguishment of debt.c-Net incomed-Included gains of $ 1,678,000, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 5,131,000, or 40 cents a share, for the year, on the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Enron Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains totaling $ 51.8 million, or 51 cents a share, from litigation settlement, property sales, stock sales and other asset sales.c-Included gains totaling $ 94.4 million, or 94 cents a share, from benefit plan cost reduction, a reserve reversal, litigation settlement and property sales.

title: Prowling in Paris For Chic Sofas, etc.
description: BUYING a hand towel or a sofa here can be a small cultural event. In a city where even dogs are allowed to eat baguettes at restaurants, the act of shopping is a social ritual, much more amusing than just spending money. It is best accomplished with well-cut clothes and posture that verges on arrogance.

title: Review/Dance; Twyla Tharp's New Company Makes Debut
description: Twyla Tharp and Dancers is the name of the ever-surprising Miss Tharp's latest venture. Not a permanent company by the choreographer's account but a group formed last summer as a current creative outlet, this heterogeneous collection of dancers -- mostly extraordinary -- opened a two-week debut season at the City Center on Tuesday night.

title: Haiti: Tighten the Embargo
description: Rampaging military hard-liners have torpedoed a promising Haitian political compromise mediated by the Organization of American States. As a result more Haitians are dying, more are fleeing for their lives, and the eventual task of reconstruction has been made more difficult. The hard-liners seem unlikely to permit any settlement unless forced to by a more stringent regional economic embargo.

title: Avia Widens Suit Against Nike
description: Avia Group International Inc., a sports apparel company, broadened its patent infringement suit against Nike Inc., saying the rival company used a basketball-shoe sole on which Avia holds a patent.

title: Chips & Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe company said the latest second quarter included a $ 19.7 million charge related to cost of goods sold for excess and slow-moving inventory and one-time pretax restructuring charges of $ 6.4 million.

title: Review/Opera; The First Met 'Fidelio' of the Season
description: What happens to an opera production as it nears the end of its useful life? To find out, one need only take a look at "Fidelio," which was given its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night.

title: 'Crazy He Calls Me' to Close
description: "Crazy He Calls Me," a play by Abraham Tetenbaum, is to close after the Saturday evening performance at the Walter Kerr Theater, 219 West 48th Street. The play, directed by John Ferraro and starring Polly Draper and Barry Miller, will have had 16 previews and 7 regular performances.

title: The Federal Budget: The Military; Pentagon Offers Some Deep Cuts But Stops There
description: The Bush Administration's proposed military budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 offers deep cuts in long-range nuclear arms and cancels several major weapons, but stops short of fundamental changes in response to the Soviet Union's collapse, budget and military analysts said today.

title: Alpha Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 23,000 for the quarter and $ 150,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 9 months.c-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 105,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 300,000, or 4 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: For Inlaid Wood, Hold the Elbow Grease
description: Because it is often easier to strip, sand and refinish wood than to restore it carefully, too many good antique furniture surfaces have been needlessly lost.

title: Rangers Moving Up and Taking It in Stride
description: Maybe it's because of their history -- so many failures in so many years -- that the Rangers are taking their success now with a kind of collective shrug. They win, but they press on. Next game.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-12

title: For Older Skiers, the More the Merrier on the Slopes
description: For a number of seasons, ski areas have sold discounted lift tickets to skiers 65 years old and over. These "junior" tickets usually cost the same as those sold to youngsters 12 and under. This season, the eastern division of the Professional Ski Instructors of America is testing midweek "senior-day" programs for skiers 50 years old and over.

title: Schult Homes Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to DEc 28
Maxus Energy Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included fourth-quarter charge of $ 6 million to increase environmental reserve due to higher estimates of future expenditures.c-Net income

title: Volvo Might Offer A Cheaper Model
description: Volvo A.B. is considering adding a lower-priced model to its American line that would most likely be built by the French auto maker Renault S.A., a company official said.

title: Philip Morris Income Falls Because of Special Charges
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income fell 12.8 percent, to $767 million, because of charges related to an accounting change and the costs of revamping its worldwide food operations.

title: Protests Bring Ouster of Third Mexican Governor
description: In a development that seems to underscore the unsteady nature of Mexico's progress toward greater democracy, opposition charges of electoral fraud have apparently led to the removal of another state governor.

title: Tyco Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge
description: A challenge match for a stake of $:50,000, about $90,000, was played in London on Monday and Tuesday. It ended in a victory, by 70 imps, for an American foursome using scientific methods. They were Bob Wolff and Bob Hamman of Dallas and Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla., and Eric Rodwell of West Lafayette, Ind.

title: One Valley Bancorp of West Virginia Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Israeli Parties Near Agreement for Election Date
description: Israel's dominant political parties indicated today that they were close to agreement on holding elections in June, but differed on the exact date.

title: Summcorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Despite Criticism, Bush Will Meet Chinese Premier
description: President Bush is to meet Prime Minister Li Peng of China in New York on Friday, the White House announced today.

title: Kaufel Group Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Our Place in the Western Community
description: To the Editor:

title: INDIA ANNOUNCES FULL ISRAELI TIES
description: In another step in its changing approach to the rest of the world, India announced today that it was establishing full diplomatic relations with Israel.

title: A Test of Democracy
description: In the name of raising the standards of public schools, calls have gone out for a national examination -- American Achievement Tests, the Bush Administration calls them -- or at least for some regionally based but universally calibrated assessment system. The rhetoric suggests a voluntary approach, but the intent of the effort belies this. The Administration would like to make these exams America's educational scorecard.

title: New Jersey Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
USF&G Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 24 million in the quarter and $ 32 million in the year, and included realized gains on investments of $ 16 million in the quarter and $ 38 million in the year, and restructuring charges of $ 26 million and $ 60 million in the quarter and year, respectively.c-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 108 million in the quarter and $ 136 million in the year, and included realized losses on investments of $ 357 million in the quarter and $ 354 million in the year, and restructuring charges of $ 34 million in the both periods.

title: Fishing for Tourists By the Musconetcong
description: The biggest fish story in New Jersey is not about the apocryphal whopper that got away, but about the big one that has yet to bite. And while the story still has no ending, its beginning will probably be here in Warren County, in a picturesque trout run called the Musconetcong River.

title: Software Case Countersuit
description: Computer Associates International Inc. said today that it had filed a lawsuit against the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, seeking $2 billion in damages for software fraud.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: New Hampshire; For Roomful of Faithful, Bush's Talk Meets Need
description: The blue Bush placards and brochures were stacked in the kitchen, and the 20-odd people gathered in Newbold and Nancy LeRoy's living room to watch the State of the Union Message Tuesday night were all die-hard Republicans, ready to give the President the benefit of the doubt -- several doubts, in fact.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: INSTALLING sheet vinyl flooring can be challenging for an amateur. Usually, though, a small bathroom or kitchen floor that requires only a single sheet can be managed the first time around.

title: Judge Gives Maximum Term in Kahane Case
description: Sharply criticizing a jury's acquittal on murder charges, a Manhattan judge sentenced an Egyptian immigrant to the maximum sentence of 7 1/3 to 22 years in prison yesterday for gun possession, assault and coercion charges arising from the assassination of Rabbi Meir Kahane.

title: Iran to Sell Draft Exemptions
description: The Iranian Parliament authorized the Government today to sell draft exemption cards for $5,000 apiece, the Teheran radio said. Two years of military service is compulsory for Iranian men over 18, and fear of conscription has discouraged thousands abroad from returning home. The radio report, monitored in Cyprus, did not say how much was expected to be raised by the plan, which was authorized during a debate on a budget bill. The report said the cards would be temporary but did not make clear how long they would be valid.

title: Awards Are Announced For Children's Books
description: Phyllis Reynolds Naylor has been named the winner of the 1992 John Newbery Medal for the most distinguished work of American literature for children for her book "Shiloh" (Atheneum), and David Wiesner won the 1992 Randolph Caldecott Medal for the most distinguished illustrated American book for children for his book "Tuesday" (Clarion Books).

title: Chum Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title:
CURRENTS;
Architects and Investors Who Believe in Ghosts
description: SOME towns never die, but still come close. Port Ludlow, Wash., an old saw mill town and lumber port on Puget Sound, was presumed dead after the mill shut down in 1935. Now Pope Resources, the owner of 3 square miles in the town, has hired several architects to rev up attempts to transform Port Ludlow from a ghost town into a resort for active elderly people.

title: Horizon Financial Services Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Big Time Sarah Chicago Blues 73 Eighth Avenue (between 13th and 14th Streets) Through Saturday

title: Money Fund Yields Drop but Slide Slows
description: Yields on both tax-exempt and taxable money funds continued to decline, but at a slower rate, for the seven-day periods ended Monday and Tuesday, respectively, IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report said yesterday. .

title: Anthony Pisani, Orthopedist, 80; Was a Sports Doctor for 2 Teams
description: Anthony J. Pisani, a noted orthopedist who performed surgery on sports players as a team doctor for the Brooklyn Dodgers and the New York Giants, died Friday at his home in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 80 years old.

title: Clark Tippet, Choreographer, 37; Ballet Theater Principal Dancer
description: Clark Tippet, a choreographer and principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, died on Tuesday at the Labette County Medical Center in Parsons, Kan. He was 37 years old.

title: Singer Co.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
A Tiny Gain For Economy Last Quarter
description: The nation's economy all but came to a standstill in the final quarter of 1991 after two quarters of small advances, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Neither fears of renewed recession nor the Administration's hopes of early recovery were confirmed by the report.

title: Clark Equipment reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe company said included in the 1991 fourth quarter results are special reserves of about $ 17 million, the major part of which relates to work force reductions and plant consolidations.Results for the year include a non-cash reserve of $ 245 million, or $ 14.16 a share, to cover retiree benefits in accordance with a financial accounting rule.

description: b-Included an after-tax amount for severance costs of $ 17.3 million and $ 31.1 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and a $ 31 million tax benefit for both the quarter and year.c-Net incomed-Included an after-tax gain of $ 112.2 million from the sale of a 20-percent stake in its Indonesian subsidiary.

title: Gateway Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Rod Stewart Madison Square Garden

title: Review/Dance; Premiere Opens Season For Nikolais and Louis
description: Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis have been marching to their own choreographic drummer for a long time now. The feast of dance they presented on Tuesday night, when Nikolais and Murray Louis Dance opened a two-week season at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street), was refreshingly new and familiar at the same time. Mr. Nikolais and Mr. Louis are still creating dances that look like no others. And those dances look anything but tired.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ABIE NATHAN, the swashbuckling Israeli philanthropist and peace campaigner, was to have received the Abraham Joshua Heschel Peace Award from the Jewish Peace Fellowship yesterday, but his daughter, SHARONA NATHAN EL SAIEH, had to stand in for him.

title: A Miniaturist of the Novel Who Finds Phones Erotic
description: "Vox" is the sound of two voices rubbing together and generating heat. Random House, its publisher, is calling it "the breakthrough erotic novel of our time." To drive the point home, the publisher sent out advance copies of the book, a conversation between two strangers on a sex telephone line, in a plain brown wrapper. Nicholson Baker, the book's mild-mannered, implausible-looking author, reached way out in left field to pull in the precise word for what goes on between his two characters: "interfingering."

title: Teaneck Officer's Partner Tells Jury Victim Had Hand in Pocket
description: A Teaneck police officer offered a detailed account today of how and why his colleague, Gary Spath, fatally shot 16-year-old Phillip Pannell nearly two years ago.

title: Franklin First Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Central Louisiana Electric Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
People
description: * Estie Todtman, director of national broadcast at Lowe & Partners, New York, has been promoted to senior vice president from vice president.

title: Bills Dismiss Assistant
description: One day after the offensive coordinator, TED MARCHIBRODA, left to become head coach of the Indianapolis Colts, the Buffalo Bills lost another assistant today when they dismissed their defensive line coach, CHUCK DICKERSON.

title: Next Chief Is Picked By Northeast Utilities
description: Northeast Utilities has named its president and chief operating officer, Bernard M. Fox, to succeed William B. Ellis as chief executive in July 1993. The announcement marks the start of a long succession process for New England's largest utility; Mr. Ellis will continue as chairman until he retires in 1995.

title: The Federal Budget: The Overview; PRESIDENT OFFERS CAUTIOUS CHANGES IN SPENDING PLAN
description: In an election-year budget of $1.52 trillion, President Bush called today for modest increases in a wide range of popular domestic programs, but he avoided any major change in spending priorities to fight the recession.

title: Trustco Bank Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods' per share earnings were adjusted for 10 percent stock dividend declared in August 1991.

title: Amcore Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jordan Reserves Rights
description: MICHAEL JORDAN has told the National Basketball Association it may no longer sell apparel bearing his image, giving Nike Inc. those rights exclusively.

title: Laserscope reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and the year included charges of about 20 cents a share on the establishment of a reserve against a high level of inventories and 27 cents a share on the settlement of a shareholder suit.

title: Cadence Design Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included restructuring and merger charges of $ 51.6 million.c-Net incomeThe company said that its merger with Valid Logic was completed in December. All results include the combined operations of Cadence and Valid.

title: The Federal Budget: Taxes; Adjustment Brings In Cash, and Risk
description: Among the more than three dozen tax proposals in the budget request for 1993 that the Bush Administration sent to Congress today, the adjustment of withholding tables for most taxpayers to cut the amount taken out of each paycheck stands alone in needing no Congressional assent.

title: Review/Fashion; Saint Laurent Finds Beauty In Perfect Cut
description: Caught between the glories of its past and the uncertainties of its future, the haute couture industry has been presenting a fragmented image in the showings of its spring and summer collections this week. Forgetting that fashion is based on change, some couturiers are reliving their past successes and others are marching in place, while a few are showing eccentric clothes.

title: Noble Affiliates reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cordero Released From Hospital
description: The Hall of Fame jockey ANGEL CORDERO JR., who suffered multiple injuries in a four-horse spill at Aqueduct on Jan. 12, was released yesterday from Long Island Jewish Hospital. The 49-year-old Cordero suffered internal injuries, a broken elbow and several broken ribs in the spill and underwent surgery to remove his damaged spleen the day after the accident. He was moved out of the intensive care unit nine days later.

title: Imperial Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe bank said the latest fourth quarter included before-tax charges of $ 21 million, consisting of provisions for loan and other losses of $ 12 million, asset valuation adjustments including losses on foreclosed real estate of $ 7 million and lawsuit settlements of $ 2.1 million.Year-ago quarter included $ 6.5 million in charges.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: A CHILD who learns that a parent is having an affair can be expected to react strongly. Some children become angry or protective toward one parent or the other. Others become withdrawn at school or start a string of sexual relationships of their own.

title: Cary to Play in Japan
description: The former Yankee pitcher CHUCK CARY has signed a one-year, $1 million contract to pitch this season for the Tokyo Yomiuri Giants in the Japanese League. Cary was waived by the Yankees on Oct. 28 after a poor season. The 31-year old left-hander was 13-26 with a 4.08 earned run average during his major league career.

title: Dow Corning Starts Investigation of Its Breast-Implant Production
description: The Dow Corning Corporation has hired former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell to investigate its behavior in the making of silicone breast implants, the company said today.

title: Georgia-Pacific reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included write-off of about $ 72 million of capitalized debt issue costs and a gain of $ 27 million, or 31 cents a share, on the sale of an 80 percent ownership interest in two Groundwood paper mills, a sawmill and Associated Hydro-Electric assets and timberlands.c-Included a charge of $ 63 million for an accounting change and a gain of $ 87 million, or $ 1.01 a share, of after tax gains on asset sales.d-Net income and included gain of $ 28 million, or 33 cents a share, on asset sales for both the quarter and year.The company said the 1990 results reflect the acquisition of Great Northern Nekoosa Corp., beginning March 9, 1990.

Billings were not disclosed. * Andre Prost Inc., Old Saybrook, Conn., to Holland Advertising, New York, for two of its brands, Kjeldsen butter cookies and Odense marzipan and almond paste. Billings were not disclosed.

title: A Dream Comes True For McKay
description: Scoring the winning goal at the Forum, the place considered the mecca of hockey in North America, is the dream of every young hockey player growing up in Montreal and that's what Randy McKay did tonight for the Devils.

title: Threat of Lawsuit Enforces Product Safety; Implant Alternative
description: To the Editor:

title: Good Guys reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Triumph to Tragedy In a Year for Penguins
description: Now that they have dropped to a shaky third place in the six-team Patrick Division and to eighth over all in the 22-team National Hockey League, it is tempting to dismiss the Stanley Cup champion Pittsburgh Penguins as one-year wonders returning to the mediocrity that marked their first quarter-century.

description: b-Included a $ 101.3 million charge against earnings which consists of a $ 74.7 million non-cash charge relating to the purchase price for the Bio-Electro Systems Inc. shares, as well as Bio-Electro liabilities which will be assumed by Alza, costs of the Bio-Electro acquisition and costs related to the restructuring of Alza's arrangements with on-site Therapeutics Inc. after related income tax credits of about 2 cents a share, the charge was $ 1.38 a common share.c-Net incomeShare earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective Nov. 29.

Firefighter Plucks Injured Man From Tank
description: A firefighter who was not too big and not too small, but just right, wriggled through a narrow opening into a fuel oil tank in a Bronx apartment building yesterday morning and rescued an unconscious and slippery man, fire officials said.

title: Deal Maker a Torchbearer? Trump Wants Olympics Here
description: Donald Trump once rebuilt the skating rink in Central Park in four months. His latest dream is to bring the Summer Olympics to New York in the year 2004.

title: Home Video
description: Next month Paramount will release "Papa's Delicate Condition" (1963), starring Jackie Gleason. "Dances With Wolves" it isn't, but dealers are moderately enthusiastic. "There are a lot of Jackie Gleason fans out there," said James Ulsamer, a senior vice president of Baker & Taylor, a distributor in Chicago.

title: Getting Through Bridge and Tunnel Tolls Cheaper and Faster
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: House Inquiry Is Expanded Into Research Overcharges
description: The investigation into universities' overcharging the Federal Government for scientific research that began at Stanford University has widened to include not only dozens of other major research universities but also contractors for two Government agencies and the officials who negotiate the research contracts.

title: Stocks Gain in Tokyo
description: Japanese stock prices rose today, pushed higher by bargain hunting and futures-related buying. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 195.41, or just under 1 percent, to close at 21,557.67. On Wednesday, the index fell 28.26 points.

title: Belo (A.H.) Corp.(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Theater: Boesman and Lena; Fugard's Sad Wanderers, With Intimations of Now
description: Whether or not you get to the Manhattan Theater Club's revival of "Boesman and Lena," you can always see another, informal version of its drama day or night on a Manhattan sidewalk or subway platform or vacant lot. Athol Fugard's image of an itinerant homeless couple sheltered within their scrap-heap possessions and awaiting the next official eviction is now as common in New York City, among other places, as it was in the South Africa where he set and wrote his play in the late 1960's. Even at the time of its premiere, "Boesman and Lena" was recognized as a universal work that might speak to audiences long after apartheid had collapsed. But who would have imagined that the universality would soon prove so uncomfortably literal?

title: Russia's Gas Cut-Off Idles Poland's Industry
description: From the Gdansk shipyards to the Galician metalworks factories, much of Poland's industry lay idle today, seven days after Russia reneged on a trade deal and cut off natural gas shipments.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Waste Industries, Houston, a solid waste collection company, acquired National Scavenger Services Inc., Chicago, a waste hauling company, and R.I. Inc., East Moline, Ill., a landfill company, for about 3.6 million shares of Allied common stock and $4.9 million in cash and notes. * Biogenex, San Ramon, Calif., a biotechnology concern, opened foreign subsidiaries in Munich, Germany, and Tokyo.

title: Piper Jaffray Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Marion Merrell Earnings Rise
description: Marion Merrell Dow Inc., a pharmaceutical company, today reported a 15 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings.

title: Arms Makers Brace for Peace
description: Even after six years of gradual Pentagon cuts, the Bush Administration's plan to slash military spending by canceling or scaling back a number of high-profile arms programs came as a jolt to weapons builders and to thousands of workers from Connecticut to California who are likely to lose their jobs in coming years.

title: Macy Getting Welcome Cash
description: With only $200,000 in cash on hand, R. H. Macy & Company received some welcome interim financing yesterday.

title: Howe Faces Delay
description: STEVE HOWE, the Yankee relief pitcher arrested last month on charges of possession of cocaine, faces yet another legal delay in being brought to trial. An arraignment hearing scheduled for Friday in Missoula, Mont., has been rescheduled for Feb. 7.

title: Gulfstream Will Sell Shares
description: The founder and chairman of the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation plans to sell part of his company to the public less than two years after buying it back from the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Valley Capital Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans; Buchanan Says Bush Stole His Ideas
description: The conservative columnist Patrick J. Buchanan, seeking to embarrass President Bush in this state's Feb. 18 primary, today accused Mr. Bush of stealing his agenda in his State of the Union Message and called on the President to debate him.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Anti-Japan Auto Ads May Backfire
description: A RENEWED wave of harsh attacks on Japanese cars and trucks is inundating television and newspapers, as sort of the evil twin of the automotive industry's "Buy American" advertising.

title: Germans Foresee a Sluggish Year
description: The German Government scaled back its economic forecasts for 1992 today, predicting a sharp decline in growth in western Germany and surging unemployment in the formerly Communist east.

title: Corrections
description: The Pulse chart in The Metro Section yesterday, showing three states' driver-registration breakdown by sex, compared with that of the United States at large, reversed the pie-chart labels in some copies. Men, represented by the right-hand segment in each case, made up a larger percentage of drivers in New York, New Jersey and the United States and a smaller percentage in Connecticut, as shown correctly in the accompanying figures.

The Big Store
description: One day this week a woman named Evie Wollman went to Macy's to buy sheets. Coincidentally, her bed was also bought at Macy's. The latter purchase, however, was over 40 years ago, when Mrs. Wollman was 36.

title: Coachmen Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Despite Ups and Down, Calcavecchia Hangs On
description: When Mark Calcavecchia birdied the last four holes to win the Phoenix Open last Sunday, he broke a victory drought of two and a half years and revived his battered confidence.

title: The Federal Budget: The Home Front; For the People of Groton, Peace Pays No Dividend
description: A Baptist minister walked into Mayor Catherine J. Kolnaski's office this morning and offered to say a prayer for her. She gratefully accepted.

title: Remembering an Embodiment of Small-Town Life
description: There is an emptiness lately in this waterside village steeped in its own past, where the trim 18th-century cottages seem plucked from the pages of a storybook and where immortality, at least in the architectural sense, does seem possible.

title: McDonald's Profit Up 8% In Quarter
description: The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that profits increased 8 percent in the fourth quarter as it benefited from discount pricing in the United States and healthy sales overseas.

title: At Home Abroad; Victims in Gaza
description: The town of Rafah is at the southern end of the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip, on the Egyptian border. Even by the standards of Gaza it is a miserable place, much of it a refugee camp: 56,000 people living in concrete hovels, with waste water running through it in open ditches.

title: Candela Laser Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 255,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 383,000, or 7 cents a share, for the 6 months.c-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 290,000, or 5 cents a share, and $ 799,000, or 15 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Destec Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
11 Hospitals Facing Cuts In New York
description: The State Office of Mental Health today proposed shutting down or sharply reducing the number of patients at half of its 22 psychiatric hospitals, a move that would save millions of dollars over the next decade but would shift the burden of caring for the mentally ill to scarce community programs.

title: Nationsbank Presses Bank Trade Groups
description: While many bankers are weary and bruised from last year's unsuccessful effort to revise Federal banking law so that banks could open branches across state lines, Hugh McColl, chairman of Nationsbank, Charlotte, N.C., is itching to renew the battle.

title:

McCabe Jr. president of the general bank division of its First American National Bank unit, John W. Boyle Jr. president of its corporate bank division and Robert E. McNeilly Jr. president of its First American Trust Co. unit. * Gulfstream Aerospace Corp., Savannah, Ga., a unit of Forstmann Little & Co., named William C. Lowe chief executive. He will retain the positions of president and chief operating officer.

title: Yankees Sign Anderson For Minors
description: With no space on their roster but with the opportunity to give a rebounding pitcher a second chance, the Yankees yesterday signed a free agent, Allan Anderson, to a one-year minor league contract that will pay him $500,000 if he makes the major league club.

title: Corrections
description: The Credit Markets column in Business Day on Monday referred incorrectly to bidding activity by Salomon Brothers at Treasury note auctions last April and May where "squeezes" occurred. Salomon's bidding at the April auction has not been questioned by regulators. In a report last week, the Government said the squeeze in May appeared to have been caused by large awards of the securities to Salomon and some of its customers, but it has not been established whether that squeeze resulted from wrongdoing by Salomon.

title: Yeltsin Denies Heavy Drinking
description: Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin, in an interview to be broadcast Friday, disputed rumors that he drinks to excess and said that unlike Mikhail S. Gorbachev, he does not consult his wife about political decisions.

title: Old Story: Flowering Maple Is Newest Hit
description: "EVERYTHING that's new is old," said Rudy Nabel. "Like hemlines. And the flowering maple."

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media; In Manchester, the Charge Is Mellow Journalism
description: So far this campaign, all the Presidential candidates have resisted the traditional temptation to stand outside The Union Leader building and denounce its publisher as an irresponsible liar. But the state's largest and most opinionated newspaper has had to confront even more troubling charges. They were summarized in The Boston Globe's recent headline: "Mellowed Union Leader loses some influence on primary."

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about the bankruptcy filing by R. H. Macy & Company, and a chart in Business Day yesterday listing the largest Macy creditors, included one company as a creditor erroneously because of an error in the bankruptcy documents. Alexander & Alexander, an insurance brokerage, is not a creditor.

Coverage of Smoking Linked to Tobacco Ads
description: A new report by researchers at the University of Michigan says that magazines that carry cigarette advertising have consistently restricted or softened coverage of the dangers of smoking, possibly out of fear of economic reprisals by cigarette manufacturers.

description: In the basement of the New York City Criminal Courts Building in Brooklyn recently, so many men were crammed into four small holding pens that most had only enough room to stand.

description: Buoyed by what he saw as President Bush's endorsement of New Jersey's new welfare revision laws during the State of the Union Message on Tuesday, Assemblyman Wayne R. Bryant, the author of the laws, said today that he expected White House support to speed their implementation.

The Saatch-skis and their client, the Nynex man! A commercialmundo. Bad scene! Bad scene!"

title: 3 Architects to Share Wolf Prize in the Arts
description: Three architects have been named to share this year's Wolf Prize in the Arts, a $100,000 cash award given by the Wolf Foundation in Jerusalem. The architects -- Frank O. Gehry of Santa Monica, Calif.; Jorn Utzon of Copenhagen, and Sir Denys Lasdun of London -- were chosen last week for "qualities existing well beyond the range of passing fashion, qualities that enhance use, transform construction and liberate the mind."

title: Prospects Warned About the Dangers of Life
description: Steve Palermo and Dr. Lonise Bias would not seem to have a lot in common, one being a major league umpire, arguably the best in his profession, the second being a doctor of religion, blessed with the evangelical passion and fervor of a Martin Luther King.

description: AS her bills piled up last year, Grace G. became so worried about her finances that she felt she had only one option: to give up part of her home in a Westchester village to a stranger.

description: Leaders of American business offered a range of reactions to the economic proposals in President Bush's State of the Union Message, and disagreed sharply over the pressure the President put on Congress to enact legislation in an election year.

title: Clinton's Middle Class Hang-Up
description: With style and shrewdness, Gov. Bill Clinton appears to have beaten the rap on his philandering and emerged stronger than he was before the Gennifer Flowers episode came up. Unless a second shoe (or bedroom slipper) drops to indicate he's a liar, his national exposure during his troubles has helped establish him more clearly as the Democrats' front-runner and likely nominee.

title: Sordid Business Booms in Queens
description: Roosevelt Avenue by day is a whirl of traffic and shoppers, to the roar and clatter of the I.R.T. passing overhead.

description: The cold war is over and the Soviet Union has disintegrated, but Capt. Mike Riegel and his crew still lurk in the depths of the Atlantic Ocean daily rehearsing a nuclear attack on the former superpower.

title: Students' Demand For Condoms Seems Limited but Steady
description: The first day condoms were made available at Walton High School in the Bronx, a line of 30 students stretched outside Alan Ettman's door, like Russians waiting for sugar and eggs.

title: In a World of Symbols, One Brings Confusion
description: WE live in an age of icon overload. The profusion of symbols is everywhere: in ever-obliging male silhouettes that indicate the location of the nearest trash receptacle, and in magazine articles that end in a flourish with a little square.

Craft Becomes Art, In Colored Glass
description: TO many museumgoers, the word crafts brings to mind self-consciously imperfect clay pots and nubby macrame wall hangings. Not to Janet Kardon, director of the American Craft Museum. For her, architecturally scaled "art" pieces fit just as nicely into the museum's ethos as folksy wood carvings.
